verse1.english: Dhritarashtra Uvācha: Dharmakshetre Kurukshetre Samaveta Yuyutsavah | Māmakāh Pāndavāshchaiva Kimakurvata Sanjaya || 1 ||
verse1.explanation: Dhritarashtra, who is blind, asks Sanjaya to narrate the events of the battlefield of Kurukshetra, where the great war is about to take place between his sons (the Kauravas) and the Pandavas.
verse1.sanskrit: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच | धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः | मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय || 1 ||

verse2.english: Sanjaya Uvācha: Drishtvā Tu Pāndavāneekam Vyoodham Duryodhanastadā | Āchāryamupasangamya Rājā Vachanamabraveet || 2 ||
verse2.explanation: Duryodhana, the leader of the Kauravas, sees the Pandava army ready for battle and goes to his mentor, Dronacharya, to discuss the situation.
verse2.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच | दृष्ट्वा तु पाण्डवानीकं व्यूढं दुर्योधनस्तदा | आचार्यमुपसंगम्य राजा वचनमब्रवीत् || 2 ||

verse3.english: Pashyaitām Pānduputrānām Āchārya Mahateem Chamoom | Vyoodhām Drupadaputrena Tava Shishyena Dheemataa || 3 ||
verse3.explanation: Duryodhana points out to Dronacharya that the Pandava army has been arranged strategically by Dronacharya’s own disciple, Dhrishtadyumna, the son of Drupada.
verse3.sanskrit: पश्यैतां पाण्डुपुत्राणामाचार्य महतीं चमूम् | व्यूढां द्रुपदपुत्रेण तव शिष्येण धीमता || 3 ||

verse4.english: Atra Shoorā Maheshwāsā Bheemārjunasamā Yudhi | Yuyudhāno Virātashcha Drupadashcha Mahārathah || 4 ||
verse4.explanation: Duryodhana highlights the strength of the Pandava army, mentioning several great warriors who are capable of formidable combat.
verse4.sanskrit: अत्र शूरा महेष्वासा भीमार्जुनसमा युधि | युयुधानो विराटश्च द्रुपदश्च महारथः || 4 ||

verse5.english: Dhrishtaketuśh Chekitānah Kāshirājashcha Veeryavān | Purujit Kuntibhojashcha Shaibyashcha Narapungavah || 5 ||
verse5.explanation: Duryodhana continues to list the names of more powerful warriors in the Pandava army, recognizing their might.
verse5.sanskrit: धृष्टकेतुश्चेकितानः काशिराजश्च वीर्यवान् | पुरुजित्कुन्तिभोजश्च शैब्यश्च नरपुंगवः || 5 ||

verse6.english: Yudhāmanyuśhcha Vikrānta Uttamaujāścha Veeryavān | Saubhadro Draupadeyāshcha Sarva Eva Mahārathāh || 6 ||
verse6.explanation: The verse lists more warriors on the Pandava side, emphasizing the strength and capability of their army.
verse6.sanskrit: युधामन्युश्च विक्रान्त उत्तमौजाश्च वीर्यवान् | सौभद्रो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्व एव महारथाः || 6 ||

verse7.english: Asmākam Tu Vishishtā Ye Tānnibodha Dwijoottama | Nāyakā Mama Sainyasya Samjñārtham Tānbraveemi Te || 7 ||
verse7.explanation: Duryodhana turns his attention to the warriors in his own army, beginning to name those who are the most distinguished.
verse7.sanskrit: अस्माकं तु विशिष्टा ये तान्निबोध द्विजोत्तम | नायका मम सैन्यस्य संज्ञार्थं तान्ब्रवीमि ते || 7 ||

verse8.english: Bhavān Bhīshmaścha Karṇaścha Kripaścha Samitinjayaḥ | Ashwatthāmā Vikarṇaścha Saumadattistathaiva Cha || 8 ||
verse8.explanation: Duryodhana lists the key warriors in his army, beginning with Dronacharya, Bhishma, Karna, and others, who are known for their prowess in battle.
verse8.sanskrit: भवान्भीष्मश्च कर्णश्च कृपश्च समितिंजयः | अश्वत्थामा विकर्णश्च सौमदत्तिस्तथैव च || 8 ||

verse9.english: Anye Cha Bahavah Shoorā Madarthe Tyaktajeevitāḥ | Nānāshastrapraharanāḥ Sarve Yuddhavishāradāḥ || 9 ||
verse9.explanation: Duryodhana acknowledges the many other warriors in his army who are prepared to lay down their lives for his cause.
verse9.sanskrit: अन्ये च बहवः शूरा मदर्थे त्यक्तजीविताः | नानाशस्त्रप्रहरणाः सर्वे युद्धविशारदाः || 9 ||

verse10.english: Aparyāptam Tadasmākam Balam Bhīshmābhirakshitam | Paryāptam Twidametesām Balam Bhīmābhirakshitam || 10 ||
verse10.explanation: Duryodhana compares the strength of his army to that of the Pandavas, expressing confidence in his forces, which are led by Bhishma, while noting that the Pandavas are led by Bhima.
verse10.sanskrit: अपर्याप्तं तदस्माकं बलं भीष्माभिरक्षितम् | पर्याप्तं त्विदमेतेषां बलं भीमाभिरक्षितम् || 10 ||

verse11.english: Ayaneshu Cha Sarveshu Yathābhāgamavasthitāḥ | Bhīshmamevābhirakshantu Bhavantah Sarva Eva Hi || 11 ||
verse11.explanation: Duryodhana instructs his warriors to ensure that Bhishma, their most powerful and senior warrior, is well protected during the battle.
verse11.sanskrit: अयनेषु च सर्वेषु यथाभागमवस्थिताः | भीष्ममेवाभिरक्षन्तु भवन्तः सर्व एव हि || 11 ||

verse12.english: Tasya Sanjanayanharsham Kuruvriddhah Pitāmahah | Simhanādam Vinadyocchaih Shankham Dadhmau Pratāpavān || 12 ||
verse12.explanation: In response to Duryodhana’s words, Bhishma blows his conch to boost the morale of the Kaurava army, signaling the start of the battle.
verse12.sanskrit: तस्य सञ्जनयन्हर्षं कुरुवृद्धः पितामहः | सिंहनादं विनद्योच्चैः शङ्खं दध्मौ प्रतापवान् || 12 ||

verse13.english: Tatah Shankhāścha Bheryāścha Paṇavānakagomukhāḥ | Sahasaivābhyahanyanta Sa Shabdaḥ Tumulo’bhavat || 13 ||
verse13.explanation: The blowing of Bhishma’s conch is followed by a cacophony of war sounds as the Kaurava army prepares for battle, creating a tumultuous atmosphere.
verse13.sanskrit: ततः शङ्खाश्च भेर्यश्च पणवानकगोमुखाः | सहसैवाभ्यहन्यन्त स शब्दस्तुमुलोऽभवत् || 13 ||

verse14.english: Tatah Shvetairhayairyukte Mahati Syandane Sthitau | Mādhavah Pāndavaśchaiva Divyau Shankhau Pradadhmatuh || 14 ||
verse14.explanation: Lord Krishna and Arjuna, the principal heroes of the Pandava side, also blow their conches, signaling their readiness for battle.
verse14.sanskrit: ततः श्वेतैर्हयैर्युक्ते महति स्यन्दने स्थितौ | माधवः पाण्डवश्चैव दिव्यौ शङ्खौ प्रदध्मतुः || 14 ||

verse15.english: Pāñchajanyam Hrisheekesho Devadattam Dhananjayah | Paundram Dadhmau Mahāshankham Bhīmakarmā Vrkodarah || 15 ||
verse15.explanation: The verse describes the specific conches blown by Krishna, Arjuna, and Bhima, each of which has a significant name and represents their individual might and determination.
verse15.sanskrit: पाञ्चजन्यं हृषीकेशो देवदत्तं धनञ्जयः | पौण्ड्रं दध्मौ महाशङ्खं भीमकर्मा वृकोदरः || 15 ||

verse16.english: Anantavijayam Rājā Kuntīputro Yudhishthirah | Nakulah Sahadevashcha Sughoshamaṇipushpakau || 16 ||
verse16.explanation: The verse mentions the conches blown by the other Pandavas: Yudhishthira, Nakula, and Sahadeva, each with its own unique name and significance.
verse16.sanskrit: अनन्तविजयं राजा कुन्तीपुत्रो युधिष्ठिरः | नकुलः सहदेवश्च सुघोषमणिपुष्पकौ || 16 ||

verse17.english: Kāshyaścha Parameshvāsah Shikhandi Cha Mahārathah | Dhrishtadyumno Virātashcha Sātyakishchāparājitah || 17 ||
verse17.explanation: The verse continues listing the warriors on the Pandava side, each of whom blows their conch to signal their participation in the battle.
verse17.sanskrit: काश्यश्च परमेष्वासः शिखण्डी च महारथः | धृष्टद्युम्नो विराटश्च सात्यकिश्चापराजितः || 17 ||

verse18.english: Drupado Draupadeyāścha Sarvashah Prithiveepate | Saubhadraścha Mahābāhuh Shankhāndadhmuh Prithakprithak || 18 ||
verse18.explanation: The verse mentions the other important warriors on the Pandava side, including Drupada, the sons of Draupadi, and Abhimanyu, who also signal their readiness to fight.
verse18.sanskrit: द्रुपदो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्वशः पृथिवीपते | सौभद्रश्च महाबाहुः शङ्खान्दध्मुः पृथक्पृथक् || 18 ||

verse19.english: Sa Ghosho Dhārtarāshtrānām Hridāyāni Vyadārayat | Nabhahcha Prithiveem Chaiva Tumulo’bhyānunādayan || 19 ||
verse19.explanation: The combined sound of the Pandavas’ conches is so powerful that it strikes fear into the hearts of the Kauravas.
verse19.sanskrit: स घोषो धार्तराष्ट्राणां हृदयानि व्यदारयत् | नभश्च पृथिवीं चैव तुमुलोऽभ्यनुनादयन् || 19 ||

verse20.english: Atha Vyavasthitān Drishtvā Dhārtarāshtrānkapidhvajah | Pravritte Shastrasampāte Dhanurudyamya Pāndavah || 20 ||
verse20.explanation: Arjuna, the great warrior of the Pandavas, prepares himself for battle, taking up his bow as the fight is about to begin.
verse20.sanskrit: अथ व्यवस्थितान्दृष्ट्वा धार्तराष्ट्रान्कपिध्वजः | प्रवृत्ते शस्त्रसंपाते धनुरुद्यम्य पाण्डवः || 20 ||

verse21.english: Hrishikesham Tadā Vākyamidamāha Maheepate | Arjuna Uvācha: Senayorubhayormadhye Ratham Sthāpaya Me’chuta || 21 ||
verse21.explanation: Arjuna asks Krishna, his charioteer, to position the chariot between the two armies so that he can observe those who have gathered for battle.
verse21.sanskrit: हृषीकेशं तदा वाक्यमिदमाह महीपते | अर्जुन उवाच | सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये रथं स्थापय मेऽच्युत || 21 ||

verse22.explanation: Arjuna wants to see who is on the battlefield, ready to fight, so that he can assess whom he will be confronting in the battle.

verse23.english: Yotsyamānānavekshe’ham Ya Ete’tra Samāgatāh | Dhārtarāshtrasya Durbuddheryuddhe Priyachikeershavah || 23 ||
verse23.explanation: Arjuna expresses a desire to see the warriors who have gathered to fight for Duryodhana, the son of Dhritarashtra, whom he considers to be of wicked intent.
verse23.sanskrit: योत्स्यमानानवेक्षेऽहं य एतेऽत्र समागताः | धार्तराष्ट्रस्य दुर्बुद्धेर्युद्धे प्रियचिकीर्षवः || 23 ||

verse24.english: Sanjaya Uvācha: Evamukto Hrisheekesho Guḍākeśena Bhārata | Senayorubhayormadhye Sthāpayitvā Rathottamam || 24 ||
verse24.explanation: Sanjaya narrates that Krishna, on Arjuna’s request, placed the chariot between the two armies, giving Arjuna a clear view of both sides.
verse24.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच | एवमुक्तो हृषीकेशो गुडाकेशेन भारत | सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये स्थापयित्वा रथोत्तमम् || 24 ||

verse25.english: Bheeshma-Dronapramukhatah Sarveshām Cha Maheekshitām | Uvācha Pārtha Pashyaitān Samavetān Kurooniti || 25 ||
verse25.explanation: Krishna points out to Arjuna the assembled warriors on the battlefield, especially drawing attention to Bhishma, Drona, and others.
verse25.sanskrit: भीष्मद्रोणप्रमुखतः सर्वेषां च महीक्षिताम् | उवाच पार्थ पश्यैतान्समवेतान्कुरूनिति || 25 ||

verse26.english: Tatrāpaśhyat Sthitān Pārthah Pitṝnatha Pitāmahān | Āchāryān Mātulān Bhrātrṝn Putrān Poutrān Sakhīn Tathā || 26 ||
verse26.explanation: Arjuna sees many of his relatives and close ones on the battlefield, including his elders, teachers, and dear friends, all ready to fight.

verse27.english: Shwashurān Suhridashchaiva Senayorubhayorapi | Tānsameekshya Sa Kaunteyah Sarvān Bandhoonavasthitān || 27 ||
verse27.explanation: Arjuna notices the presence of his family members, including fathers-in-law and well-wishers, on both sides, which deeply disturbs him.
verse27.sanskrit: श्वशुरान्सुहृदश्चैव सेनयोरुभयोरपि | तान्समीक्ष्य स कौन्तेयः सर्वान्बन्धूनवस्थितान् || 27 ||

verse28.english: Kripayā Parayāviṣhṭo Viṣhīdannidamabravīt | Arjuna Uvācha: Dṛiṣhṭvemaṁ Swajanaṁ Krishna Yuyutsuṁ Samupasthitam || 28 ||
verse28.explanation: Overcome by compassion and sorrow, Arjuna is dismayed to see his own relatives on the battlefield, ready to fight against each other.
verse28.sanskrit: कृपया परयाविष्टो विषीदन्निदमब्रवीत् | अर्जुन उवाच | दृष्ट्वेमं स्वजनं कृष्ण युयुत्सुं समुपस्थितम् || 28 ||

verse29.english: Sīdanti Mama Gātrāṇi Mukhaṁ Cha Pariśhuṣhyati | Vepathuśhcha Sharīre Me Romaharṣhaśhcha Jāyate || 29 ||
verse29.explanation: Arjuna describes the physical symptoms of his inner turmoil, expressing the intense emotional conflict he feels at the prospect of fighting against his own kin.
verse29.sanskrit: सीदन्ति मम गात्राणि मुखं च परिशुष्यति | वेपथुश्च शरीरे मे रोमहर्षश्च जायते || 29 ||

verse30.english: Gāṇḍīvaṁ Sraṁsate Hastāttvakchaiva Paridahyate | Na Cha Shaknomyavasthātuṁ Brahmatīva Cha Me Manaḥ || 30 ||
verse30.explanation: Arjuna, overwhelmed by his emotions, finds himself physically unable to continue. His mind is in turmoil, and he feels incapacitated.
verse30.sanskrit: गाण्डीवं स्रंसते हस्तात्त्वक्चैव परिदह्यते | न च शक्नोम्यवस्थातुं भ्रमतीव च मे मनः || 30 ||

verse31.english: Nimittāni Cha Paśhyāmi Viparītāni Keśhava | Na Cha Śhreyo’nupaśhyāmi Hatvā Swajanamāhave || 31 ||
verse31.explanation: Arjuna perceives negative omens and believes that nothing good can come from engaging in a battle that will lead to the death of his own relatives.
verse31.sanskrit: निमित्तानि च पश्यामि विपरीतानि केशव | न च श्रेयोऽनुपश्यामि हत्वा स्वजनमाहवे || 31 ||

verse32.english: Na Kāṅkṣhe Vijayaṁ Krishna Na Cha Rājyaṁ Sukhāni Cha | Kiṁ No Rājyena Govinda Kiṁ Bhogairjīvitena Vā || 32 ||
verse32.explanation: Arjuna questions the purpose of the war, stating that he has no desire for victory, power, or pleasure if it comes at the cost of killing his loved ones.
verse32.sanskrit: न काङ्क्षे विजयं कृष्ण न च राज्यं सुखानि च | किं नो राज्येन गोविन्द किं भोगैर्जीवितेन वा || 32 ||

verse33.english: Yeṣhāmarthe Kāṅkṣhitaṁ No Rājyaṁ Bhogāḥ Sukhāni Cha | Ta Ime’vasthitā Yuddhe Prāṇāṁstyaktvā Dhanāni Cha || 33 ||
verse33.explanation: Arjuna reflects that those for whom he seeks victory are the very people who are ready to fight and die on the battlefield, making the pursuit of such goals meaningless.
verse33.sanskrit: येषामर्थे काङ्क्षितं नो राज्यं भोगाः सुखानि च | त इमेऽवस्थिता युद्धे प्राणांस्त्यक्त्वा धनानि च || 33 ||

verse34.english: Āchāryāḥ Pitarah Putrās Tathaiva Cha Pitāmahāḥ | Mātulāḥ Śhwaśhurāḥ Poutrāḥ Śhyālāḥ Sambandhinas Tathā || 34 ||
verse34.explanation: Arjuna lists the relationships he sees on the battlefield, emphasizing the familial ties that make the prospect of war so distressing for him.
verse34.sanskrit: आचार्याः पितरः पुत्रास्तथैव च पितामहाः | मातुलाः श्वशुराः पौत्राः श्यालाः सम्बन्धिनस्तथा || 34 ||

verse35.english: Etān Na Hantumichhāmi GhNato’pi Madhusūdana | Api Trailokyarājyasya Hetoḥ Kiṁ Nu Maheekrite || 35 ||
verse35.explanation: Arjuna declares that he does not desire to kill his relatives even if it would gain him dominion over the entire universe, let alone for mere earthly power.
verse35.sanskrit: एतान्न हन्तुमिच्छामि घ्नतोऽपि मधुसूदन | अपि त्रैलोक्यराज्यस्य हेतोः किं नु महीकृते || 35 ||

verse36.english: Nihatya Dhārtarāṣhṭrān Naḥ Kā Prītiḥ Syājjanārdana | Pāpamevāśhrayedasmān Hatvaitānātatāyinaḥ || 36 ||
verse36.explanation: Arjuna argues that even though the Kauravas are aggressors, killing them will only bring sin and no real happiness.
verse36.sanskrit: निहत्य धार्तराष्ट्रान्नः का प्रीतिः स्याज्जनार्दन | पापमेवाश्रयेदस्मान्हत्वैतानाततायिनः || 36 ||

verse37.english: Tasmān Nārhā Vayaṁ Hantuṁ Dhārtarāṣhṭrān Svabāndhavān | Swajanaṁ Hi Kathaṁ Hatvā Sukhinah Syāma Mādhava || 37 ||
verse37.explanation: Arjuna concludes that killing his own relatives, the sons of Dhritarashtra, would not bring happiness, and thus, they should not engage in such an act.
verse37.sanskrit: तस्मान्नार्हा वयं हन्तुं धार्तराष्ट्रान्स्वबान्धवान् | स्वजनं हि कथं हत्वा सुखिनः स्याम माधव || 37 ||

verse38.english: Yadyapyete Na Pashyanti Lobhopahatachetasah | Kulakṣhayakṛitaṁ Doṣhaṁ Mitradrohe Cha Pātakam || 38 ||
verse38.explanation: Arjuna acknowledges that the Kauravas, blinded by greed, are unable to see the grave consequences of destroying their own family and betraying friends.
verse38.sanskrit: यद्यप्येते न पश्यन्ति लोभोपहतचेतसः | कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं मित्रद्रोहे च पातकम् || 38 ||

verse39.english: Katham Na Jñeyamasmābhih Pāpādasmānnivartitum | Kulakṣhayakṛitaṁ Doṣhaṁ Prapaśhyadbhiḥ Janārdana || 39 ||
verse39.explanation: Arjuna questions how they, who understand the sin involved in killing their own relatives, could choose to commit such an act.
verse39.sanskrit: कथं न ज्ञेयमस्माभिः पापादस्मान्निवर्तितुम् | कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं प्रपश्यद्भिर्जनार्दन || 39 ||

verse40.english: Kulakṣhaye Praṇaśhyanti Kuladharmāḥ Sanātanāh | Dharme Naṣhṭe Kulaṁ Kṛitsnam Adharmo’bhibhavatyuta || 40 ||
verse40.explanation: Arjuna laments that the destruction of a family leads to the loss of its traditions and moral values, and without law, the entire family falls into chaos.
verse40.sanskrit: कुलक्षये प्रणश्यन्ति कुलधर्माः सनातनाः | धर्मे नष्टे कुलं कृत्स्नमधर्मोऽभिभवत्युत || 40 ||

verse41.english: Adharmābhibhavāt Krishna Praduṣhyanti Kulastriyah | Strīṣhu Duṣṭāsu Vārṣhṇeya Jāyate Varṇa-saṅkaraḥ || 41 ||
verse41.explanation: Arjuna points out that the degradation of women due to lawlessness results in societal disorder and moral decay, leading to undesirable social consequences.
verse41.sanskrit: अधर्माभिभवात्कृष्ण प्रदुष्यन्ति कुलस्त्रियः | स्त्रीषु दुष्टासु वार्ष्णेय जायते वर्णसङ्करः || 41 ||

verse42.english: Saṅkaro Narakāyaiva Kulaghnānāṁ Kulasya Cha | Patanti Pitaro Hyeṣhāṁ Luptapiṇḍodakakriyāh || 42 ||
verse42.explanation: Arjuna describes how societal disorder causes the family to fall into hell, and their ancestors suffer due to the discontinuation of ancestral rites.
verse42.sanskrit: सङ्करो नरकायैव कुलघ्नानां कुलस्य च | पतन्ति पितरो ह्येषां लुप्तपिण्डोदकक्रियाः || 42 ||

verse43.english: Doṣhairetaih Kulaghnānāṁ Varṇasaṅkarakārakaih | Utsādyante Jātidharmāh Kuladharmāśhcha Śhāśhvatāh || 43 ||
verse43.explanation: Arjuna laments that the sinful actions leading to societal disorder also result in the destruction of long-standing family and social traditions.
verse43.sanskrit: दोषैरेतैः कुलघ्नानां वर्णसङ्करकारकैः | उत्साद्यन्ते जातिधर्माः कुलधर्माश्च शाश्वताः || 43 ||

verse44.english: Utsannakuladharmāṇāṁ Manushyāṇāṁ Janārdana | Narake’niyataṁ Vāso Bhavatītyanuśhuśhruma || 44 ||
verse44.explanation: Arjuna recalls that those who abandon their family traditions are doomed to suffer in hell indefinitely.
verse44.sanskrit: आश्चर्यम् मा प्रेत्य विषमश्च विवेदनद्वारे विविधानां दृश्यं तु न कोऽपि न मणिज्ञातम्

verse45.english: Aho Bata Mahatpāpaṁ Kartuṁ Vyavasitā Vayam | Yad Rājyasukhalobhena Hantuṁ Swajanamudyatāh || 45 ||
verse45.explanation: Arjuna is distressed by the realization that their pursuit of power and pleasure is leading them to commit the grievous sin of killing their own family members.
verse45.sanskrit: अहो बत महत्पापं कर्तुं व्यवसिता वयम् | यद्राज्यसुखलोभेन हन्तुं स्वजनमुद्यताः || 45 ||

verse46.english: Yadi Mām Apratīkāram Aśhastraṁ Śhastrapāṇayah | Dhārtarāṣhṭrā Raṇe Hanyuḥ Tanme Kṣhemataraṁ Bhavet || 46 ||
verse46.explanation: Arjuna expresses that he would prefer to be killed unresisting and unarmed by the Kauravas rather than engage in the battle that would lead to the destruction of his family.
verse46.sanskrit: यदि मामप्रतीकारमशस्त्रं शस्त्रपाणयः | धार्तराष्ट्रा रणे हन्युः तन्मे क्षेमतरं भवेत् || 46 ||

verse47.english: Sanjaya Uvācha: Evamuktvā’rjunaḥ Saṅkhye Rathopastha Upāviśhat | Visṛijya Sa-śharaṁ Chāpaṁ Śhoka-saṁvigna-mānasaḥ || 47 ||
verse47.explanation: Sanjaya concludes the chapter by narrating that Arjuna, overcome by sorrow and confusion, discards his weapons and sits down in his chariot, deeply troubled and unable to fight.
verse47.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच | एवमुक्त्वार्जुनः सङ्ख्ये रथोपस्थ उपाविशत् | विसृज्य सशरं चापं शोकसंविग्नमानसः || 47 ||

verse1.english: sangrāme samare yodhā tava vikrama kopitaḥ nāsmin maraṇaṁ gatvā vyavasthitāś charati
verse1.explanation: Arjuna is overwhelmed by grief and compassion at the thought of fighting against his own relatives, teachers, and friends in the battle. Sanjaya, who is narrating the events to King Dhritarashtra, describes Arjuna’s emotional state before Krishna begins his teachings.
verse1.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच | तं तथा कृपयाविष्टमश्रुपूर्णाकुलेक्षणम् | विषीदन्तमिदं वाक्यमुवाच मधुसूदनः || 1 ||

verse2.english: śrī-bhagavān uvāca | kutas tvā kaśmalam idaṃ viṣame samupasthitam | anārya-juṣṭam asvargyam akīrti-karam arjuna || 2 ||
verse2.explanation: Krishna gently reprimands Arjuna for his uncharacteristic display of weakness and confusion. He emphasizes that such behavior is not suitable for a warrior of Arjuna’s stature, and it will neither lead to spiritual progress nor earn him any respect.
verse2.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | कुतस्त्वा कश्मलमिदं विषमे समुपस्थितम् | अनार्यजुष्टमस्वर्ग्यमकीर्तिकरमर्जुन || 2 ||

verse3.english: klaibyaṃ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitat tvayy upapadyate | kṣudraṃ hṛdaya-daurbalyaṃ tyaktvottiṣṭha parantapa || 3 ||
verse3.explanation: Krishna encourages Arjuna to abandon his weakness and rise to the occasion. He reminds Arjuna of his duty as a Kshatriya (warrior class) and urges him to overcome his doubts and fears.
verse3.sanskrit: क्लैब्यं मा स्म गमः पार्थ नैतत्त्वय्युपपद्यते | क्षुद्रं हृदयदौर्बल्यं त्यक्त्वोत्तिष्ठ परन्तप || 3 ||

verse4.english: arjuna uvāca | kathaṃ bhīṣmam ahaṃ saṅkhye droṇaṃ ca madhusūdana | iṣubhiḥ pratiyotsyāmi pūjārhāv arisūdana || 4 ||
verse4.explanation: Arjuna expresses his inner conflict and reluctance to fight against revered figures like Bhishma and Drona, who have been his teachers and elders. He is torn between his duty as a warrior and his respect for these great men.
verse4.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | कथं भीष्ममहं सङ्ख्ये द्रोणं च मधुसूदन | इषुभिः प्रतियोत्स्यामि पूजार्हावरिसूदन || 4 ||

verse5.english: gurūn ahatvā hi mahānubhāvān śreyo bhoktuṃ bhaikṣyam apīha loke | hatvārtha-kāmāṃs tu gurūn ihaiva bhuñjīya bhogān rudhira-pradigdhān || 5 ||
verse5.explanation: Arjuna further laments that killing his elders and teachers, even for the sake of a kingdom, would result in a life of sorrow and guilt. He feels that it would be better to live a humble life rather than one filled with wealth and power gained through such sinful actions.
verse5.sanskrit: गुरूनहत्वा हि महानुभावान् श्रेयो भोक्तुं भैक्ष्यमपीह लोके | हत्वार्थकामांस्तु गुरूनिहैव भुञ्जीय भोगान्रुधिरप्रदिग्धान् || 5 ||

verse6.english: na caitad vidmaḥ kataran no garīyo yad vā jayema yadi vā no jayeyuḥ | yān eva hatvā na jijīviṣāmas te 'vasthitāḥ pramukhe dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ || 6 ||
verse6.explanation: Arjuna is so disheartened that he cannot even decide whether it is better to fight and win or to lose. The thought of killing his own relatives and friends makes him question the purpose of the battle altogether.
verse6.sanskrit: न चैतद्विद्मः कतरन्नो गरीयो यद्वा जयेम यदि वा नो जयेयुः | यानेव हत्वा न जिजीविषामः तेऽवस्थिताः प्रमुखे धार्तराष्ट्राः || 6 ||

verse7.english: kārpaṇya-doṣopahata-svabhāvaḥ pṛcchāmi tvāṃ dharma-sammūḍha-cetāḥ | yac chreyaḥ syān niścitaṃ brūhi tan me śiṣyas te 'haṃ śādhi māṃ tvāṃ prapannam || 7 ||
verse7.explanation: Realizing his inner turmoil, Arjuna surrenders to Krishna and asks for guidance. He acknowledges his confusion and seeks Krishna’s wisdom to help him understand what is right and what he should do.
verse7.sanskrit: कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभावः पृच्छामि त्वां धर्मसम्मूढचेताः | यच्छ्रेयः स्यान्निश्चितं ब्रूहि तन्मे शिष्यस्तेऽहं शाधि मां त्वां प्रपन्नम् || 7 ||

verse8.english: na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyād yac chokam ucchoṣaṇam indriyāṇām | avāpya bhūmāv asapatnam ṛddhaṃ rājyaṃ surāṇām api cādhipatyam || 8 ||
verse8.explanation: Arjuna expresses that even if he were to win the battle and gain the entire earth or even the dominion of the gods, it would not remove his deep sorrow and distress. He is overwhelmed by his emotions and is unable to see any positive outcome.
verse8.sanskrit: न हि प्रपश्यामि ममापनुद्याद् यच्छोकमुच्छोषणमिन्द्रियाणाम् | अवाप्य भूमावसपत्नमृद्धं राज्यं सुराणामपि चाधिपत्यम् || 8 ||

verse9.english: sañjaya uvāca | evam uktvā hṛṣīkeśaṃ guḍākeśaḥ parantapaḥ | na yotsya iti govindam uktvā tūṣṇīṃ babhūva ha || 9 ||
verse9.explanation: After expressing his despair and confusion, Arjuna declares that he will not fight and falls silent, leaving the situation to Krishna, who now has to respond to Arjuna's crisis of conscience.
verse9.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच | एवमुक्त्वा हृषीकेशं गुडाकेशः परन्तपः | न योत्स्य इति गोविन्दमुक्त्वा तूष्णीं बभूव ह || 9 ||

verse10.english: tam uvāca hṛṣīkeśaḥ prahasan niva bhārata | senayor ubhayor madhye viṣīdantam idaṃ vacaḥ || 10 ||
verse10.explanation: Krishna, smiling in a comforting manner, begins to address Arjuna's doubts and concerns, signaling the start of the profound teachings that follow. Krishna’s smile indicates his understanding of Arjuna’s inner turmoil and his readiness to guide him.
verse10.sanskrit: तमुवाच हृषीकेशः प्रहसन्निव भारत | सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये विषीदन्तमिदं वचः || 10 ||

verse11.english: śrī-bhagavān uvāca | aśocyān anvaśocas tvaṃ prajñā-vādāṃś ca bhāṣase | gatāsūn agatāsūṃś ca nānuśocanti paṇḍitāḥ || 11 ||
verse11.explanation: Krishna begins his discourse by telling Arjuna that his sorrow is misplaced. True wisdom lies in understanding that the soul is eternal and not affected by the death of the body. Therefore, lamenting over the physical destruction of the body is unnecessary.
verse11.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | अशोच्यानन्वशोचस्त्वं प्रज्ञावादांश्च भाषसे | गतासूनगतासूंश्च नानुशोचन्ति पण्डिताः || 11 ||

verse12.english: na tvevāhaṃ jātu nāsaṃ na tvaṃ neme janādhipāḥ | na caiva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarve vayam ataḥ param || 12 ||
verse12.explanation: Krishna explains the eternal nature of the soul. He tells Arjuna that the soul is never born and never dies. It has always existed and will continue to exist forever, regardless of the physical body.
verse12.sanskrit: न त्वेवाहं जातु नासं न त्वं नेमे जनाधिपाः | न चैव न भविष्यामः सर्वे वयमतः परम् || 12 ||

verse13.english: dehino 'smin yathā dehe kaumāraṃ yauvanaṃ jarā | tathā dehāntara-prāptir dhīras tatra na muhyati || 13 ||
verse13.explanation: Krishna explains the process of the soul's journey through different stages of life and into another body after death. Understanding this natural transition helps one remain unaffected by the concept of death.
verse13.sanskrit: देहिनोऽस्मिन्यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा | तथा देहान्तरप्राप्तिर्धीरस्तत्र न मुह्यति || 13 ||

verse14.english: mātrā-sparśās tu kaunteya śītoṣṇa-sukha-duḥkha-dāḥ | āgamāpāyino 'nityās tāṃs titikṣasva bhārata || 14 ||
verse14.explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to endure the dualities of life, such as pleasure and pain, as they are temporary and inevitable. These experiences are due to the interactions of the senses with the external world, and a wise person remains steady through them.

verse15.english: yaṃ hi na vyathayanty ete puruṣaṃ puruṣarṣabha | sama-duḥkha-sukhaṃ dhīraṃ so 'mṛtatvāya kalpate || 15 ||
verse15.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that one who remains undisturbed by the dualities of life, such as happiness and sorrow, and maintains equanimity, is fit for attaining spiritual liberation (moksha).
verse15.sanskrit: यं हि न व्यथयन्त्येते पुरुषं पुरुषर्षभ | समदुःखसुखं धीरं सोऽमृतत्वाय कल्पते || 15 ||

verse16.english: nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ | ubhayor api dṛṣṭo 'ntas tv anayos tattva-darśibhiḥ || 16 ||
verse16.explanation: Krishna explains that the physical body is temporary and perishable, whereas the soul is eternal and indestructible. The wise understand this distinction and do not get attached to the transient body.
verse16.sanskrit: नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः | उभयोरपि दृष्टोऽन्तस्त्वनयोस्तत्त्वदर्शिभिः || 16 ||

verse17.english: avināśi tu tad viddhi yena sarvam idaṃ tatam | vināśam avyayasyāsya na kaścit kartum arhati || 17 ||
verse17.explanation: Krishna tells Arjuna that the soul, which pervades the entire body, is eternal and cannot be destroyed. The body may perish, but the soul remains intact, unaffected by physical destruction
verse17.sanskrit: अविनाशि तु तद्विद्धि येन सर्वमिदं ततम् | विनाशमव्ययस्यास्य न कश्चित्कर्तुमर्हति || 17 ||

verse18.english: antavanta ime dehā nityasyoktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ | anāśino 'prameyasya tasmād yudhyasva bhārata || 18 ||
verse18.explanation: Krishna urges Arjuna to fulfill his duty as a warrior, reminding him that the physical body is temporary and perishable, but the soul is eternal and cannot be destroyed.
verse18.sanskrit: अन्तवन्त इमे देहा नित्यस्योक्ताः शरीरिणः | अनाशिनोऽप्रमेयस्य तस्माद्युध्यस्व भारत || 18 ||

verse19.english: ya enaṃ vetti hantāraṃ yaś cainaṃ manyate hatam | ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṃ hanti na hanyate || 19 ||
verse19.explanation: Krishna explains that the soul neither kills nor can it be killed. Those who think otherwise are not truly wise, as they fail to understand the eternal and immutable nature of the soul.
verse19.sanskrit: य एनं वेत्ति हन्तारं यश्चैनं मन्यते हतम् | उभौ तौ न विजानीतो नायं हन्ति न हन्यते || 19 ||

verse20.english: na jāyate mriyate vā kadācin- nāyaṃ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ | ajo nityaḥ śāśvato 'yaṃ purāṇo na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre || 20 ||
verse20.explanation: Krishna describes the soul as eternal and beyond the cycle of birth and death. The soul has always existed and will continue to exist; it is not subject to the physical processes that govern the body.
verse20.sanskrit: न जायते म्रियते वा कदाचि- न्नायं भूत्वा भविता वा न भूयः | अजो नित्यः शाश्वतोऽयं पुराणो न हन्यते हन्यमाने शरीरे || 20 ||

verse21.english: vedāvināśinaṃ nityaṃ ya enam ajam avyayam | kathaṃ sa puruṣaḥ pārtha kaṃ ghātayati hanti kam || 21 ||
verse21.explanation: Krishna questions how anyone with the knowledge of the soul’s true nature can believe in killing or being killed. The soul’s immortality makes the idea of physical violence irrelevant to its true essence.
verse21.sanskrit: वेदाविनाशिनं नित्यं य एनमजमव्ययम् | कथं स पुरुषः पार्थ कं घातयति हन्ति कम् || 21 ||

verse22.english: vāsāṃsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya navāni gṛhṇāti naro 'parāṇi | tathā śarīrāṇi vihāya jīrṇā- nyanyāni saṃyāti navāni dehī || 22 ||
verse22.explanation: Krishna compares the process of reincarnation to changing clothes. The soul discards old, worn-out bodies and takes on new ones, continuing its journey across lifetimes
verse22.sanskrit: वासांसि जीर्णानि यथा विहाय नवानि गृह्णाति नरोऽपराणि | तथा शरीराणि विहाय जीर्णा- न्यन्यानि संयाति नवानि देही || 22 ||

verse23.english: nainaṃ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṃ dahati pāvakaḥ | na cainaṃ kledayanty āpo na śoṣayati mārutaḥ || 23 ||
verse23.explanation: Krishna explains that the soul is beyond the reach of any physical forces. It cannot be harmed by weapons, fire, water, or wind, emphasizing its invincible and eternal nature.
verse23.sanskrit: नैनं छिन्दन्ति शस्त्राणि नैनं दहति पावकः | न चैनं क्लेदयन्त्यापो न शोषयति मारुतः || 23 ||

verse24.english: acchedyo 'yam adāhyo 'yam akledyo 'śoṣya eva ca | nityaḥ sarva-gataḥ sthāṇur acalo 'yaṃ sanātanaḥ || 24 ||
verse24.explanation: The soul’s invulnerability is further highlighted by Krishna, who lists all the physical actions that cannot affect it. The soul is stable, ever-present, and ancient, untouched by the forces of nature.
verse24.sanskrit: अच्छेद्योऽयमदाह्योऽयमक्लेद्योऽशोष्य एव च | नित्यः सर्वगतः स्थाणुरचलोऽयं सनातनः || 24 ||

verse25.english: avyakto 'yam acintyo 'yam avikāryo 'yam ucyate | tasmād evaṃ viditvainaṃ nānuśocitum arhasi || 25 ||
verse25.explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna that the soul, being beyond human perception and understanding, should not be the cause of grief. The body may perish, but the soul remains unchanged and eternal.

verse26.english: atha cainaṃ nitya-jātaṃ nityaṃ vā manyase mṛtam | tathāpi tvaṃ mahā-bāho naivaṃ śocitum arhasi || 26 ||
verse26.explanation: Krishna tells Arjuna that even if he believes in the cycle of birth and death for the soul, there is still no reason to grieve. Life and death are natural processes, and accepting them is part of wisdom.
verse26.sanskrit: अथ चैनं नित्यजातं नित्यं वा मन्यसे मृतम् | तथापि त्वं महाबाहो नैवं शोचितुमर्हसि || 26 ||

verse27.english: jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyur dhruvaṃ janma mṛtasya ca | tasmād aparihārye 'rthe na tvaṃ śocitum arhasi || 27 ||
verse27.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the inevitability of birth and death. Since these events are unavoidable, lamenting over them is futile. Arjuna is encouraged to accept this natural order without sorrow.
verse27.sanskrit: जातस्य हि ध्रुवो मृत्युर्ध्रुवं जन्म मृतस्य च | तस्मादपरिहार्येऽर्थे न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि || 27 ||

verse28.english: avyakta-dīnī bhūtāni vyakta-madhyāni bhārata | avyakta-nidhanānyeva tatra kā paridevanā || 28 ||
verse28.explanation: Krishna explains that all beings exist in an unmanifest state before birth and return to it after death. The brief period of manifestation (life) should not be a cause for lament, as it is just one phase in a continuous cycle.
verse28.sanskrit: अव्यक्तादीनि भूतानि व्यक्तमध्यानि भारत | अव्यक्तनिधनान्येव तत्र का परिदेवना || 28 ||

verse29.english: āścaryavat paśyati kaścid enam āścaryavad vadati tathaiva cānyaḥ | āścaryavat cainam anyaḥ śṛṇoti śrutvāpy enaṃ veda na caiva kaścit || 29 ||
verse29.explanation: Krishna explains that the soul is a profound mystery. Some people perceive it as a wonder, some describe it as such, and others listen in awe, but many still do not fully grasp its true nature, emphasizing the soul's deep and elusive essence.
verse29.sanskrit: आश्चर्यवत्पश्यति कश्चिदेन- माश्चर्यवद्वदति तथैव चान्यः | आश्चर्यवच्चैनमन्यः शृणोति श्रुत्वाप्येनं वेद न चैव कश्चित् || 29 ||

verse30.english: dehī nityam avadhyo 'yaṃ dehe sarvasya bhārata | tasmāt sarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvaṃ śocitum arhasi || 30 ||
verse30.explanation: Krishna reinforces the idea that the soul within every being is eternal and cannot be destroyed. Thus, Arjuna is advised not to grieve for the destruction of the body, as the soul remains untouched.
verse30.sanskrit: देही नित्यमवध्योऽयं देहे सर्वस्य भारत | तस्मात्सर्वाणि भूतानि न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि || 30 ||

verse31.english: svadharmam api cāvekṣya na vikampitum arhasi | dharmyād dhi yuddhāc chreyo 'nyat kṣatriyasya na vidyate || 31 ||
verse31.explanation: Krishna reminds Arjuna of his duty (svadharma) as a warrior (Kshatriya). Engaging in a righteous battle is the highest duty for a Kshatriya, and abandoning it would be dishonorable.
verse31.sanskrit: स्वधर्ममपि चावेक्ष्य न विकम्पितुमर्हसि | धर्म्याद्धि युद्धाच्छ्रेयोऽन्यत्क्षत्रियस्य न विद्यते || 31 ||

verse32.english: yadṛcchayā copapannaṃ svarga-dvāram apāvṛtam | sukhinaḥ kṣatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddham īdṛśam || 32 ||
verse32.explanation: Krishna tells Arjuna that it is a great fortune for a warrior to find themselves in a battle that opens the doors to heaven, especially when the battle comes without their seeking.
verse32.sanskrit: यदृच्छया चोपपन्नं स्वर्गद्वारमपावृतम् | सुखिनः क्षत्रियाः पार्थ लभन्ते युद्धमीदृशम् || 32 ||

verse33.english: atha cet tvam imaṃ dharmyaṃ saṃgrāmaṃ na kariṣyasi | tataḥ svadharmaṃ kīrtiṃ ca hitvā pāpam avāpsyasi || 33 ||
verse33.explanation: Krishna warns Arjuna that by refusing to fight, he would not only forsake his duty as a warrior but also bring disgrace upon himself, leading to sinful consequences.
verse33.sanskrit: अथ चेत्त्वमिमं धर्म्यं संग्रामं न करिष्यसि | ततः स्वधर्मं कीर्तिं च हित्वा पापमवाप्स्यसि || 33 ||

verse34.english: akīrtiṃ cāpi bhūtāni kathayiṣyanti te 'vyayām | sambhāvitasya cākīrtir maraṇād atiricyate || 34 ||
verse34.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that for someone like Arjuna, who is esteemed, the disgrace of not fulfilling his duty would be more painful than death itself.
verse34.sanskrit: अकीर्तिं चापि भूतानि कथयिष्यन्ति तेऽव्ययाम् | सम्भावितस्य चाकीर्तिर्मरणादतिरिच्यते || 34 ||

verse35.english: bhayād raṇād uparataṃ maṃsyante tvāṃ mahārathāḥ | yeṣāṃ ca tvaṃ bahu-mato bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam || 35 ||
verse35.explanation: Krishna points out that Arjuna’s reputation among his fellow warriors would suffer greatly if he withdraws from the battle, as they would attribute his retreat to fear, tarnishing his honor.
verse35.sanskrit: भयाद्रणादुपरतं मंस्यन्ते त्वां महारथाः | येषां च त्वं बहुमतो भूत्वा यास्यसि लाघवम् || 35 ||

verse36.english: avācyavādāṃś ca bahūn vadiṣyanti tavāhitāḥ | nindantas tava sāmarthyaṃ tato duḥkha-taraṃ nu kim || 36 ||
verse36.explanation: Krishna tells Arjuna that the mockery and insults from his enemies would be a source of immense sorrow if he avoids the battle, questioning what could be more painful than such disgrace.
verse36.sanskrit: अवाच्यवादांश्च बहून्वदिष्यन्ति तवाहिताः | निन्दन्तस्तव सामर्थ्यं ततो दुःखतरं नु किम् || 36 ||

verse37.english: hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṃ jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm | tasmād uttiṣṭha kaunteya yuddhāya kṛta-niścayaḥ || 37 ||
verse37.explanation: Krishna encourages Arjuna to fight without hesitation, as either outcome is beneficial: victory will bring earthly pleasures, while death in battle will lead to heavenly rewards.
verse37.sanskrit: हतो वा प्राप्स्यसि स्वर्गं जित्वा वा भोक्ष्यसे महीम् | तस्मादुत्तिष्ठ कौन्तेय युद्धाय कृतनिश्चयः || 37 ||

verse38.english: sukha-duḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhālābhau jayājayau | tato yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṃ pāpam avāpsyasi || 38 ||
verse38.explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to maintain equanimity in all situations, whether favorable or unfavorable, and to focus on his duty without attachment to the results, thus avoiding sinful consequences.
verse38.sanskrit: सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ | ततो युद्धाय युज्यस्व नैवं पापमवाप्स्यसि || 38 ||

verse39.english: eṣā te 'bhihitā sāṅkhye buddhir yoge tv imāṃ śṛṇu | buddhyā yukto yayā pārtha karma-bandhaṃ prahāsyasi || 39 ||
verse39.explanation: Krishna transitions from the philosophical (Sankhya) to the practical (Yoga). He emphasizes that by applying this wisdom in action, Arjuna can break free from the cycle of karma and its consequences.
verse39.sanskrit: एषा तेऽभिहिता सांख्ये बुद्धिर्योगे त्विमां शृणु | बुद्ध्या युक्तो यया पार्थ कर्मबन्धं प्रहास्यसि || 39 ||

verse40.english: nehābhikrama-nāśo 'sti pratyavāyo na vidyate | svalpam apyasya dharmasya trāyate mahato bhayāt || 40 ||
verse40.explanation: Krishna assures Arjuna that any effort on the path of Yoga is never wasted and that even a small amount of practice can save one from great danger, providing immense spiritual benefit.
verse40.sanskrit: नेहाभिक्रमनाशोऽस्ति प्रत्यवायो न विद्यते | स्वल्पमप्यस्य धर्मस्य त्रायते महतो भयात् || 40 ||

verse41.english: vyavasāyātmikā buddhir ekeha kuru-nandana | bahu-śākhā hyanantāś ca buddhayo 'vyavasāyinām || 41 ||
verse41.explanation: Krishna explains that those with a focused and determined mind are steadfast in their purpose, while those who are irresolute are distracted by countless thoughts and desires, preventing them from reaching their goals.
verse41.sanskrit: व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन | बहुशाखा ह्यनन्ताश्च बुद्धयोऽव्यवसायिनाम् || 41 ||

verse42.english: yām imāṃ puṣpitāṃ vācaṃ pravadanty avipaścitaḥ | veda-vāda-ratāḥ pārtha nānyad astīti vādinaḥ ||42||
verse42.explanation: Krishna criticizes those who misinterpret the Vedas, focusing only on rituals and material gains rather than seeking higher knowledge. Such individuals are entangled in desires, which ultimately bind them to the cycle of birth and death.
verse42.sanskrit: यामिमां पुष्पितां वाचं प्रवदन्त्यविपश्चितः | वेदवादरताः पार्थ नान्यदस्तीति वादिनः ||42||

verse43.english: kāmātmānaḥ svarga-parā janma-karma-phala-pradām | kriyā-viśeṣa-bahulāṃ bhogaiśvarya-gatiṃ prati || 43 ||
verse43.explanation: Krishna criticizes those who misinterpret the Vedas, focusing only on rituals and material gains rather than seeking higher knowledge. Such individuals are entangled in desires, which ultimately bind them to the cycle of birth and death.
verse43.sanskrit: कामात्मानः स्वर्गपरा जन्मकर्मफलप्रदाम् | क्रियाविशेषबहुलां भोगैश्वर्यगतिं प्रति || 43 ||

verse44.english: bhogaiśvarya-prasaktānāṃ tayāpahṛta-cetasām | vyavasāyātmikā buddhiḥ samādhau na vidhīyate || 44 ||
verse44.explanation: Krishna explains that those who are consumed by the pursuit of pleasure and wealth lose their ability to focus their minds on spiritual practice, preventing them from achieving true meditation and self-realization.
verse44.sanskrit: भोगैश्वर्यप्रसक्तानां तयापहृतचेतसाम् | व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिः समाधौ न विधीयते || 44 ||

verse45.english: trai-guṇya-viṣayā vedā nistrai-guṇyo bhavārjuna | nirdvandvo nitya-sattva-stho niryoga-kṣema ātmavān || 45 ||
verse45.explanation: Krishna urges Arjuna to transcend the three gunas (modes of material nature) and the dualities of life (like pleasure and pain, gain and loss). By doing so, one can maintain a steady and pure mind, focused on the true self.
verse45.sanskrit: त्रैगुण्यविषया वेदा निस्त्रैगुण्यो भवार्जुन | निर्द्वन्द्वो नित्यसत्त्वस्थो निर्योगक्षेम आत्मवान् || 45 ||

verse46.english: yāvān artha udapāne sarvataḥ samplutodake | tāvān sarveṣu vedeṣu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ || 46 ||
verse46.explanation: Krishna compares the Vedas to a small reservoir of water, which becomes insignificant in the presence of a flood. Similarly, for a person who has realized the self, the rituals and knowledge of the Vedas become secondary to the direct experience of the divine.
verse46.sanskrit: यावानर्थ उदपाने सर्वतः सम्प्लुतोदके | तावान्सर्वेषु वेदेषु ब्राह्मणस्य विजानतः || 46 ||

verse47.english: karmaṇy-evādhikāras te mā phaleṣu kadācana | mā karma-phala-hetur bhūr mā te saṅgo 'stvakarmaṇi || 47 ||
verse47.explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to perform his duties with dedication, without being attached to the results. By detaching from the outcomes, one can avoid the bondage of karma and maintain equanimity.
verse47.sanskrit: कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन | मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि || 47 ||

verse48.english: yoga-sthaḥ kuru karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā dhanañjaya | siddhy-asiddhyoḥ samo bhūtvā samatvaṃ yoga ucyate || 48 ||
verse48.explanation: Krishna defines Yoga as the practice of performing one’s duties with a balanced mind, free from attachment to success or failure. This mental state of equanimity is essential for spiritual growth.
verse48.sanskrit: योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय | सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते || 48 ||

verse49.english: dūreṇa hy avaraṃ karma buddhi-yogād dhanañjaya | buddhau śaraṇam anviccha kṛpaṇāḥ phala-hetavaḥ || 49 ||
verse49.explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to take refuge in wisdom, as actions performed without the guidance of wisdom lead to misery. Actions driven by attachment to results are considered inferior to those guided by wisdom.
verse49.sanskrit: दूरेण ह्यवरं कर्म बुद्धियोगाद्धनञ्जय | बुद्धौ शरणमन्विच्छ कृपणाः फलहेतवः || 49 ||

verse50.english: buddhi-yukto jahātīha ubhe sukṛta-duṣkṛte | tasmād yogāya yujyasva yogaḥ karmaṣu kauśalam || 50 ||
verse50.explanation: Krishna explains that a wise person transcends the dualities of good and evil deeds. By practicing Yoga, one can perform actions skillfully, free from the bondage of karma.
verse50.sanskrit: बुद्धियुक्तो जहातीह उभे सुकृतदुष्कृते | तस्माद्योगाय युज्यस्व योगः कर्मसु कौशलम् || 50 ||

verse51.english: karma-jaṃ buddhi-yuktā hi phalaṃ tyaktvā manīṣiṇaḥ | janma-bandha-vinir-muktāḥ padaṃ gacchanty anāmayam || 51 ||
verse51.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that those who act with wisdom and detachment from the results of their actions can break free from the cycle of birth and death, reaching a state of eternal peace.
verse51.sanskrit: कर्मजं बुद्धियुक्ता हि फलं त्यक्त्वा मनीषिणः | जन्मबन्धविनिर्मुक्ताः पदं गच्छन्त्यनामयम् || 51 ||

verse52.english: yadā te moha-kalilaṃ buddhir vyatitariṣyati | tadā gantāsi nirvedaṃ śrotavyasya śrutasya ca || 52 ||
verse52.explanation: Krishna tells Arjuna that once his intellect overcomes the delusion of attachment and ignorance, he will become indifferent to the worldly knowledge and rituals that bind one to the material world.
verse52.sanskrit: यदा ते मोहकलिलं बुद्धिर्व्यतितरिष्यति | तदा गन्तासि निर्वेदं श्रोतव्यस्य श्रुतस्य च || 52 ||

verse53.english: śruti-vipratipannā te yadā sthāsyati niścalā | samādhāv acalā buddhis tadā yogam avāpsyasi || 53 ||
verse53.explanation: Krishna explains that when Arjuna's intellect becomes unwavering and steady, free from confusion and doubts, he will attain the true state of Yoga—union with the Divine.
verse53.sanskrit: श्रुतिविप्रतिपन्ना ते यदा स्थास्यति निश्चला | समाधावचला बुद्धिस्तदा योगमवाप्स्यसि || 53 ||

verse54.english: arjuna uvāca | sthita-prajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhi-sthasya keśava | sthita-dhīḥ kiṃ prabhāṣeta kim āsīta vrajeta kim || 54 ||
verse54.explanation: Arjuna asks Krishna to describe the characteristics of a person who is established in steady wisdom and remains in a state of meditation, wanting to understand how such an enlightened person behaves.
verse54.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | स्थितप्रज्ञस्य का भाषा समाधिस्थस्य केशव | स्थितधीः किं प्रभाषेत किमासीत व्रजेत किम् || 54 ||

verse55.english: śrī-bhagavān uvāca | prajahāti yadā kāmān sarvān pārtha mano-gatān | ātmany evātmanā tuṣṭaḥ sthita-prajñas tadocyate || 55 ||
verse55.explanation: Krishna explains that a person who has completely given up all desires of the mind and is content in the self, by the self, is considered to be established in true wisdom.
verse55.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | प्रजहाति यदा कामान्सर्वान्पार्थ मनोगतान् | आत्मन्येवात्मना तुष्टः स्थितप्रज्ञस्तदोच्यते || 55 ||

verse56.english: duḥkheṣv anudvigna-manāḥ sukheṣu vigata-spṛhaḥ | vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhaḥ sthita-dhīr munir ucyate || 56 ||
verse56.explanation: Krishna describes the characteristics of a wise sage: someone who remains calm and unperturbed by sorrow or joy, and who is free from attachment, fear, and anger.

verse57.english: yaḥ sarvatra anabhisnehas tat-tat prāpya śubhāśubham | nābhinandati na dveṣṭi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā || 57 ||
verse57.explanation: Krishna explains that a person who is free from attachment and remains unaffected by good or bad events is established in steady wisdom, reflecting an enlightened state of mind.
verse57.sanskrit: यः सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम् | नाभिनन्दति न द्वेष्टि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता || 57 ||

verse58.english: yadā saṃharate cāyaṃ kūrmo 'ṅgānīva sarvaśaḥ | indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā || 58 ||
verse58.explanation: Krishna uses the analogy of a tortoise withdrawing its limbs to describe a person who has control over their senses, drawing them away from sense objects. This control leads to steady wisdom.
verse58.sanskrit: यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वश: | इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता || 58 ||

verse59.english: viṣayā vinivartante nirāhārasya dehinaḥ | rasa-varjaṃ raso 'py asya paraṃ dṛṣṭvā nivartate || 59 ||
verse59.explanation: Krishna explains that simply avoiding sense objects doesn't remove the desire for them. However, once one experiences the higher taste of the Supreme, even this lingering desire fades away.
verse59.sanskrit: विषया विनिवर्तन्ते निराहारस्य देहिन: | रसवर्जं रसोऽप्यस्य परं दृष्ट्वा निवर्तते || 59 ||

verse60.english: yatato hy api kaunteya puruṣasya vipaścitaḥ | indriyāṇi pramāthīni haranti prasabhaṃ manaḥ || 60 ||
verse60.explanation: Krishna warns that even for a wise person, the senses are powerful and can lead the mind astray, emphasizing the need for constant vigilance and discipline.
verse60.sanskrit: यततो ह्यपि कौन्तेय पुरुषस्य विपश्चित: | इन्द्रियाणि प्रमाथीनि हरन्ति प्रसभं मन: || 60 ||

verse61.english: tāni sarvāṇi saṃyamya yukta āsīta mat-paraḥ | vaśe hi yasyendriyāṇi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā || 61 ||
verse61.explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to control his senses and direct his mind towards devotion to the Divine. Only then will his wisdom be steady and unwavering.
verse61.sanskrit: तानि सर्वाणि संयम्य युक्त आसीत मत्पर: | वशे हि यस्येन्द्रियाणि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता || 61 ||

verse62.english: dhyāyato viṣayān puṃsaḥ saṅgas teṣūpajāyate | saṅgāt sañjāyate kāmaḥ kāmāt krodho 'bhijāyate || 62 ||
verse62.explanation: Krishna explains the process by which attachment leads to desire, and unfulfilled desire leads to anger, which can disturb the mind and lead to further negative consequences.
verse62.sanskrit: ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंस: सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते | सङ्गात्सञ्जायते काम: कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते || 62 ||

verse63.english: krodhād bhavati sammohaḥ sammohāt smṛti-vibhramaḥ | smṛti-bhraṃśād buddhi-nāśo buddhi-nāśāt praṇaśyati || 63 ||
verse63.explanation: Krishna describes the destructive chain reaction that begins with anger and leads to the complete degradation of a person's consciousness and wisdom, ultimately causing them to fall from their spiritual path.

verse64.english: rāga-dveṣa-viyuktais tu viṣayān indriyaiś caran | ātma-vaśyair vidheyātmā prasādam adhigacchati || 64 ||
verse64.explanation: Krishna teaches that a person who can engage with the world without being swayed by attraction or repulsion, while maintaining control over their senses, will attain divine peace and grace.

verse65.english: prasāde sarva-duḥkhānāṃ hānir asyopajāyate | prasanna-cetaso hy āśu buddhiḥ paryavatiṣṭhate || 65 ||
verse65.explanation: Krishna explains that when one attains divine grace and inner peace, all suffering is eradicated. This state of peace stabilizes the mind and sharpens one’s intellect.
verse65.sanskrit: प्रसादे सर्वदु:खानां हानिरस्योपजायते | प्रसन्नचेतसो ह्याशु बुद्धि: पर्यवतिष्ठते || 65 ||

verse66.english: nāsti buddhir ayuktasya na cāyuktasya bhāvanā | na cābhāvayataḥ śāntir aśāntasya kutaḥ sukham || 66 ||
verse66.explanation: Krishna points out that an unstable mind lacks wisdom and the ability to meditate. Without meditation, peace is impossible, and without peace, true happiness cannot be achieved.
verse66.sanskrit: नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना | न चाभावयत: शान्तिरशान्तस्य कुत: सुखम् || 66 ||

verse67.english: indriyāṇāṃ hi caratāṃ yan mano 'nuvidhīyate | tad asya harati prajñāṃ vāyur nāvam ivāmbhasi || 67 ||
verse67.explanation: Krishna uses the metaphor of a ship being carried away by the wind to describe how the mind, if it follows the restless senses, can destroy a person’s wisdom and lead them astray
verse67.sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते | तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि || 67 ||

verse68.english: tasmād yasya mahā-bāho nigṛhītāni sarvaśaḥ | indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā || 68 ||
verse68.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that only when a person fully controls their senses and keeps them away from worldly objects can their wisdom remain firm and undisturbed.
verse68.sanskrit: तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वश: | इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता || 68 ||

verse69.english: yā niśā sarva-bhūtānāṃ tasyāṃ jāgarti saṃyamī | yasyāṃ jāgrati bhūtāni sā niśā paśyato muneḥ || 69 ||
verse69.explanation: Krishna illustrates the difference between the worldly and the wise. What the ignorant consider to be of value (the sensory world) is of no value to the sage, and what the sage values (spiritual wisdom) is neglected by the ignorant.
verse69.sanskrit: या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी | यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुने: || 69 ||

verse70.english: āpūryamāṇam acala-pratiṣṭhaṃ samudram āpaḥ praviśanti yadvat | tadvat kāmā yaṃ praviśanti sarve sa śāntim āpnoti na kāma-kāmī || 70 ||
verse70.explanation: Krishna compares the sage to an ocean that remains calm and undisturbed even as rivers flow into it. Similarly, a person of steady wisdom remains unaffected by desires and attains peace, unlike those who are driven by cravings.
verse70.sanskrit: आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं समुद्रमाप: प्रविशन्ति यद्वत् | तद्वत्कामा यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी || 70 ||

verse71.english: vihāya kāmān yaḥ sarvān pumāṃś carati niḥspṛhaḥ | nirmamo nirahaṅkāraḥ sa śāntim adhigacchati || 71 ||
verse71.explanation: Krishna explains that true peace is attained by one who has renounced all desires, attachment to possessions, and egoistic identity.
verse71.sanskrit: विहाय कामान्य: सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति नि:स्पृह: | निर्ममो निरहङ्कार: स शान्तिमधिगच्छति || 71 ||

verse72.english: eṣā brāhmī sthitiḥ pārtha naināṃ prāpya vimuhyati | sthitvāsyām anta-kāle 'pi brahma-nirvāṇam ṛcchati || 72 ||
verse72.explanation: Krishna concludes by describing the state of divine consciousness, which is free from delusion. A person who is established in this state, even at the moment of death, attains liberation and becomes one with Brahman, the ultimate reality.
verse72.sanskrit: एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति | स्थित्वास्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृच्छति || 72 ||

verse1.english: Arjuna Uvācha: Jyāyasī Chetkarmaṇaste Matā Buddhirjanārdana | Tatkiṁ Karmaṇi Ghore Māṁ Niyojayasi Keśhava || 1 ||
verse1.explanation: Arjuna is confused as to why Krishna is urging him to fight if he believes that knowledge (Jnana) is superior to action (Karma). He questions the need to engage in such a fearful action.
verse1.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | ज्यायसी चेत्कर्मणस्ते मता बुद्धिर्जनार्दन | तत्किं कर्मणि घोरे मां नियोजयसि केशव || 1 ||

verse2.english: Vyāsenena Mahābāho Mohayāsīva Me Manaḥ | Tadekaṁ Vada Niśhchitya Yena Śhreyo'hamāpnuyām || 2 ||
verse2.explanation: Arjuna feels conflicted by Krishna's teachings and asks him to clearly guide him on the one path that will lead to his ultimate well-being.
verse2.sanskrit: व्यासेनेन महाबाहो मोहयासीव मे मनः | तदेकं वद निश्चित्य येन श्रेयोऽहमाप्नुयाम् || 2 ||

verse3.english: Śhrī Bhagavānuvācha: Loke’smin Dvividha Niṣhṭhā Purā Proktā Mayānagha | Jñānayogena Sāṅkhyānāṁ Karmayogena Yoginām || 3 ||
verse3.explanation: Śhrī Bhagavānuvācha: Loke’smin Dvividha Niṣhṭhā Purā Proktā Mayānagha | Jñānayogena Sāṅkhyānāṁ Karmayogena Yoginām || 3 ||
verse3.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | लोकेऽस्मिन् द्विविधा निष्ठा पुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ | ज्ञानयोगेन साङ्ख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम् || 3 ||

verse4.english: Na Karmaṇāmanārambhān Naiṣhkarmyaṁ Puruṣho'śhnute | Na Cha Sannyasanādeva Siddhiṁ Samadhigachchhati || 4 ||
verse4.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that merely avoiding action or renouncing the world does not lead to spiritual liberation. Perfection comes through the proper performance of one's duties.
verse4.sanskrit: न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते | न च सन्न्यसनादेव सिद्धिं समधिगच्छति || 4 ||

verse5.english: Na Hi Kaśhchitkṣhaṇamapi Jātu Tiṣhṭhatyakarmakṛit | Kāryate Hyavaśhaḥ Karma Sarvaḥ Prakṛitijairguṇaiḥ || 5 ||
verse5.explanation: Krishna explains that it is impossible for anyone to remain inactive because the qualities of nature (Prakriti) compel everyone to act.
verse5.sanskrit: न हि कश्चित्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत् | कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः || 5 ||

verse6.english: Karmendriyāṇi Saṁyamya Ya Āste Manasā Smaran | Indriyārthānvimūḍhātmā Mithyāchāraḥ Sa Uchyate || 6 ||
verse6.explanation: Krishna warns against hypocrisy, stating that those who outwardly restrain themselves from action while mentally dwelling on sense objects are deluding themselves.
verse6.sanskrit: कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन् | इन्द्रियार्थान्विमूढात्मा मिथ्याचारः स उच्यते || 6 ||

verse7.english: Yastvindriyāṇi Manasā Niyamyārabhate'rjuna | Karmendriyaiḥ Karmayogamasaktaḥ Sa Viśiṣhyate || 7 ||
verse7.explanation: Krishna praises those who control their senses and perform their duties with a detached mind. Such individuals, who engage in selfless action, are superior.
verse7.sanskrit: यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन | कर्मेन्द्रियैः कर्मयोगमसक्तः स विशिष्यते || 7 ||

verse8.english: Niyataṁ Kuru Karma Tvaṁ Karma Jyāyo Hyakarmaṇaḥ | Śharīrayātrāpi Cha Te Na Prasiddhyedakarmaṇaḥ || 8 ||
verse8.explanation: Niyataṁ Kuru Karma Tvaṁ Karma Jyāyo Hyakarmaṇaḥ | Śharīrayātrāpi Cha Te Na Prasiddhyedakarmaṇaḥ || 8 ||
verse8.sanskrit: नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः | शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्ध्येदकर्मणः || 8 ||

verse9.english: Yajñārthāt Karmaṇo'nyatra Loko'yaṁ Karmabandhanaḥ | Tadarthaṁ Karma Kaunteya Muktasaṅgaḥ Samāchara || 9 ||
verse9.explanation: Krishna explains that actions performed for selfish reasons lead to bondage, whereas those done as a form of sacrifice (for the welfare of others) lead to liberation.
verse9.sanskrit: यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः | तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय मुक्तसङ्गः समाचर || 9 ||

verse10.english: Sahayajñāḥ Prajāḥ Sṛiṣhṭvā Purovācha Prajāpatiḥ | Anena Prasaviṣhyadhvam Eṣha Vo'stviṣṭakāmadhuk || 10 ||
verse10.explanation: Sahayajñāḥ Prajāḥ Sṛiṣhṭvā Purovācha Prajāpatiḥ | Anena Prasaviṣhyadhvam Eṣha Vo'stviṣṭakāmadhuk || 10 ||
verse10.sanskrit: सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः | अनेन प्रसविष्यध्वमेष वोऽस्त्विष्टकामधुक् || 10 ||

verse11.english: Devānbhāvayatānena Te Devā Bhāvayantu Vaḥ | Parasparaṁ Bhāvayantaḥ Śhreyaḥ Paramavāpsyatha || 11 ||
verse11.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the importance of mutual cooperation between humans and the divine. By performing sacrifices, humans please the gods, who in turn provide blessings.
verse11.sanskrit: देवान्भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः | परस्परं भावयन्तः श्रेयः परमवाप्स्यथ || 11 ||

verse12.english: Iṣhṭānbhogān Hi Vo Devā Dāsyante Yajñabhāvitāḥ | Tairdattānapradāyaibhyo Yo Bhuṅkte Stena Eva Saḥ || 12 ||
verse12.explanation: Krishna warns that those who take the gifts of nature without offering anything in return are like thieves. He advocates for a reciprocal relationship between humans and the divine.
verse12.sanskrit: इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः | तैर्दत्तानप्रदायैभ्यो यो भुङ्क्ते स्तेन एव सः || 12 ||

verse13.english: Yajñaśhiṣṭāśhinaḥ Santo Muchyante Sarvakilbiṣhaiḥ | Bhuñjate Te Tvaghaṁ Pāpā Ye Pachantyātmakāraṇāt || 13 ||
verse13.explanation: Krishna explains that those who partake in the offerings of sacrifice are purified, whereas those who act selfishly, without offering, are consumed by sin.
verse13.sanskrit: यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः | भुञ्जते ते त्वघं पापा ये पचन्त्यात्मकारणात् || 13 ||

verse14.english: Annādbhavanti Bhūtāni Parjanyādannasaṁbhavaḥ | Yajñādbhavati Parjanyo Yajñaḥ Karmasamudbhavaḥ || 14 ||
verse14.explanation: Krishna explains the cycle of sustenance: all beings depend on food, which comes from rain, which in turn is produced by sacrifice. Sacrifice itself arises from action.
verse14.sanskrit: अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसम्भवः | यज्ञाद्भवति पर्जन्यो यज्ञः कर्मसमुद्भवः || 14 ||

verse15.english: Karma Brahmodbhavaṁ Viddhi Brahmākṣharasamudbhavam | Tasmātsarvagataṁ Brahma Nityaṁ Yajñe Pratiṣhṭhitam || 15 ||
verse15.explanation: Krishna elaborates that actions are guided by the Vedas, which originate from the imperishable Brahman. Thus, Brahman, the Supreme Reality, is always present in sacrifice.
verse15.sanskrit: कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम् | तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम् || 15 ||

verse16.english: Evaṁ Pravartitaṁ Chakraṁ Nānu Vartayatīha Yaḥ | Aghāyurindriyārāmo Moghaṁ Pārtha Sa Jīvati || 16 ||
verse16.explanation: Krishna warns that those who do not participate in the cosmic cycle of sacrifice and instead indulge in sensual pleasures lead a worthless and sinful life.
verse16.sanskrit:
एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह यः |
अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं पार्थ स जीवति || 16 ||

verse17.english: Yastvātmaratireva Syādātmatṛiptaśhcha Mānavaḥ | Ātmanyeva Cha Santuṣhṭastasya Kāryaṁ Na Vidyate || 17 ||
verse17.explanation: Krishna explains that a person who has realized the Self and is fully content within requires no external duties or actions for fulfillment.
verse17.sanskrit: यस्त्वात्मरतिरेव स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः | आत्मन्येव च सन्तुष्टस्तस्य कार्यं न विद्यते || 17 ||

verse18.english:
Naiva Tasya Kṛitenārtho Nākṛiteneha Kaśchana |
Na Chāsya Sarvabhūteṣhu Kaśchidarthavyapāśhrayaḥ || 18 ||
verse18.explanation: Krishna clarifies that a self-realized person is free from the need to perform any action and is independent of external circumstances or outcomes.
verse18.sanskrit: नैव तस्य कृतेनार्थो नाकृतेनेह कश्चन | न चास्य सर्वभूतेषु कश्चिदर्थव्यपाश्रयः || 18 ||

verse19.english: Tasmādasaktaḥ Satataṁ Kāryaṁ Karma Samāchara | Asakto Hyācharankarma Paramāpnoti Puruṣhaḥ || 19 ||
verse19.explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to perform his duties without attachment to the results, as this leads to spiritual liberation and realization of the Supreme.
verse19.sanskrit: तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर | असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुषः || 19 ||

verse20.english: Karmaṇaiva Hi Saṁsiddhimāsthita Janakādayaḥ | Lokasaṅgrahamevāpi Sampyaṣyankartumarhasi || 20 ||
verse20.explanation: Krishna cites the example of King Janaka, who achieved perfection through action, and urges Arjuna to perform his duties for the welfare of society.
verse20.sanskrit: कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता जनकादयः | लोकसंग्रहमेवापि सम्पश्यन्कर्तुमर्हसि || 20 ||

verse21.english: Yadyadācharati Śhreṣhṭhastattadevetaro Janaḥ | Sa Yatpramāṇaṁ Kurute Lokastadanuvartate || 21 ||
verse21.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the influence of great people in society, explaining that others naturally follow their example.
verse21.sanskrit: यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः | स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदनुवर्तते || 21 ||

verse22.english: Na Me Pārthāsti Kartavyaṁ Triṣhu Lokeṣhu Kiñchana | Nānavāptamavāptavyaṁ Varta Eva Cha Karmaṇi || 22 ||
verse22.explanation: Krishna explains that although he has no duties and nothing to gain in the three worlds, he still engages in action for the sake of maintaining order.
verse22.sanskrit: न मे पार्थास्ति कर्तव्यं त्रिषु लोकेषु किञ्चन | नानवाप्तमवाप्तव्यं वर्त एव च कर्मणि || 22 ||

verse23.english: Yadi Hyahaṁ Na Varteyaṁ Jātu Karmaṇyatandritaḥ | Mama Vartmānuvartante Manuṣhyāḥ Pārtha Sarvaśhaḥ || 23 ||
verse23.explanation: Krishna warns that if he, as the Supreme, did not act, it would set a precedent, leading people to neglect their duties.
verse23.sanskrit: यदि ह्यहं न वर्तेयं जातु कर्मण्यतन्द्रितः | मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः || 23 ||

verse24.english: na me pārthāsti kartavyaṁ triṣu lokeṣhu kiñcana nānāvāptam avāptavyaṁ vartamāneṣhu karmasu
verse24.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the importance of action, stating that his inaction would lead to chaos and the destruction of the universe.
verse24.sanskrit: उत्सीदेयुरिमे लोका न कुर्यां कर्म चेदहम् | सङ्करस्य च कर्ता स्यामुपहन्यामिमा: प्रजाः || 24 ||

verse25.explanation: Krishna advises that the wise should perform their duties without attachment, setting an example for others, just as the ignorant act with attachment.

verse26.english: Na Buddhibhedaṁ Janayedajñānāṁ Karmasaṅginām | Joṣhayetsarvakarmāṇi Vidvān Yuktaḥ Samācharan || 26 ||
verse26.explanation: Krishna advises that those who are knowledgeable should not disturb the understanding of those attached to actions, but instead should perform their duties wisely, guiding others.
verse26.sanskrit: न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेदज्ञानां कर्मसङ्गिनाम् | जोषयेत्सर्वकर्माणि विद्वान् युक्तः समाचरन् || 26 ||

verse27.english: Prakṛiteḥ Kriyamāṇāni Guṇaiḥ Karmāṇi Sarvaśhaḥ | Ahaṅkāravimūḍhātmā Kartāhamiti Manyate || 27 ||
verse27.explanation: Krishna explains that it is the modes of nature (Prakriti) that are responsible for actions, but those under the illusion of ego believe themselves to be the doers.
verse27.sanskrit: प्रकृतेः क्रियमाणानि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः | अहङ्कारविमूढात्मा कर्ताहमिति मन्यते || 27 ||

verse28.english: Tattvavittu Mahābāho Guṇakarmavibhāgayoḥ | Guṇā Guṇeṣhu Vartanta Iti Matvā Na Sajjate || 28 ||
verse28.explanation: Krishna teaches that a person who understands the true nature of the gunas and actions sees that they are merely interacting with each other and does not get attached to the results.
verse28.sanskrit: तत्त्ववित्तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः | गुणा गुणेषु वर्तन्त इति मत्वा न सज्जते || 28 ||

verse29.english: Prakṛiterguṇasaṁmūḍhāḥ Sajjante Guṇakarmasu | Tānakṛitsnavido Mandānkṛitsnavinna Vichālayet || 29 ||
verse29.explanation: Krishna advises that the wise should not disturb the ignorant who are attached to actions due to the influence of the gunas, as this could confuse them.
verse29.sanskrit: प्रकृतेर्गुणसम्मूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु | तानकृत्स्नविदो मन्दान्कृत्स्नविन्न विचालयेत् || 29 ||

verse30.english: Mayi Sarvāṇi Karmāṇi Saṁnyasyādhyātmacetasā | Nirvīryaḥ Nirvinirmāmo Bhūtvā Yudhyasva Vigatajvaraḥ || 30 ||
verse30.explanation: Krishna urges Arjuna to surrender all his actions to Him, focusing on the Self, and fight without attachment, desire, or anxiety.
verse30.sanskrit: मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि संन्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा | निर्वीर्यः निर्विनिर्मामो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः || 30 ||

verse31.english: Ye Me Matamidaṁ Nityamanutiṣhṭhanti Mānavāḥ | Śhraddhāvanto'nasūyanto Muchyante Te'pi Karmabhiḥ || 31 ||
verse31.explanation: Krishna assures that those who sincerely follow His teachings, without any malice or envy, will be liberated from the consequences of their actions.
verse31.sanskrit: ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः | श्रद्धावन्तोऽनसूयन्तो मुच्यन्ते तेऽपि कर्मभिः || 31 ||

verse32.english: Ye Tvetadabhyasūyanto Nānutiṣhṭhanti Me Matam | Sarvajñānavimūḍhān Tānv-iddhi Naṣhṭānachetasāḥ || 32 ||
verse32.explanation: Krishna warns that those who, out of envy or ignorance, disregard His teachings are misguided and doomed to destruction.
verse32.sanskrit: ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम् | सर्वज्ञानविमूढांस्तान्विद्धि नष्टानचेतसः || 32 ||

verse33.english: Sadṛiśhaṁ Cheṣhṭate Svasyāḥ Prakṛiterjñānavānapi | Prakṛitiṁ Yānti Bhūtāni Nigrahaḥ Kiṁ Kariṣhyati || 33 ||
verse33.explanation: Krishna explains that even the wise act according to their nature, and since all beings are governed by their nature, external restraint is often ineffective.
verse33.sanskrit: सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि | प्रकृतिं यान्ति भूतानि निग्रहः किं करिष्यति || 33 ||

verse34.english: Indriyasye'indriyasya'rthe Rāgadveṣhau Vyavasthitau | Tayorna Vaśhamāgachchhettau Hyasya Paripanthinau || 34 ||
verse34.explanation: Krishna advises that attachment and aversion are natural inclinations within the senses, but one should avoid being controlled by them as they obstruct spiritual progress.
verse34.sanskrit: इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ | तयोर्न वशमागच्छेत्तौ ह्यस्य परिपन्थिनौ || 34 ||

verse35.english: Śhreyān Swadharmo Viguṇaḥ Paradharmātsvanuṣhṭhitāt | Swadharme Nidhanaṁ Śhreyaḥ Paradharmo Bhayāvahaḥ || 35 ||
verse35.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that it's preferable to fulfill one's own duty, even if imperfectly, rather than to do someone else’s duty well, as the latter may lead to adverse outcomes.
verse35.sanskrit: श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात् | स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः || 35 ||

verse36.english: Arjuna Uvācha | Atha Kena Prayukto'yamapi Karmaṇi Nibadhyate | Anicchannapi Vārṣhṇe Ya Balādiva Niyojitaḥ || 36 ||
verse36.explanation: Arjuna inquires about the force or influence that drives a person to commit sinful actions even when they do not wish to.
verse36.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | अथ केन प्रयुक्तोऽयमपि कर्मणि निबध्यते | अनिच्छन्नपि वार्ष्णे य बलादिव नियोजितः || 36 ||

verse37.english: Śhrī Bhagavānuvācha | Kāma Eṣha Krodha Eṣha Rajoguṇasamudbhavaḥ | Mahāśhano Mahāpāpmā Viddhyenamīva Iha || 37 ||
verse37.explanation: Krishna explains that desire and anger, arising from the mode of passion, are powerful and destructive forces that lead to ignorance and sin.
verse37.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः | महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्ध्येनमईवैह || 37 ||

verse38.english: Dhūmenāvriyate Vāṅdhuḥ Yathādarśo Malena Cha | Yatholbhenāvṛito Garbhastathā Tenedamāvṛitam || 38 ||
verse38.explanation: Desire and anger obscure true knowledge and wisdom just as smoke, dust, and womb conceal their respective objects.
verse38.sanskrit: धूमेनाव्रियते वान्धुः यथादर्शो मलेन च | यथोल्बेनावृतो गर्भस्तथा तेनेदमावृतम् || 38 ||

verse39.english:
Avaritaṁ Jñānametena Jñānino Nityavairiṇā |
Sūkṣmaḥ Kāmaḥ Krodhaścha Pūṣāṁ Patatyabhāṣhaya || 39 ||
verse39.explanation: Desire, being a constant and insatiable adversary, continuously obscures and destroys true knowledge.
verse39.sanskrit: अवृतं ज्ञानमेतेन ज्ञानिनो नित्यवैरिणा | कृष्ण गङ्गा पुसा नाम पत्यम् || 39 ||

verse40.english: Indriyāṇāṁ Hi Charatāṁ Yanmano’nuvidhīyate | Tadasya Harati Prajñāṁ Vāyurnāvamivāmbhasaḥ || 40 ||
verse40.explanation: When the mind follows the senses, it can easily divert one’s wisdom and understanding, much like the wind moves a boat on water.
verse40.sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते | तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसः || 40 ||

verse41.english: Tasmādyasya Mahābāho Nigṛhītatānī Sarvaśhaḥ | Indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyaḥ Tasya Prajñā Pratiṣṭhitā || 41 ||
verse41.explanation: Tasmādyasya Mahābāho Nigṛhītatānī Sarvaśhaḥ | Indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyaḥ Tasya Prajñā Pratiṣṭhitā || 41 ||
verse41.sanskrit: तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृह्यतानी सर्वशः | इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता || 41 ||

verse42.english: Śarīravāṅmanobhiryatkarma Prārabhate Naraḥ | Nyāyyaṁ Vā Viparītaṁ Vā Pañcaite Tasya Hetavaḥ || 42 ||
verse42.explanation: Krishna explains that all actions performed through body, speech, or mind are influenced by five factors which determine their outcome.
verse42.sanskrit: शरीरवाङ्मनोभिर्यत्कर्म प्रारभते नरः | न्याय्यं वा विपरीतं वा पञ्चैते तस्य हेतवः || 42 ||

verse43.english: Tasmāt Svaswadharme Yuktah Sādhyashchett Kartuṣhyaṁ | Sarvājñah Api Sattvaśchen Mama Api Vivarṣhitaḥ || 43 ||
verse43.explanation: Krishna advises that one should follow their own duty and control their mind, as this approach leads to the cultivation of wisdom and fulfillment.
verse43.sanskrit: तस्मात्स्वस्वधर्मे युक्तः साध्यश्चेत्तु कर्तव्यम् | सर्वज्ञोऽपि सत्त्वश्चेन्ममपि विवर्धते || 43 ||

verse1.english: Imam vivasvate yogam proktavan aham avyayam | Vivasvan manave praha manur ikshvakave 'bravit ||
verse1.explanation: The Blessed Lord said: I taught this imperishable yoga to Vivasvan (the Sun god); Vivasvan taught it to Manu (the father of mankind); Manu, in turn, taught it to Ikshvaku.
verse1.sanskrit: इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम्। विवस्वान्मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत्।।

verse2.english: Evam parampara-praptam imam rajarshayo viduh | Sa kaleneha mahata yogo nashtah parantapa ||
verse2.explanation: Thus, handed down in succession, the royal sages knew this. But in course of time, the yoga was lost to the world, O Arjuna.
verse2.sanskrit: एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः। स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परन्तप।।

verse3.english: Sa evayam maya te 'dya yogah proktah puratanah | Bhakto 'si me sakha ceti rahasyam hy etad uttamam ||
verse3.explanation: Today, I have taught you that very ancient yoga, for you are my devotee and friend, and this is the supreme secret.
verse3.sanskrit: स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः। भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम्।।

verse4.english: Aparam bhavato janma param janma vivasvatah | Katham etad vijaniyam tvam adau proktavan iti ||
verse4.explanation: Arjuna said: But you were born much later, while Vivasvan (the Sun god) was born long before. How am I to understand that you taught this yoga in the beginning?
verse4.sanskrit: अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः। कथमेतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति।।

verse5.english: Bahuni me vyatitani janmani tava carjuna | Tany aham veda sarvani na tvam vettha parantapa ||
verse5.explanation: The Blessed Lord said: Many births have passed for both you and me, O Arjuna. I know them all, but you do not know, O Parantapa (scorcher of foes).
verse5.sanskrit: बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन। तान्यहं वेद सर्वाणि न त्वं वेत्थ परन्तप।।

verse6.english: Ajo 'pi sann avyayatma bhutanam isvaro 'pi san | Prakritim svam adhisthaya sambhavamy atma-mayaya ||
verse6.explanation: Although I am unborn, and my transcendental body never deteriorates, and although I am the Lord of all living entities, I still appear in every millennium in my original transcendental form.
verse6.sanskrit: अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन्। प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय सम्भवाम्यात्ममायया।।

verse7.english: Yada yada hi dharmasya glanir bhavati bharata | Abhyutthanam adharmasya tadatmanam srjamy aham ||
verse7.explanation: Whenever there is a decline in righteousness and an increase in unrighteousness, O Bharata (Arjuna), at that time, I manifest myself on earth.
verse7.sanskrit: यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत। अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदात्मानं सृजाम्यहम्।।

verse8.english: Paritranaya sadhunam vinasaya ca dushkritam | Dharma-samsthapanarthaya sambhavami yuge yuge ||
verse8.explanation: To protect the righteous, to annihilate the wicked, and to reestablish the principles of dharma (righteousness), I appear millennium after millennium.
verse8.sanskrit: परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम्। धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय सम्भवामि युगे युगे।।

verse9.english: Janma karma ca me divyam evam yo vetti tattvatah | Tyaktva deham punar janma naiti mam eti so 'rjuna ||
verse9.explanation: One who knows the transcendental nature of my appearance and activities does not, upon leaving the body, take birth again in this material world, but attains my eternal abode, O Arjuna.
verse9.sanskrit: जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः। त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन।।

verse10.english: Vita-raga-bhaya-krodha man-maya mam upashritah | Bahavo jnana-tapasa puta mad-bhavam agatah ||
verse10.explanation: Being freed from attachment, fear, and anger, being fully absorbed in me and taking refuge in me, many persons in the past became purified by knowledge of me—and thus they all attained transcendental love for me.
verse10.sanskrit: जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः। त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन।।

verse11.english: Ye yatha mam prapadyante tams tathaiva bhajamy aham | Mama vartmanuvartante manushyah partha sarvashah ||
verse11.explanation: As all surrender unto me, I reciprocate with them accordingly. Everyone follows my path in all respects, O son of Pritha.
verse11.sanskrit: ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम्। मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः।।

verse12.english: Kanksantah karmanam siddhim yajanta iha devatah | Kshipram hi manuse loke siddhir bhavati karma-ja ||
verse12.explanation: Men in this world desire success in fruitive activities, and therefore they worship the demigods. Quickly, of course, men get results from fruitive work in this world.
verse12.sanskrit: काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः। क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा।।

verse13.english: Chatur-varnyam maya srishtam guna-karma-vibhagashah | Tasya kartaram api mam viddhy akartaram avyayam ||
verse13.explanation: According to the three modes of material nature and the work associated with them, I created the four divisions of human society. And, although I am the creator of this system, you should know that I am yet the non-doer, being unchangeable.
verse13.sanskrit: चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः। तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम्।।

verse14.english: Na mam karmani limpanti na me karma-phale sprha | Iti mam yo 'bhijanati karmabhir na sa badhyate ||
verse14.explanation: There is no work that affects me, nor do I aspire for the fruits of action. One who understands this truth about me also does not become entangled in the fruitive reactions of work.
verse14.sanskrit: न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा। इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते।।

verse15.english: Evam jnatva krtam karma purvair api mumukshubhih | Kuru karmaiva tasmat tvam purvaih purvataram krtam ||
verse15.explanation: All the liberated souls in ancient times acted with this understanding of my transcendental nature. Therefore, you should perform your duty, following in their footsteps.
verse15.sanskrit: एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः। कुरु कर्मैव तस्मात्त्वं पूर्वैः पूर्वतरं कृतम्।।

verse16.english: Kim karma kim akarmeti kavayo 'py atra mohitah | Tat te karma pravaksyami yaj jnatva moksyase 'subhat ||
verse16.explanation: Even the intelligent are bewildered in determining what is action and what is inaction. Now I shall explain to you what action is, knowing which you shall be liberated from all misfortune.
verse16.sanskrit: किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः। तत्ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात्।।

verse17.english: Karmano hy api boddhavyam boddhavyam ca vikarmanah | Akarmanash ca boddhavyam gahana karmano gatih ||
verse17.explanation: The intricacies of action are very hard to understand. Therefore, one should know properly what action is, what forbidden action is, and what inaction is.
verse17.sanskrit: कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः। अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः।।

verse18.english: Karmany akarma yah pasyed akarmani ca karma yah | Sa buddhiman manushyeshu sa yuktah krtsna-karma-krt ||
verse18.explanation: One who sees inaction in action, and action in inaction, is intelligent among men, and he is in the transcendental position, although engaged in all sorts of activities.
verse18.sanskrit: कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः। स बुद्धिमान्मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत्।।

verse19.english: Yasya sarve samarambhah kama-sankalpa-varjitah | Jnana-agni-dagdha-karmanam tam ahuh panditam budhah ||
verse19.explanation: One is understood to be in full knowledge whose every act is devoid of desire for sense gratification. He is said by sages to be a worker whose fruitive action is burned up by the fire of perfect knowledge.
verse19.sanskrit: यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः। ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः।।

verse20.english: Tyaktva karma-phalasangam nitya-tripto nirashrayah | Karmany abhipravrtto 'pi naiva kincit karoti sah ||
verse20.explanation: Abandoning all attachment to the results of his activities, ever satisfied and independent, he performs no fruitive action, although engaged in all kinds of undertakings.
verse20.sanskrit: त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः। कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किञ्चित्करोति सः।।

verse21.english: Nirashir yata-cittatma tyakta-sarva-parigrahah | Sariram kevalam karma kurvan napnoti kilbisham ||
verse21.explanation: Such a man of understanding acts with mind and intelligence perfectly controlled, gives up all sense of proprietorship over his possessions, and acts only for the bare necessities of life. Thus working, he is not affected by sinful reactions.
verse21.sanskrit: निर्द्वन्द्वो हि महाबाहो सुखं बन्धात्प्रमुच्यते। यः पश्यति स पश्यति।।

verse22.english: Yadrccha-labha-santusto dvandvatito vimatsarah | Samah siddhav asiddhau ca krtvapi na nibadhyate ||
verse22.explanation: He who is satisfied with gain that comes of its own accord, who is free from duality and does not envy, who is steady in both success and failure, is never entangled, although performing actions.

verse23.english: Gata-sangasya muktasya jnanavasthita-cetasah | Yajnayacaratah karma samagram praviliyate ||
verse23.explanation: The work of a man who is unattached to the modes of material nature and who is fully situated in transcendental knowledge merges entirely into transcendence.
verse23.sanskrit: यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः। ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः।।

verse24.english: Brahmarpanam brahma havir brahmagnau brahmana hutam | Brahmaiva tena gantavyam brahma-karma-samadhina ||
verse24.explanation: A person who is fully absorbed in Krishna consciousness is sure to attain the spiritual kingdom because of his full contribution to spiritual activities, in which the consummation is absolute and that which is offered is of the same spiritual nature.
verse24.sanskrit: ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम्। ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्मसमाधिना।।

verse25.english: Daivam evapare yajnam yoginah paryupasate | Brahmagnav apare yajnam yajnenaivopajuhvati ||
verse25.explanation: Some yogis perfectly worship the demigods by offering different sacrifices to them, and some of them offer sacrifices in the fire of the Supreme Brahman.
verse25.sanskrit: दैवमेवापरे यज्ञं योगिनः पर्युपासते। ब्रह्मग्नावपरे यज्ञं यज्ञेनैवोपजुह्वति।।

verse26.english: Srotradinindriyany anye samyamagnishu juhvati | Shabdadin visayan anya indriyagnishu juhvati ||
verse26.explanation: Some (the unadulterated brahmacharis) sacrifice the hearing process and the senses in the fire of mental control, and others (the regulated householders) sacrifice the objects of the senses in the fire of the senses.
verse26.sanskrit: श्रोत्रादीनीन्द्रियाण्यन्ये संयमाग्निषु जुह्वति। शब्दादीन्विषयानन्य इन्द्रियाग्निषु जुह्वति।।

verse27.english: Sarvani indriya-karmani pranakarmani capare | Atma-samyama-yogagnau juhvati jnana-dipite ||
verse27.explanation: Others, who are interested in achieving self-realization through control of the mind and senses, offer the functions of all the senses and of the life breath, as oblations, into the fire of the controlled mind.
verse27.sanskrit: सर्वाणीन्द्रियकर्माणि प्राणकर्माणि चापरे। आत्मसंयमयोगाग्नौ जुह्वति ज्ञानदीपिते।।

verse28.english: Dravya-yajnas tapo-yajna yoga-yajnas tathapare | Svadhyaya-jnana-yajnas ca yatayah samsita-vratah ||
verse28.explanation: Having accepted strict vows, some become enlightened by sacrificing their possessions, and others by performing severe austerities, by practicing the yoga of eightfold mysticism, or by studying the Vedas to advance in transcendental knowledge.
