verse29.english: Apane juhvati pranam prane 'panam tathapare | Pranapana-gati-ruddhva pranayama-parayanah ||
verse29.explanation: Still others, who are inclined to the process of breath restraint to remain in trance, practice by offering the movement of the outgoing breath into the incoming, and the incoming breath into the outgoing, and thus at last remain in trance, stopping all breathing. Others curtailing the eating process, offer the outgoing breath into itself as a sacrifice.
verse29.sanskrit: अपाने जुह्वति प्राणं प्राणेऽपानं तथापरे। प्राणापानगती रुद्ध्वा प्राणायामपरायणाः।।

verse30.english: Apare niyataharah pranam praneshv juhvati | Sarve 'py ete yajna-vido yajna-ksapita-kalmasah ||
verse30.explanation: All these performers who know the meaning of sacrifice become cleansed of sinful reactions, and, having tasted the nectar of the results of sacrifices, they advance toward the supreme eternal atmosphere.
verse30.sanskrit: अपरे नियताहाराः प्राणान्प्राणेषु जुह्वति। सर्वेऽप्येते यज्ञविदो यज्ञक्षपितकल्मषाः।।

verse31.english: Yajna-shishtamrta-bhujo yanti brahma sanatanam | Nayam loko 'sty ayajnasya kuto 'nyah kuru-sattama ||
verse31.explanation: O best of the Kuru dynasty, without sacrifice one can never live happily on this planet or in this life; what then of the next?
verse31.sanskrit: यज्ञशिष्टामृतभुजो यान्ति ब्रह्म सनातनम्। नायं लोकोऽस्त्ययज्ञस्य कुतोऽन्यः कुरुसत्तम।।

verse32.english: Evam bahu-vidha yajna vitata brahmano mukhe | Karma-jan viddhi tan sarvan evam jnatva vimoksyase ||
verse32.explanation: All these different types of sacrifice are approved by the Vedas, and all of them are born of different types of work. Knowing them as such, you will become liberated.
verse32.sanskrit: एवं बहुविधा यज्ञा वितता ब्रह्मणो मुखे। कर्मजान्विद्धि तान्सर्वानेवं ज्ञात्वा विमोक्ष्यसे।।

verse33.english: Sreyan dravya-mayad yajnat jnana-yajnah parantapa | Sarvam karmakhilam partha jnane parisamapyate ||
verse33.explanation: O chastiser of the enemy, the sacrifice performed in knowledge is better than the mere sacrifice of material possessions. After all, O son of Pritha, all sacrifices of work culminate in transcendental knowledge.
verse33.sanskrit: श्रेयान्द्रव्यमयाद्यज्ञाज्ज्ञानयज्ञः परन्तप। सर्वं कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यते।।

verse34.english: Tad viddhi pranipatena pariprashnena sevaya | Upadeksyanti te jnanam jnaninas tattva-darshinah ||
verse34.explanation: Just try to learn the truth by approaching a spiritual master. Inquire from him submissively and render service unto him. The self-realized souls can impart knowledge unto you because they have seen the truth.
verse34.sanskrit: तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया। उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः।।

verse35.english: Yaj jnatva na punar moham evam yasyasi pandava | Yena bhutany ashesani draksyasy atmany atho mayi ||
verse35.explanation: Having obtained real knowledge from a self-realized soul, you will never fall again into such illusion, for by this knowledge you will see that all living beings are but part of the Supreme, or, in other words, that they are mine.
verse35.sanskrit: यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव। येन भूतान्यशेषेण द्रक्ष्यस्यात्मन्यथो मयि।।

verse36.english: Api ced asi papebhyah sarvebhyah papa-krittamah | Sarvam jnana-plavenaiva vrjinam santarisyasi ||
verse36.explanation: Even if you are considered to be the most sinful of all sinners, when you are situated in the boat of transcendental knowledge, you will be able to cross over the ocean of miseries.
verse36.sanskrit: अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः। सर्वं ज्ञानप्लवेनैव वृजिनं सन्तरिष्यसि।।

verse37.english: Yathaidhamsi samiddho 'gnir bhasmasat kurute 'rjuna | Jnanagnih sarva-karmani bhasmasat kurute tatha ||
verse37.explanation: As a blazing fire turns firewood to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge burn to ashes all reactions to material activities.
verse37.sanskrit: यथैधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निर्भस्मसात्कुरुतेऽर्जुन। ज्ञानाग्निः सर्वकर्माणि भस्मसात्कुरुते तथा।।

verse38.english: Na hi jnanena sadrsam pavitram iha vidyate | Tat svayam yoga-samsiddhah kalenatmani vindati ||
verse38.explanation: In this world, there is nothing so sublime and pure as transcendental knowledge. Such knowledge is the mature fruit of all mysticism. And one who has become accomplished in the practice of devotional service enjoys this knowledge within himself in due course of time.
verse38.sanskrit: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते। तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति।।

verse39.english: Sraddhaval labhate jnanam tat-parah samyatendriyah | Jnanam labdhva param shantim acirenadhigacchati ||
verse39.explanation: A faithful man who is absorbed in transcendental knowledge and who subdues his senses quickly attains the supreme spiritual peace.
verse39.sanskrit: श्रद्धावान्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः। ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति।।

verse40.english: Ajnas casraddadhanas ca samsayatma vinasyati | Nayam loko 'sti na paro na sukham samsayaatmanah ||
verse40.explanation: But ignorant and faithless persons who doubt the revealed scriptures do not attain God consciousness; they fall down. For the doubting soul, there is happiness neither in this world nor in the next.
verse40.sanskrit: अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति। नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः।।

verse41.english: Yoga-sannyasta-karmanam jnana-sanchinna-samsayam | Atmavantam na karmani nibadhnanti dhananjaya ||
verse41.explanation: A person who practices Yoga, renounces attachment to results, and is established in self-knowledge is liberated from the bondage of actions.
verse41.sanskrit: योगसंन्यस्तकर्माणं ज्ञानसञ्छिन्नसंशयम्। आत्मवन्तं न कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय।।

verse42.english: Tasmad ajnana-sambhutam hrit-stham jnanasin atmanah | Chittvainam samsayam yogam atisthottistha bharata ||
verse42.explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to use the sword of knowledge to dispel doubts, take refuge in Yoga, and act with clarity and wisdom.
verse42.sanskrit: तस्मादज्ञानसम्भूतं हृत्स्थं ज्ञानासिनात्मनः। छित्त्वैनं संशयं योगमातिष्ठोत्तिष्ठ भारत।।

verse1.english: arjuna uvāca saṁnyāsaṁ karma-yogaṁ ca yaḥ paśhyati sa paśhyati yaḥ paśhyati sa paśhyati
verse1.explanation: Arjuna questions Krishna about the paths of renunciation (sannyasa) and selfless action (karma yoga). He wants to understand which of these paths is more beneficial and how they compare in achieving spiritual realization. This verse sets up the discussion on the merits of different spiritual practices and their impact on attaining liberation.
verse1.sanskrit: "अर्जुन उवाच | अनाश्रितः कर्मफलम् कस्यचित् कर्मयोगम् | सन्दर्शयति कं कर्म सन्दर्शयति यथाश्रुतम् ||"

verse2.english: sāṅkhya-yogau pṛcchāmi hṛṣhīkeśa-parīpṣitaḥ sāṅkhya-yogasya yogasya karmayogasya niḥspharaṁ
verse2.explanation: Arjuna is seeking clarification from Krishna on the differences between the path of Sankhya, which is the path of knowledge and intellectual insight, and the path of Yoga, which is the path of action and devotion. He wants to understand how these paths compare and which might be more effective in achieving spiritual goals. This verse sets the stage for Krishna to explain the nuances and benefits of both paths.
verse2.sanskrit: सन्न्यासस्य महाबाहो दुःखमाप्तुमयोगतः | योगयुक्तो महाबाहो दुःखामाप्तुमयोगतः || 5.2 ||

verse3.english: niṣṭhā saṁnyāsasya sthitā bandhanaṁ karma-yoginaḥ sannyāsena yogasya svarṇāya notthyaṁ
verse3.explanation: Krishna explains the distinction between renunciation and selfless action. He suggests that the path of renunciation (sannyasa), where one completely renounces worldly actions and responsibilities, is considered superior to the path of selfless action (karma yoga). However, he also acknowledges that for those who have mastered renunciation, the practice of selfless action can also lead to spiritual refinement. This verse underscores the complex relationship between these two paths and their respective roles in spiritual development
verse3.sanskrit: योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः | सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते || 5.3 ||

verse4.english: na karmaṇā nārambhaṁ mayāivaṁ karma yogam karma-yogasya sattvasya saṁnyāsasya muñcati
verse4.explanation: Krishna explains that the practice of selfless action (karma yoga) does not hinder the path of renunciation. In fact, those who have reached a high level of self-realization and devotion are not bound by their actions. This verse highlights that selfless action and renunciation are interconnected and that true realization transcends the apparent dichotomy between these practices.
verse4.sanskrit: न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः | यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते || 5.4 ||

verse5.english: yogasya antah prāptasya siddhātmanā yoginaḥ karmān na tu karmaṇām prāṇāyāmy uta na anavasthitaḥ
verse5.explanation: Krishna explains that for someone who has achieved the perfection of Yoga and self-realization, the distinction between action (karma) and renunciation becomes irrelevant. Such a person transcends the need for specific practices and embodies the highest state of spiritual attainment. This verse emphasizes that ultimate realization goes beyond conventional paths and practices.
verse5.sanskrit: नैव किंचित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्यता तत्त्ववित् | पश्यन्शृण्वन्स्पृशन्स्मर्णन्सनानि तस्य सत्यतः || 5.5 ||

verse6.english: arjuna uvāca saṁnyāsaṁ karma-yogaṁ ca yaḥ paśhyati sa pana hi deha-bhṛtā śhakyaṁ tyaktuṁ karmāṇy aśheṣhataḥ yaḥ tu karma-phala-tyāgī sa tyāgīty akṛṣhiḥśhyati yaḥ paśhyati sa paśhyati
verse6.explanation: Krishna acknowledges that it is not feasible for a living being to completely abandon all forms of action while living in the body. Instead, true renunciation is achieved by renouncing the desire for the results of actions. This perspective emphasizes that it is the attitude towards the fruits of actions that defines true renunciation, rather than the mere abandonment of physical activity.

verse7.english: yoga-yukto viśuddhātmanā vijitātmā jitendriyaḥ na sukheṇa samaḥ sadā sarve sukha-śātvah
verse7.explanation: Krishna describes the qualities of a person who practices Yoga diligently. Such a person has a purified soul, has mastery over their mind and senses, and remains balanced and content in all situations. This verse emphasizes the inner peace and stability achieved through dedicated spiritual practice, highlighting that true contentment comes from within, unaffected by external conditions.
verse7.sanskrit: योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः | सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते || 5.7 ||

verse8.english: na karma-phala-saṅyogaṁ yogī na karma-saṁbhavaḥ na karma-phala-saṅyogaḥ na karma-phala-saṅyogaḥ
verse8.explanation: Krishna explains that a true yogi, or someone who has deep knowledge of the Self, realizes that they are not personally engaged in action. Actions are performed by the body and mind, and the Self (or soul) remains unaffected. This verse highlights the detachment from the notion of being the doer of actions, emphasizing that a realized person understands the true nature of action and the Self.
verse8.sanskrit: निःस्पृहः सर्वभूतस्य तस्य तद्व्यतिरेकिना | सर्वकर्माण्यपि सन्न्यस्य सुस्थितो यथा तत्त्वतः || 5.8 ||

verse9.english: yoga-yukto viśuddhātmanā vijitātmā jitendriyaḥ na sukheṇa samaḥ sadā sarve sukha-śātvah
verse9.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that a person who performs actions with detachment and without attachment to the results is not bound by those actions. Such a person understands that the fruits of actions are not their personal concern and thus remains free from the bondage typically associated with actions. This verse reinforces the principle of performing one's duties selflessly and without attachment to outcomes.
verse9.sanskrit: निःस्पृहः सर्वभूतस्य तस्य तद्व्यतिरेकिना | सर्वकर्माण्यपि सन्न्यस्य सुस्थितो यथा तत्त्वतः || 5.8 ||

verse10.english: brahmaṇy ādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ niḥsaṅgaḥ sa siddhārāḥ yaḥ siddhyati
verse10.explanation: Krishna explains that actions performed with a sense of dedication to the Supreme and without attachment to the outcomes lead to spiritual perfection. The true yogi is one who acts selflessly, free from the desire for personal gain, and attains the highest level of spiritual realization. This verse emphasizes the importance of selfless action and detachment in achieving spiritual success.
verse10.sanskrit: ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविः ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम् | ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्म समाधिना || 5.10 ||

verse11.english: kāyena manasā buddhyā kevalair indriyair api yoginaḥ karma kurvanti saṅgaṁ tyaktvātma-śuddhaye
verse11.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that a true practitioner of Yoga is one who performs all actions with the understanding that they are dedicated to the Divine, rather than being concerned with personal outcomes. This selfless approach, where one renounces the attachment to the results of actions, leads to spiritual liberation and fulfillment. The verse highlights that the essence of Yoga is in
verse11.sanskrit: ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविः ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम् | ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्म समाधिना || 5.10 ||

verse12.english: yuktaḥ karma-phalaṁ tyaktvā śhāntim āpnoti naiṣhṭhikīm ayuktaḥ kāma-kāreṇa phale sakto nibadhyate
verse12.explanation: Krishna explains that the individual who renounces attachment to the results of their actions and dedicates their efforts to the Divine attains the highest level of spiritual perfection. This verse emphasizes that the true essence of action lies not in the physical performance but in the attitude of non-attachment and dedication.
verse12.sanskrit: "निःस्पृग्गण्यः स्वधर्मेण तिष्ठन्ति समाहितः | संतुष्टः सर्वकर्मण्यविनिर्भिः स निश्चलः || 12 ||"

verse13.english: sarva-karmāṇi manasā saṁnyasyāste sukhaṁ vaśhī navadvāre pure dehī naiva kurvan na kārayan
verse13.explanation: Krishna explains that a person who performs their duties selflessly, dedicating them to the Divine, and who is free from attachment to the outcomes, attains liberation. This individual acts with a sense of detachment and devotion, understanding that the results of actions are not their primary concern. The verse highlights that the path to liberation involves performing actions with a selfless attitude and dedication.
verse13.sanskrit: "सर्वकर्माण्यपि सन्न्यस्याध्यात्मचित्तः नित्यसर्गः | न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः || 13 ||"

verse14.english: na kartṛtvaṁ na karmāṇi lokasya sṛjati prabhuḥ na karma-phala-saṁyogaṁ svabhāvas tu pravartate
verse14.explanation: Krishna clarifies that the Supreme Divine, or the ultimate reality, is beyond the effects of individual actions and their results. The divine principle remains unaffected by the actions performed by beings. This verse reinforces the concept that the true essence of spiritual practice is performing one's duties with selflessness and without attachment to the results, as the divine reality is beyond the dualities of action and its fruits.
verse14.sanskrit: "न कर्मणाम् अनारंभान् यति नस्यति नाश्रयात् | न कर्मफलसङ्गेऽस्मिन्युच्छेदोऽन्यथा वसेत् || 14 ||"

verse15.english: nādatte kasyacit pāpaṁ na caiva sukṛtaṁ vibhuḥ ajñānenāvṛtaṁ jñānaṁ tena muhyanti jantavaḥ
verse15.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that the Supreme Divine is beyond the influence of actions or their results. The ultimate reality is unaffected by the performance or results of actions. This verse reiterates that the practice of Yoga involves engaging in actions selflessly, without attachment to the outcomes, as the divine essence remains impervious to these worldly processes.
verse15.sanskrit: "न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेत् अजñानम् कर्मसङ्गिनाम् | जो यो कर्मधार्मिकः सस्वादधिको मणाश्रमः || 15 ||"

verse16.english: jñānena tu tad ajñānaṁ yeṣhāṁ nāśhitam ātmanaḥ teṣhām āditya-vaj jñānaṁ prakāśhayati tat param
verse16.explanation: Krishna explains that it is impossible for a living being to entirely give up all forms of action while in the body. Instead, the essence of renunciation lies in giving up attachment to the results of one's actions. A person who performs their duties selflessly, without concern for the outcomes, is considered a true renunciant. This verse emphasizes that the key to true renunciation is detachment from the fruits of actions, rather than the mere cessation of physical activity.

verse17.english: tad-buddhayas tad-ātmānaḥ tan-niṣhṭhās tat-parāyaṇāḥ gacchanty apunar-āvṛittim jñāna-nirdhūta-kalmaṣhāḥ
verse17.explanation: Krishna explains that the ultimate state of perfection and realization is achieved through actions performed with discernment and wisdom, not by merely ceasing to act. The highest spiritual attainment comes from understanding and engaging in actions in a selfless and detached manner, rather than through inaction or avoidance of duties. This verse underscores the importance of performing one's duties with wisdom and right understanding to achieve spiritual growth and fulfillment.
verse17.sanskrit: "तमोऽस्मिन्हि कर्मणामपारमत्वात् | मायाह प्राप्यतेऽनेन रागस्य धृतः स्यान्मुखः || 17 ||"

verse18.english: vidyā-vinaya-sampanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini śhuni chaiva śhva-pāke cha paṇḍitāḥ sama-darśhinaḥ
verse18.explanation: Krishna explains that a truly wise person, who has attained true knowledge and insight, sees everyone and everything with equal respect and compassion. This equality of vision transcends social, economic, and physical differences. The verse emphasizes that spiritual wisdom involves recognizing the inherent unity and divinity in all beings, regardless of their external conditions.
verse18.sanskrit: "विद्याविनयसंयुक्ता ब्राह्मणाः क्षत्रियस्तथा | वैश्यस्तथा शूद्रस्तथा नान्येव यथाविधि || 18 ||"

verse19.english: ihaiva tair jitaḥ sargaḥ yeṣhāṁ sāmye sthitaṁ manaḥ nirdoṣhaṁ hi samaṁ brahma tasmād brahmaṇi te sthitāḥ
verse19.explanation: Krishna explains that a truly wise person, who has attained true knowledge and insight, sees everyone and everything with equal respect and compassion. This equality of vision transcends social, economic, and physical differences. The verse emphasizes that spiritual wisdom involves recognizing the inherent unity and divinity in all beings, regardless of their external conditions.
verse19.sanskrit: "यस्तु सर्वाणि कर्माणि निःस्प्रग्गाणि सन्दधाति | न चेदं वेधि वेदश्च न शास्त्रसिद्धयोऽपि || 19 ||"

verse20.english: na prahṛṣyet priyaṁ prāpya nodvijet prāpya chāpriyam sthira-buddhir asammūḍho brahma-vid brahmaṇi sthitaḥ
verse20.explanation: Krishna teaches that a person who remains unaffected by the fluctuations of pleasure and pain, and who does not get disturbed by happiness or sorrow, is truly peaceful and wise. This equanimity is a sign of a sage who has transcended the impacts of material experiences. The verse underscores the importance of maintaining inner peace and stability amidst the dualities of life.
verse20.sanskrit: "न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः | यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते || 20 ||"

verse21.english: naiva kiñcit karenārho vigata-saṅgaḥ susantuṣaḥ antaḥ-pramāṇaṁ yastu brahma-bhūtaḥ sanātanaṁ
verse21.explanation: Krishna explains that the true Self (Atman) is eternal and unchanging, unaffected by birth or death. A wise person understands this and is devoted to their own duty and spiritual practice. Such an individual, who relies on the eternal Self and is dedicated to their own path, is regarded as virtuous. The verse emphasizes the eternal nature of the Self and the importance of adhering to one's duty while remaining grounded in spiritual truth.
verse21.sanskrit: "नासत्वाश्च निश्चलः स्वधर्मात् साक्षात् परं परमः | नं लिङ्गं लिङ्गरूपं च न वस्त्रं वस्त्रमौप्यः || 21 ||"

verse22.english: yad rājyaṁ prāpya śānto nānṛṇaṁ nāpi bhūtim brahma-sūryam anugacchati saḥ pāṇiḥ pāṇiḥ sanātanaḥ
verse22.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that true contentment and satisfaction come from mastering the senses and the mind. A person who has successfully subdued their desires and who is focused on the Self finds inner peace and fulfillment, independent of external conditions. This verse highlights the significance of self-control and inner mastery in achieving a state of true satisfaction and tranquility.
verse22.sanskrit: "यस्त्वात्मरतिरेव स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः | आत्मन्येवात्मानं यस्तु तस्यात्याचारता पुनः || 22 ||"

verse23.english: yo na hṛṣhyati na dveṣhṭi na śhochati na kāṅkṣhati śubha-śubha-parityāgī gacchanti brahma-saṁsthitāḥ
verse23.explanation: Krishna explains that a person who has attained spiritual realization and is grounded in divine wisdom finds true happiness and contentment within themselves. They are not dependent on external actions or outcomes for their sense of fulfillment. This inner peace and joy are derived from their understanding and connection with the divine, rather than from the external world
verse23.sanskrit: "न सुखं न दुःखं च न शोकः सुखस्य परं यतः | स्वधर्मे च समाहितः सतोऽप्यात्मन्यवस्थितः || 23 ||"

verse24.english: brahmaṇy ādhāya karmāṇi sāmya-prāptaḥ samaḥ priyaḥ santuṣhṭaḥ sattva-vatīṁ na tv ācāryuḥ sadā sukhī
verse24.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that spiritual fulfillment is not contingent upon worldly success or material possessions. True realization and ultimate satisfaction come from understanding and connecting with the divine within oneself. This verse highlights that achieving the highest state of spiritual attainment is independent of external factors and is rooted in inner spiritual wisdom.
verse24.sanskrit: "ब्रह्मणि आदाय भूदानं संन्यासं न्यस्य नः शुभम् | तदात्मानं प्राप्य तमसा या तृप्तः सदा मुक्ति || 24 ||"

verse25.english: brahmārpaṇaṁ brahma haviḥ brahmāgnau brahmaṇā hutam brahmaiva tena gantavyaṁ brahma-karma samādhinā
verse25.explanation: Krishna describes that a true yogi, who has reached a state of inner satisfaction and peace, perceives the Self in all creatures and aspects of life. This universal vision and understanding signify the culmination of spiritual practice. The verse emphasizes that spiritual success involves seeing and
verse25.sanskrit: "ब्रह्मैव वह्नोश्च युक्ता योगिनो ज्ञानयोगिनः | अहिंसा तव तावार्यमुक्ति सत्यविहीने || 25 ||"

verse26.english: brahmāṇam brahma-saṁjñam bhavaty apashyati sadā brahma-saṁjñāṁ vi vichchhāntaṁ sadā brahma-sādhakaḥ
verse26.explanation: Krishna explains that a person who perceives the divine essence within all beings and sees all beings as part of the Self has achieved true self-realization. Such a person understands the fundamental unity of existence and experiences the ultimate truth of interconnectedness. This realization reflects a deep spiritual insight where the individual recognizes the divine presence in all aspects of life and existence.
verse26.sanskrit: "ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविः ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा यतः | ब्रह्मैव ब्रह्मणोऽन्तःस्मिन्ग्रह्ममध्यात्म तत्त्वतः || 26 ||"

verse27.english: śarīra-vāṅ-manobhir yat karmāṁ prārabhate naraḥ nyāyyam vā viparyayam na khalv ātra niṣhṛitam
verse27.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that merely performing physical actions for the sake of bodily needs, without recognizing their deeper spiritual purpose, does not reflect true wisdom. A true sage understands and acts with awareness of the spiritual significance behind actions. This verse underscores the importance of performing one's duties with an understanding of their higher purpose, rather than focusing solely on material or physical outcomes.
verse27.sanskrit: "सर्वधर्मान्परित्यज्य मामेकं सरणं व्रज | अहं त्वां सर्वपापेभ्यो मोक्षयिष्यामि मा sucah || 27 ||"

verse28.english: sattvaṁ prekṣya karmāṇi prayatnaścha vadanti hi saṁvṛttiḥ parituṣṭasya śarīra-vāṇy asī sarvathā
verse28.explanation: Krishna teaches that attaining the Supreme is not about abandoning action but performing it with detachment and without attachment to outcomes. Those who act selflessly and remain unattached to the results find true peace and embody the highest virtues. This verse highlights the importance of approaching actions with the right attitude to achieve spiritual fulfillment and inner calm.
verse28.sanskrit: "ब्रह्मयोग्यः साक्षात्कृत्यात्मानं च भुज्यते | अप्राणप्राणदायासं यस्तु सूक्ष्मायामेकः || 28 ||"

verse29.english: brahmārpaṇaṁ brahma haviḥ brahmāgnau brahmaṇā hutam brahmaiva tena gantavyaṁ brahma-karma samādhinā
verse29.explanation: Krishna teaches that attaining the Supreme is not about abandoning action but performing it with detachment and without attachment to outcomes. Those who act selflessly and remain unattached to the results find true peace and embody the highest virtues. This verse highlights the importance of approaching actions with the right attitude to achieve spiritual fulfillment and inner calm.
verse29.sanskrit: "ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्म हविः ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा यतः | ब्रह्मैव ब्रह्मणोऽन्तःस्मिन्ग्रह्ममध्यात्म तत्त्वतः || 29 ||"

verse1.english: anāśhritaḥ karma-phalaṁ kāryaṁ karma karoti yaḥ sa sannyāsī cha yogī cha na niragnir na chākriyaḥ
verse1.explanation: Krishna describes the nature of true renunciation. He explains that the essence of renunciation lies in performing one's duties without being attached to the results. A person who acts with this mindset, without being influenced by the outcomes of their actions, is regarded as a genuine renunciant. The focus is on the quality of action and the intention behind it, rather than the results.
verse1.sanskrit: अनाश्रितः कर्मफलं कार्यं कर्म करोति यः | स संन्यासी च योगी च न निरग्निर्न चाक्रियः ||

verse2.english: yaṁ sannyāsam iti prāhur yogaṁ taṁ viddhi pāṇḍava na hy asannyasta-saṅkalpo yogī bhavati kaśchana
verse2.explanation: Krishna explains to Arjuna that the path of renunciation (sannyasa) and the path of yoga are essentially the same because both require the renunciation of attachment to desires. To be a true yogi, one must relinquish desires and the attachment to the fruits of their actions.
verse2.sanskrit: यं संन्यासमिति प्राहुर्योगं तं विद्धि पाण्डव | न ह्यसंन्यस्तसङ्कल्पो योगी भवति कश्चन ||

verse3.english: ārurukṣhor muner yogaṁ karma kāraṇam uchyate yogārūḍhasya tasyaiva śhamaḥ kāraṇam uchyate
verse3.explanation: Krishna explains that for those just beginning the path of yoga, performing their duties and actions is essential. However, for those who have progressed and are established in yoga, the practice of detachment and inner peace becomes the focus, and the renunciation of action becomes the means to maintain their state of union with the divine.
verse3.sanskrit: आरुरुक्षोर्मुनेर्योगं कर्म कारणमुच्यते | योगारूढस्य तस्यैव शमः कारणमुच्यते ||

verse4.english: yadā hi nendriyārtheṣhu na karmasv anuṣhajjate sarva-saṅkalpa-sannyāsī yogārūḍhas tadocyate
verse4.explanation: Krishna describes the state of a person who has reached an advanced level in yoga. Such a person is no longer driven by the desire for sense pleasures or attached to the outcomes of their actions. They have renounced all material desires and are fully absorbed in the practice of yoga, which is characterized by complete control over the mind and senses. This state marks the culmination of the yoga journey.
verse4.sanskrit: यदा हि नेन्द्रियार्थेषु न कर्मस्वनुषज्जते | सर्वसङ्कल्पसंन्यासी योगारूढस्तदोच्यते ||

verse5.english: uddhared ātmanātmānaṁ nātmānam avasādayet ātmaiva hyātmano bandhur ātmaiva ripur ātmanaḥ
verse5.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the importance of self-discipline and mental control. One's own mind can be their best friend if it is controlled and directed towards positive goals. However, if the mind is not controlled, it can become one's greatest enemy, leading to self-destruction. The responsibility for one's spiritual progress lies within themselves, and it is crucial to elevate oneself through the power of a disciplined mind.
verse5.sanskrit: उद्धरेदात्मनाऽऽत्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत् | आत्मैव ह्यात्मनो बन्धुरात्मैव रिपुरात्मन: ||

verse6.english: bandhur ātmātmanas tasya yenātmaivātmanā jitaḥ anātmanas tu śatrutve vartetātmaiva śatruvat
verse6.explanation: Krishna explains that a person who has control over their mind finds it to be their greatest ally, aiding them in their spiritual journey. Conversely, for someone who has not mastered their mind, it becomes their worst enemy, leading to internal conflict and spiritual stagnation. Mastery over the mind is thus crucial for progress on the path of yoga
verse6.sanskrit: बन्धुरात्मात्मनस्तस्य येनात्मैवात्मना जित: | अनात्मनस्तु शत्रुत्वे वर्तेतात्मैव शत्रुवत् ||

verse7.english: jitātmanaḥ praśhāntasya paramātmā samāhitaḥ śhītoṣhṇa-sukha-duḥkheṣhu tathā mānāpamānayoḥ
verse7.explanation: Krishna explains that self-mastery is crucial for inner peace and harmony. For someone who has conquered their own mind and self, the Self becomes a loyal friend, offering inner support and tranquility. Conversely, for someone who has not achieved this self-mastery, the mind becomes an enemy, leading to inner conflict and unrest. This verse highlights the importance of self-control and inner discipline in achieving spiritual growth and well-being.
verse7.sanskrit: जितात्मन: प्रशान्तस्य परमात्मा समाहित: | शीतोष्णसुखदु:खेषु तथा मानापमानयो: ||

verse8.english: yadā sanharate chāyaṁ kūrmo ‘ṅgānīva sarvaśhaḥ indriyāṇī indriya-arthhebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
verse8.explanation: Krishna uses the metaphor of a tortoise withdrawing its limbs to illustrate how a person should control their senses. Just as a tortoise retracts its limbs to protect itself, a person practicing yoga should withdraw their senses from external objects and distractions. This sense withdrawal leads to a steady and unwavering intellect, essential for achieving true knowledge and self-realization.
verse8.sanskrit: यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वश: | इन्द्रियाणी इन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ||

verse9.english: vidhīṣṭa-lakṣmiśhca sūyate sarvāṇy api chāyuktam sarveṣām api chāyuktam
verse9.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the importance of being even-minded and disciplined. A person who approaches all situations with detachment and without being swayed by materialistic pleasures or pride will achieve true wisdom. Such an individual maintains equilibrium in their actions and reactions, which is crucial for spiritual progress.
verse9.sanskrit: वित्ते लक्ष्मीश्च सूयते | सर्वान्यपि चायुक्तं | सर्वेषामपि चायुक्तं ||

verse10.english: yogī yuñjīta satatam ātmānaṁ rahasi sthitaḥ ekākī yata-cittātmā nirāśhīr aparigrahaḥ
verse10.explanation: Krishna describes the ideal environment and mindset for a yogi. A yogi should practice meditation consistently, in a quiet and secluded place, where they can focus without distractions. The yogi should be alone, with a disciplined mind and body, free from desires, and not attached to material possessions. This disciplined practice leads to deeper concentration and spiritual growth.
verse10.sanskrit: योगी युञ्जीत सततमात्मानं रहसि स्थित: | एकाकी यतचित्तात्मा निराशीरपरिग्रह: ||

verse11.english: śhuchau deśhe pratiṣhṭhāpya sthiram āsanam ātmanaḥ nātyuchchhritaṁ nātinīchaṁ chailājina-kuśhottaram
verse11.explanation: Krishna provides specific instructions for setting up a suitable place for meditation. The seat should be in a clean, sanctified location, neither too high nor too low, and should be made with a combination of cloth, deerskin, and kusha grass to provide comfort and stability. This careful preparation of the seat helps in maintaining physical steadiness and supports the mental focus required for successful meditation.
verse11.sanskrit: शुचौ देशे प्रतिष्ठाप्य स्थिरमासनमात्मन: | नात्युच्छ्रितं नातिनीचं चैलाजिनकुशोत्तरम् ||

verse12.english: tatraikāgraṁ manaḥ kṛitvā yata-chittendriya-kriyaḥ upaviśhyāsane yuñjyād yogam ātma-viśhuddhaye
verse12.explanation: Krishna instructs that after preparing the seat as described in the previous verse, one should sit on it with the mind focused and senses controlled. The purpose of this disciplined practice of yoga is to purify the self, both mentally and spiritually. Concentration, control of the senses, and dedicated practice are essential for achieving this inner purification and advancing on the spiritual path.
verse12.sanskrit: तत्रैकाग्रं मन: कृत्वा यतचित्तेन्द्रियक्रिय: | उपविश्यासने युञ्ज्याद्योगमात्मविशुद्धये ||

verse13.english: samaṁ kāya-śhiro-grīvaṁ dhārayann achalaṁ sthiraḥ samprekṣhya nāsikāgraṁ svaṁ diśhaś chānavalokayan
verse13.explanation: Krishna provides further guidance on the posture for meditation. The body, head, and neck should be kept straight and aligned, and the practitioner should remain steady and motionless. The gaze should be fixed on the tip of the nose, helping to focus the mind and avoid distractions. This physical alignment and focused gaze are meant to facilitate deep concentration during meditation, leading to greater control over the mind and senses.
verse13.sanskrit: समं कायशिरोग्रीवं धारयन्नचलं स्थिर: | सम्प्रेक्ष्य नासिकाग्रं स्वं दिशश्चानवलोकयन् ||

verse14.english: praśhāntātmā vigata-bhīr brahmachāri-vrate sthitaḥ manaḥ saṁyamya mach-chitto yukta āsīta mat-paraḥ
verse14.explanation: Krishna advises the practitioner to meditate with a calm and peaceful mind, devoid of fear. Observing celibacy, which implies a disciplined and controlled lifestyle, helps in focusing the mind. The practitioner should direct their thoughts towards Krishna, with unwavering devotion and concentration. This verse emphasizes the importance of mental calmness, self-discipline, and single-minded devotion in the practice of meditation.
verse14.sanskrit: प्रशान्तात्मा विगतभीर्ब्रह्मचारिव्रते स्थित: | मन: संयम्य मच्चित्तो युक्त आसीत मत्पर: ||

verse15.english: yuñjann evaṁ sadātmānaṁ yogī niyata-mānasaḥ śhāntiṁ nirvāṇa-paramāṁ mat-saṁsthām adhigachchhati
verse15.explanation: Krishna explains that by practicing constant self-discipline and mental control, a yogi attains a state of supreme peace, referred to as Nirvana. This state is free from the turmoil of the material world and is rooted in the divine consciousness of Krishna. The verse emphasizes the importance of consistent practice and mental focus in achieving spiritual liberation and ultimate peace.
verse15.sanskrit: युञ्जन्नेवं सदात्मानं योगी नियतमानस: | शान्तिं निर्वाणपरमां मत्संस्थामधिगच्छति ||

verse16.english: nāty-aśhnatas tu yogo ’sti na chaikānta-manaśhnataḥ na chāti-svapna-śhīlasya jāgrato naiva chārjuna
verse16.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the importance of moderation in all aspects of life for the successful practice of yoga. Both extremes—whether in eating, sleeping, or waking—are detrimental to the path of yoga. A balanced lifestyle, where one does not indulge excessively nor deprives oneself unduly, is essential for maintaining the physical and mental harmony necessary for spiritual progress.
verse16.sanskrit: नात्यश्नतस्तु योगोऽस्ति न चैकान्तमनश्नत: | न चातिस्वप्नशीलस्य जाग्रतो नैव चार्जुन ||

verse17.english: yuktāhāra-vihārasya yukta-cheṣhṭasya karmasu yukta-svapnāvabodhasya yogo bhavati duḥkha-hā
verse17.explanation: Krishna explains that a balanced and moderate lifestyle is crucial for successful yoga practice. When a person practices moderation in all aspects—whether it’s eating, recreation, work, sleep, or wakefulness—they create the right conditions for yoga to flourish. This balanced approach helps in overcoming sorrows and leads to a more harmonious and peaceful life. Moderation in daily activities supports the mind's calmness and stability, essential for spiritual growth.
verse17.sanskrit: युक्ताहारविहारस्य युक्तचेष्टस्य कर्मसु | युक्तस्वप्नावबोधस्य योगो भवति दु:खहा ||

verse18.english: yadā viniyataṁ chittam ātmany evāvatiṣhṭhate niḥspṛihaḥ sarva-kāmebhyo yukta ityuchyate tadā
verse18.explanation: Krishna explains that true yoga is achieved when a person’s mind is fully controlled and focused on the self, without any desires for material pleasures. When the mind is disciplined and completely absorbed in the self, free from all worldly cravings, one reaches the state of being "yukta," or perfectly united in yoga. This state represents the ultimate harmony and spiritual alignment, where the mind is steady and peaceful, anchored in the higher self.
verse18.sanskrit: यदा विनियतं चित्तमात्मन्येवावतिष्ठते | निःस्पृहः सर्वकामेभ्यो युक्त इत्युच्यते तदा ||

verse19.english: yathā dīpo nivāta-stho neṅgate sopamā smṛitā yogino yata-chittasya yuñjato yogam ātmanaḥ
verse19.explanation: Krishna provides a powerful metaphor to describe the state of a yogi who has attained mental discipline. Just as a lamp placed in a windless spot burns steadily without flickering, similarly, the mind of a disciplined yogi remains unwavering and calm, focused on the self. This verse highlights the stability and peace that come with deep meditation and self-control, where the mind is undisturbed by external influences or distractions, allowing for a steady and clear connection with the inner self.
verse19.sanskrit: यथा दीपो निवातस्थो नेङ्गते सोपमा स्मृता | योगिनो यतचित्तस्य युञ्जतो योगमात्मन: ||

verse20.english: yatroparamate chittaṁ niruddhaṁ yoga-sevayā yatra chaivātmanātmānaṁ paśhyann ātmani tuṣhyati
verse20.explanation: Krishna describes the profound state achieved through the practice of yoga. When the mind, through disciplined practice, becomes calm and quiet, the yogi experiences deep self-realization. In this state, one sees the self with a clear vision, free from distractions, and finds complete satisfaction within the self alone. This verse highlights the ultimate goal of yoga—self-realization and inner contentment, where external desires and influences no longer disturb the mind's peace.
verse20.sanskrit: यत्रोपरमते चित्तं निरुद्धं योगसेवया | यत्र चैवात्मनाऽऽत्मानं पश्यन्नात्मनि तुष्यति ||

verse21.english: sukham ātyantikaṁ yat tad buddhi-grāhyam atīndriyam vetti yatra na chaivāyaṁ sthitaś chalati tattvataḥ
verse21.explanation: Krishna describes the supreme bliss experienced in the state of true yoga. This joy is not sensory but is grasped by the intellect and is far deeper than any physical pleasure. Once a yogi attains this state, they are firmly grounded in the truth and are not swayed by the external world. This verse emphasizes the transcendental and unshakable nature of the happiness found through self-realization and spiritual enlightenment.
verse21.sanskrit: सुखमात्यन्तिकं यत्तद्बुद्धिग्राह्यमतीन्द्रियम् | वेत्ति यत्र न चैवायं स्थितश्चलति तत्त्वत: ||

verse22.english: yaṁ labdhvā chāparaṁ lābhaṁ manyate nādhikaṁ tataḥ yasmin sthito na duḥkhena guruṇāpi vichālyate
verse22.explanation: Krishna explains that once a yogi attains the supreme state of self-realization and spiritual enlightenment, they see no other achievement as greater or more valuable. This state brings such profound inner fulfillment that no external gain or loss can compare. Furthermore, being established in this state, the yogi remains unshaken even in the face of the most intense sorrows or difficulties. This verse highlights the supreme stability and unassailable peace that come with spiritual enlightenment.
verse22.sanskrit: यं लब्ध्वा चापरं लाभं मन्यते नाधिकं तत: | यस्मिन्स्थितो न दुःखेन गुरुणापि विचाल्यते ||

verse23.english: taṁ vidyād duḥkha-saṁyoga-viyogaṁ yoga-saṁjñitam sa niśhchayena yoktavyo yogo ’nirviṇṇa-chetasā
verse23.explanation: Krishna defines yoga as the state of being free from the union with suffering. It is the art of disconnecting oneself from the causes of sorrow and establishing oneself in inner peace and joy. This yoga should be pursued with strong resolve and a steadfast, undistracted mind. The verse emphasizes the importance of dedication and mental strength in achieving the ultimate goal of yoga, which is liberation from all forms of suffering.
verse23.sanskrit: तं विद्यात् दुःखसंयोगवियोगं योगसंज्ञितम् | स निश्चयेन योक्तव्यो योगोऽनिर्विण्णचेतसा ||

verse24.english: sarva-bandha-vinirmukto yogī parama-gāmyaham uttiṣṭheta yoga-saṁyogāt sarvasya siddhim āpnuyāt
verse24.explanation: Krishna advises that a yogi who has overcome all limitations and achieved the highest state of yoga should rise and continue their practice. This persistent practice leads to the attainment of complete perfection in all areas of life. The verse underscores the importance of ongoing effort and discipline in yoga, which ultimately leads to a state of full realization and accomplishment.
verse24.sanskrit: सर्वबन्धविनिर्मुक्तो योगी परमगाम्यहम् | उत्तिष्ठेत योगसंयोगात् सर्वस्य सिद्धिमाप्नुयात् ||

verse25.english: saṁyamaṁ prāṇāyāmaṁ turyam anuṣāsanam saṁyamaṁ niṣevatāṁ śāntāṁ vā viṣādānām
verse25.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the need for gradual and consistent practice in controlling the mind. By engaging in disciplined and steady practice, one can attain mastery over the mind and achieve a state of inner calm and mental control. This practice should be continued with patience and persistence to reach the ultimate goal of tranquility and spiritual progress.

verse26.english: yato yato niśhcarati manaśh chanchalam asthiram tatas tato niyām yetātman-y eva vaśham nayet
verse26.explanation: Krishna instructs that whenever the mind, which is naturally restless and prone to wandering, strays from its focus, it should be gently brought back under control. The practice involves directing the mind back to the self or the point of focus, reinforcing its discipline. This ongoing effort to regain control over the mind is essential for effective meditation and spiritual progress.
verse26.sanskrit: यतो यतो निश्चरति मनश्चंचलमस्थिरम् | ततस्ततो नियाम्येतात्मन्येव वशं नयेत् ||

verse27.english: praśhānta-manāḥ so ’śhāntiḥ paramaṁ saṅgataṁ sasteṣhām yoga-mattamanam śāntam asī svagam
verse27.explanation: Krishna describes the state of supreme tranquility that is achieved when the mind is calm and peaceful. For those who have mastered their inner selves and practiced yoga diligently, this state of peace becomes a natural outcome. It signifies the highest level of inner calm and contentment, a profound state of serenity that arises from spiritual realization and disciplined practice.
verse27.sanskrit: प्रशान्तमना: सोऽशान्ति: परमं सङ्गतं | सस्तेषां योगमत्तमनं शान्तमसि स्वगम् ||

verse28.english: yadā sattve samāviṣṭaṁ yogamālinam tadā labhate yogī tan-manasī sadāraṇam
verse28.explanation: Krishna explains that when a yogi's mind is completely immersed in the practice of yoga and is filled with pure, sattvic qualities, they attain a stable and consistent state of consciousness. This steady mental state reflects the successful practice of yoga, leading to a constant and unwavering awareness, free from disturbances and fluctuations.
verse28.sanskrit: यदा सत्त्वे समाविष्टमहोऽनं योगमालिनं | तदा लभते योगी तन्मनसि सदारणम् ||

verse29.english: sarva-bhūta-stham ātmānaṁ sarva-bhūtāni chātmani ikṣhate yoga-yuktātmā sarvatra samadarśhanaḥ
verse29.explanation: Krishna describes the vision of a true yogi. One who is firmly established in yoga perceives the Self (Atman) present in all living beings and recognizes that all beings are essentially the same Self. This realization leads to an equal vision, where the yogi views all beings with the same level of understanding and compassion, transcending personal biases and distinctions. This universal perspective reflects the deep spiritual insight and unity achieved through dedicated practice of yoga.
verse29.sanskrit: सर्वभूतस्थमात्मानं सर्वभूतानि चात्मनि | इक्षते योगयुक्तात्मा सर्वत्र समदर्शन: ||

verse30.english: yo māṁ paśhyati sarvatra sarvaṁ cha mayi paśhyati tasyāhaṁ na praṇaśhyāmi sa cha me na praṇaśhyati
verse30.explanation: Krishna explains that when a person perceives the divine presence in all things and recognizes everything as being within the divine, there is a profound mutual connection. Such a person remains constantly aware of the divine presence and is never separated from it. This reciprocal vision ensures that both the divine and the devotee are always in a state of unity, reflecting the ultimate realization of oneness through spiritual practice.
verse30.sanskrit: यो मां पश्यति सर्वत्र सर्वं च मयि पश्यति | तस्याहं न प्रणश्यामि स्च मे न प्रणश्यति ||

verse31.english: athvā hy asya me sattvaṁ yad ya sattva-yutaṁ sarveṣhāṁ su-saṁdṛṣṭis sarvaṁ prāpto yoginām
verse31.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that the essence of true yogic practice lies in perceiving the Self (Atman) within all beings and recognizing all beings within the Self. This vision of interconnectedness and unity reflects a profound understanding and realization of the ultimate truth. The yogi who achieves this insight attains the highest level of spiritual awareness and fulfills the ultimate goal of yoga, which is to experience and embody the unity of all existence.
verse31.sanskrit: अथ्वा ह्यस्य में सत्त्वं यद् या सत्त्वयुतं | सर्वेषां सुसंदृष्टिस्सर्वं प्राप्तो योगिनाम् ||

verse32.english: ātmanam sarva-bhūteṣhu yaḥ paśhyati saḥ yogaḥ sarveṣhāṁ cha māttamānaṁ hi so ’ham asmi yatsmin sthānam tu me
verse32.explanation: Krishna highlights that the highest form of yoga is achieved by seeing the Self within all living beings and recognizing the interconnectedness of all existence. This vision of unity, where one perceives no separation between themselves and others, signifies the ultimate realization of oneness. The yogi who reaches this level of understanding and perception attains the highest state of spiritual awareness and alignment with the divine.
verse32.sanskrit: आत्मनं सर्वभूतेषु यः पश्यति सः योग: | सर्वेषां च मात्तमानं हि सोऽहमस्मि यत्स्मिन्स्थानं तु मे ||

verse33.english: arjuna uvācha atha kena prayukto ’yaṁ pāśhyaṁ naḥ yaḥ ātmanam kathaṁ cha prājñaḥ serāśhchaṣṭa-pāśhyaḥ karmaṇaḥ
verse33.explanation: Arjuna asks Krishna about the nature of the inner forces that drive a person to act contrary to their better judgment or intentions. He inquires about what influences a person to perform actions that seem to go against their own understanding and wisdom. This question addresses the conflict between inherent tendencies and the conscious decisions of a person, seeking to understand the underlying causes of such behavior.
verse33.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | अथ केन प्रयुक्तोऽयं पाश्वाणति यः आत्मनम् | कथं च प्राज्ञः सेराश्चेष्टपश्चार्थकर्मणः ||

verse34.english: chañchalaṁ hi manaḥ kṛiṣhṇa pramāthi balavattaraṁ tasyāhaṁ nigṛhīte ’pi abhyāsena tu kaushalam
verse34.explanation: Arjuna acknowledges the mind's restless and turbulent nature, comparing it to a powerful force, even stronger than the wind. He expresses the difficulty in controlling such a mind but acknowledges that with persistent practice and discipline, it is possible to master it. This verse highlights the challenge of mental control in yoga and the importance of consistent effort and perseverance in achieving mastery over the mind.
verse34.sanskrit: चञ्चलं हि मनः कृष्ण प्रामाथि बलवत्तरं | तस्याहं निगृहीतेऽपि अभ्यासेन तु कौशलम् ||

verse35.english: asaṁśhayaṁ mahābāho mano dur-nigrahaṁ chalam abhyāsena tu kaunteya vairāgyaṁ ca gṛhyate
verse35.explanation: Krishna agrees with Arjuna that the mind is indeed very restless and challenging to control. However, he reassures Arjuna that with persistent practice and detachment, mastery over the mind can be achieved. This verse emphasizes the importance of perseverance and the combination of disciplined effort and dispassion in the process of mental control and spiritual progress.
verse35.sanskrit: असंशयं महाबाहो मनो दुरनिग्रहं चलं | अभ्यासेन तु कौंश्यं वायुः चान्ति यथास्तथा ||

verse36.english: atha chittaṁ mano vāyuḥ tasmād dīrghāṁ yogaḥ vṛiddhyād asmin āpi yogaṁ upārjaya
verse36.explanation: Arjuna acknowledges that controlling the mind is as challenging as controlling the wind. Krishna acknowledges this difficulty but emphasizes that with persistent practice and effort in yoga, one can manage to control the mind. This verse highlights the importance of consistent and determined practice in achieving mental discipline and control.
verse36.sanskrit: अथ चित्तं मनो वायुः तस्माद् द्ध्यायते रिव | विवृद्ध्यादस्मिनं अपि योगप्रणीयते ||

verse37.english: ārūḍhāśh che mātrāṁ prāpyaḥ bhayena prāpyaṁ vṛiddhyā
verse37.explanation: Arjuna expresses concern that without proper control, the restless mind may lead to a lower state of being or regression. However, Krishna reassures that even if the mind does not achieve full control initially, persistent effort in yoga can still lead to significant progress and eventual perfection. This verse underscores the importance of continual practice and dedication, acknowledging that while the path may be challenging, perseverance can lead to spiritual advancement and achievement.
verse37.sanskrit: अर्थश्चे च मात्रश्च सत्त्वतामविपद्धति | वायुः च मृतनादृत्यायोगास्मान्या: ||

verse38.english: aprapya yoga-siddhiṁ prāpya cāpa-yāḥ śāntiṁ māyāṁ āpnoti sāṁnyāya paṁṭhānāmā apīṇaṁ
verse38.explanation: Arjuna questions the fate of a person who practices yoga sincerely but has not yet achieved complete success. Krishna acknowledges this concern, emphasizing that even if one does not reach full perfection, the effort is never wasted. Such a person gains spiritual merit and progresses toward future success. This verse reassures that persistent effort in yoga, even if incomplete, leads to positive spiritual advancement and prepares one for future growth.
verse38.sanskrit: अप्राप्तः शान्तमाप्नोति सान्तमाप्त्वा सद्भ्यः | शान्ति मयावशान पापनमत्यन्तमात्र्यः ||

verse39.english: āyur-vedaṁ asattvaṁ tat karmaiva niḥsṛtam asti kim iti vinandati tvam eva pārtha
verse39.explanation: Arjuna inquires about the fate of those who sincerely practice yoga but do not achieve complete success. He is concerned about the spiritual outcome for such individuals and seeks to understand how their efforts impact their future. Krishna’s response will address these concerns, reassuring Arjuna about the positive results of sincere practice, even if perfection is not immediately attained.
verse39.sanskrit: आयुर्वेदमसद्धि चन्त्रितस्तु कर्मैव | अस्ति किमतिविनन्दत त्वमेव पार्थ ||

verse40.english: na hi deha-bhr̥tā śhakyaṁ tyaktuṁ karmāṇy aśheṣhataḥ yas tu karma-phala-tyāgī sa tasyāṁ sukhena bhavati
verse40.explanation: Krishna explains that it is impossible for a person with a physical body to fully renounce all actions, as some form of action is always necessary. However, true peace and contentment come from renouncing the desire for the results of one's actions. By practicing detachment from the outcomes, one achieves inner tranquility and spiritual satisfaction. This verse highlights the importance of focusing on the action itself rather than being attached to the results.
verse40.sanskrit: न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः | यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स तस्याऽऽचितः सुखम् ||

verse41.english: prāptakarmaṇyam aste punar āpnoti tatra tatra na hi deha-bhr̥tā karma kaśhcid alpa-siddhyet
verse41.explanation: Krishna reassures Arjuna that even if a person does not achieve complete success in their current lifetime, their efforts are not lost. Such individuals are reborn in favorable circumstances, such as in the family of enlightened or virtuous people. This favorable rebirth provides them with the opportunity to continue their spiritual journey and progress further. The verse emphasizes the enduring benefits of sincere practice and the assurance of continued spiritual growth.
verse41.sanskrit: प्राप्तकर्मण्यमस्ते पुनराप्नोति तत्र तत्र | न हि देहभृता कर्म कश्चिदलप्नसिद्ध्येत् ||

verse42.english: tatra tāṁ buddhi-yogaṁ tu prāpnoti tad nālpaṇam sa tu karma-phala-tyāgī tvarīyaḥ syānti kumat-kramam
verse42.explanation: Krishna explains that the soul reborn with past spiritual practice will continue to advance in their practice of yoga. The previous efforts are not wasted; instead, they lead to a deeper understanding and renewed dedication. This ongoing practice, based on past wisdom, will ultimately lead to success and realization. The verse reassures that even incomplete efforts have significant value and contribute positively to one’s spiritual path.
verse42.sanskrit: तत्र तं बुद्धियोगं तु प्राप्नोति तद् नाल्पनम् | स तु कर्मफलत्यागी त्वर्यः स्यान्ति कुमत्क्रमम् ||

verse43.english: prāptakarmaṇyam aste punar āpnoti tatra tatra na hi deha-bhr̥tā karma kaśhcid alpa-siddhyet
verse43.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that even if a yogi has not reached complete success in their practice, their efforts are not in vain. Instead, they are reborn in circumstances that are conducive to their continued spiritual development, such as in a family of righteous or spiritually advanced individuals. This favorable rebirth enables them to continue their spiritual journey with greater ease and support, ensuring that their previous efforts contribute positively to their future progress.
verse43.sanskrit: प्राप्तकर्मण्यमस्ते पुनराप्नोति तत्र तत्र | न हि देहभृता कर्म कश्चिदलप्नसिद्ध्येत् ||

verse44.english: prāptakarmaṇyam aste punar āpnoti tatra tatra na hi deha-bhr̥tā karma kaśhcid alpa-siddhyet
verse44.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that even if a yogi has not reached complete success in their practice, their efforts are not in vain. Instead, they are reborn in circumstances that are conducive to their continued spiritual development, such as in a family of righteous or spiritually advanced individuals. This favorable rebirth enables them to continue their spiritual journey with greater ease and support, ensuring that their previous efforts contribute positively to their future progress.
verse44.sanskrit: प्राप्तकर्मण्यमस्ते पुनराप्नोति तत्र तत्र | न हि देहभृता कर्म कश्चिदलप्नसिद्ध्येत् ||

verse45.english: prāptasya puṇya-pāpeyaṁ yogam āyogataḥ sacchascha tu svadharmena svadharmo ’pi kumāt-kramam
verse45.explanation: Krishna assures that the spiritual progress made through yoga is never lost. Even if a person does not attain perfection, their past efforts and merits will ensure that they are reborn into favorable conditions—such as a pious or enlightened family—where they can continue their spiritual journey. This verse emphasizes that the practice of yoga creates a lasting impact, allowing individuals to build on their previous progress and move forward in their spiritual evolution.
verse45.sanskrit: प्राप्तस्य पुण्यपापेयं योगमायोगत: | सच्चश्च तु स्वधर्मेन स्वधर्मोऽपि कुमात्क्रमम् ||

verse46.english: tapasvibhyo ’dhikāḥ yogī jñānibhyo ’pi mato ’dhikāḥ karmibhyo ’pi cha yogī tasmād yogī bhavārjuna
verse46.explanation: Krishna explains that among those who engage in spiritual practices, the yogi—one who practices meditation and self-realization—is superior. This superiority extends beyond those who engage in physical austerities, those who possess knowledge, and those who perform various actions. The yogi, due to their focused and disciplined practice, is considered the highest and most advanced in spiritual development. This verse highlights the esteemed position of the yogi and encourages Arjuna to recognize and strive for this elevated state.
verse46.sanskrit: तपस्विभ्योऽधिकः योगी ज्ञानिभ्योऽपि मतोऽधिकः | कर्मिभ्योऽपि च योगी तस्माद्योगी भवार्जुन ||

verse47.english: yoginām api sarveṣhām mad-gatena antar-ātmanā sad-bhāvaṁ yogī yuktāraḥ tasmāt tat-samām iyuktam
verse47.explanation: Krishna concludes the chapter by affirming that among all practitioners of yoga, those who cultivate unwavering devotion to the divine and recognize the divine presence within themselves are the most elevated. This inner realization and steadfast devotion are what make a yogi supreme. The verse highlights the significance of inner connection and devotion in achieving the highest state of yoga and spiritual unity.
verse47.sanskrit: योगिनामपि सर्वेषां मद्गतेनान्तरात्मना | सद्धवमति योक्तारस्तस्मात्तत्सममिव युक्तम् ||

verse1.english: saṁjñānam ātmanaṁ jñeyam ātmānaṁ tu māyā-śhramam sarvaśhaḥ pravṛttiṁ cha yaḥ yo ’pi śrotum aścha gahaḥ
verse1.explanation: Krishna declares that he will explain the highest knowledge, which encompasses both the ultimate reality and the means to transcend worldly illusions.
verse1.sanskrit: सर्वज्ञन्यत्मन: ज्ञेयम् आत्मानं तु मायाश्रमम् | सर्वशः प्रवृत्ति च य: योऽपि श्रोतुमश्च गहः ||

verse2.english: jñānaṁ vijñāna-sahitaṁ yad ajñānaṁ tu mayi śītam mayā ’dattam japaty anyas chāstra-yonam uttamam
verse2.explanation: Knowledge and wisdom that come directly from me, which are superior to all other forms of knowledge, are the means to understand the ultimate truth.
verse2.sanskrit: ज्ञानं विज्ञानसहितं यदज्ज्ञानं तु मयि शीतम् | मयाऽऽदत्तं जपत्यन्यः शास्त्रयोनमुत्तमम् ||

verse3.english: sarva-bhūtāni paśhyanti yaḥ paśhyati harim yat tat sarva-dṛṣṭaṁ me tasmin ātmani śāśvatām
verse3.explanation: He who sees the divine presence in all beings and perceives all that exists as a part of this divine essence, achieves eternal realization.
verse3.sanskrit: सर्वभूतानि पश्यन्ति यः पश्यति हरिम् | यत्तत्सर्वदृष्टं मे तस्मिन्हात्मनि शाश्वताम् ||

verse4.english: mad-brahma yathā karma yo yo ’pi kṛitaṁ karmāṇi sarvaśhaḥ satya-vittamaṁ tasyānanta-maṇo ’kṛitam
verse4.explanation: Whatever actions are performed in the light of divine understanding, they are considered eternal and pure.
verse4.sanskrit: मद्ब्रह्म यथा कर्म यो योऽपि कृतं कर्माणि | सर्वशः सत्यवित्तमं तस्यानन्तमणोऽकृतम् ||

verse5.english: vināśhāya cha paśhyanti yadā brahma saṁsṛṣṭutam yathā-śhṛiṇo ’trādānyo somāpyaḥ śvāsāv asyaḥ
verse5.explanation: Krishna explains that the divine energy, or the ultimate reality, is not easily perceived by ordinary beings. It is the force behind both creation and destruction, and its workings are subtle and pervasive. This energy operates beyond the grasp of ordinary understanding, highlighting the complexity and profound nature of divine influence in the cosmos.
verse5.sanskrit: विनाशाय च पश्यन्ति यदा ब्रह्म सवस्तुतम् | यथाशृणोत्रदेहान्यः सोमाप्यः श्वासोऽवश्येत ||

verse6.english: na hi deha-bhr̥tā śhakyaṁ tyaktuṁ karmāṇy aśheṣhataḥ yas tu karma-phala-tyāgī sa tasyāṁ sukhena bhavati
verse6.explanation: Krishna acknowledges that while it is impossible for an embodied being to completely abandon all forms of action, it is possible to attain peace by renouncing attachment to the outcomes of those actions. By focusing on the action itself and relinquishing desire for specific results, one can achieve a state of inner tranquility and fulfillment. This verse underscores the importance of detachment and the right attitude towards actions in the pursuit of spiritual well-being.
verse6.sanskrit: न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स तस्याऽऽचितः सुखम्||

verse7.english: mayy āsaktam aśaktāni saṁsāreṣhu rīyate tavācārāt paramātma balapreritaṁ jīvitam
verse7.explanation: Krishna explains that while the Supreme Soul (Paramatma) is beyond attachment and not influenced by worldly affairs, it exerts an underlying influence on the material world. For individuals bound by material desires and attachments, the cycle of existence continues. However, by recognizing the divine presence and understanding its role in all actions, one can transcend worldly limitations and attain liberation. This verse highlights the contrast between the divine detachment and human attachment and the path to overcoming it.
verse7.sanskrit: मय्याशक्तमशक्तानि संसारेषु रीयते तवाचरात् परमात्मा बलप्रेरितं जीवितम् ||

verse8.english: raso ’ham apsu kaunteya pravaśhmi tad anantam tad anantam advayaṁ nityam pravaśhmi tasmin ye
verse8.explanation: Krishna reveals that he is the essence behind various aspects of the material world and spiritual knowledge. He is the taste in water, symbolizing his presence in every element of nature. He is also the light in celestial bodies, the sacred syllable ‘OM’ in the Vedas, and the sound in the ether, representing his pervasiveness. By identifying himself with these fundamental aspects of existence, Krishna emphasizes that the divine is inherent in all things and all experiences.
verse8.sanskrit: रसोऽहमप्सु कौंतेय प्रवास्मि तदनन्तम तदनन्तमद्वयं नित्यम् प्रवस्मि तस्मिन्ये ||

verse9.english: padārthaṁ yaścha taṁ bandham saṅgād yaḥ puruṣarṣabhaḥ na hi deha-bhr̥tā śhakyaṁ tyaktuṁ karmāṇy aśheṣhataḥ
verse9.explanation: Krishna continues to describe his divine essence in various forms. He is the fragrance in the earth, the heat that drives fire, and the life force present in all living beings. By embodying these fundamental elements and forces, Krishna illustrates how his divine presence permeates every aspect of existence. This verse reinforces the idea that the divine is integral to the fabric of reality, manifesting through essential qualities and functions in the world.
verse9.sanskrit: पदार्थं यश्च तं बन्धं सङ्गाद्यः पुरुषर्षभः न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः ||

verse10.english: buddhir jñānam asaktiḥ samāhitaṁ ātmanaḥ vivekaṁ asaktasya yaḥ sattva-sarga-saṁsthitah
verse10.explanation: Krishna reveals that he is the source of various qualities that characterize wisdom and spiritual growth. He is the understanding in the wise, the wisdom that guides the disciplined, and the detachment that defines the renunciates. By being the essence of knowledge and the foundation of all actions, Krishna emphasizes that all intellectual and spiritual virtues ultimately derive from the divine. This verse illustrates how the divine manifests in the highest aspects of human qualities and endeavors.

verse11.english: viryaṁ śākṣam tu pāṇḍavaḥ puṇyo ’smi nipuṇas tataḥ adhīyantu tu pāṇḍavaḥ satsu premṇāṁ vidhāsi yaḥ
verse11.explanation: Krishna states that he is the inherent strength in all forms of power and the purity in all virtuous acts. He embodies the essence of all noble qualities and virtues. This divine presence is evident in acts of strength, purity, and devotion. By emphasizing his role in these aspects, Krishna highlights that all positive qualities and powers are manifestations of the divine essence. This verse reinforces the idea that the divine is present in the most fundamental and virtuous aspects of existence.
verse11.sanskrit: वीर्यं शाक्षं तु पाण्डवः पुण्योऽस्मि निपुणस्ततः अधीयन्तु तु पाण्डवः सत्सु प्रेम्णां विधासि यः ||

verse12.english: yasmin paśhyati sarveṣhāṁ sarvaṁ tasya subhāvaḥ sarvajño ’smi nipuṇas tasya svātmani mano ’vasthitam
verse12.explanation: Krishna explains that he is the fundamental divine principle that underlies and pervades all creation. He is the essence that binds the universe together and is the source of all knowledge and wisdom. By existing in the hearts of all beings, Krishna emphasizes his omnipresence and the deep connection between the divine and every aspect of existence. This verse highlights the divine’s integral role in sustaining and guiding all creation.
verse12.sanskrit: यस्मिन पश्यति सर्वेषां सर्वं तस्य सुभावः सर्वज्ञोऽस्मि निपुणस्तस्य स्वात्मनि मनोऽवस्थितम् ||

verse13.english: dvā vimau ’smin samaḥ samaḥ prakṛtir iyaṁ dvivibhaḥ ucito ’smin savaṅgalāḥ sarvasmin svamaṇāt param
verse13.explanation: Krishna points out that human beings are often deluded by the dualities of nature, such as pleasure and pain, success and failure. These dualities create confusion and attachment, causing individuals to stray from the path of true understanding and spiritual liberation. Krishna highlights the importance of recognizing and transcending these dualities to achieve a deeper insight into the nature of reality and to attain liberation.
verse13.sanskrit: द्वाविमोऽस्मिन्समः समः प्रकृतिरियं द्विविभः उचितोऽस्मिन्सवमङ्गलाः सर्वस्मिन्स्वमणात् परम् ||

verse14.english: daivī hyeṣhā guṇamayī mama māyā duratyayā māmeva ye prapadyante māyām etāṁ taranti te
verse14.explanation: Krishna explains that the material world is governed by the divine illusion (māyā) which is made up of the three fundamental modes of nature: goodness (sattva), passion (rajas), and ignorance (tamas). This illusion is very difficult to surpass. However, those who take refuge in Him, surrendering to His divine will, can transcend this illusion and overcome the constraints of material existence. This verse emphasizes the importance of divine grace and surrender in transcending the limitations imposed by material nature.
verse14.sanskrit: दैवी ह्येषा गुणमयी मम मायाऽध्रुर्विणा मामेव ये प्रपद्यन्ते मायामेतां तरन्ति ते

verse15.english: na māsaṁ bandhate pāpam jñānamṛtyuḥ kṛitaṁ sadā mama tadyānti jñānam pāraṁ pāra-siddhim
verse15.explanation: Krishna explains that individuals who are unaware of spiritual wisdom and remain entangled in ignorance are bound by the cycle of birth and death. They continue to experience the cycle of suffering and rebirth. In contrast, those who seek and attain true knowledge and divine wisdom can transcend this cycle and achieve liberation. This verse highlights the importance of seeking spiritual knowledge and understanding to overcome the limitations of material existence and achieve spiritual freedom.
verse15.sanskrit: न मासं बन्धते पापम् जन्ममृत्युः कृतं सदा मम तद्यान्ति ज्ञानम् पारं पारसिद्धिम्

verse16.english: chattvāri vidyāyajñānaṁ śreyo ’smin paraṁ yathā bhaṅktimayāyaḥ sarvān sarvajñaiḥ svāminaḥ kṣhitiḥ
verse16.explanation: Krishna categorizes the four types of people who seek divine connection: those who are distressed and seek relief, those who seek knowledge, those who desire material gains, and those who are wise and seek the divine for spiritual understanding. Krishna points out that the wise, who approach Him with true understanding and devotion, are the most exalted among these seekers. This verse highlights the superior nature of seeking divine connection through wisdom and self-realization over mere material or temporary needs.
verse16.sanskrit: चत्वारि विद्यायज्ञानं श्रेयोऽस्मिन्परं यथा भक्तिमयायाः सर्वान् सर्वज्ञैः स्वामिनः क्षितिः

verse17.english: udārāḥ sarve ’pi yānti māma mastakṛto na hi suprāṇasahitāḥ yogāt sāttvikaḥ syād vivekī
verse17.explanation: Krishna highlights that those who possess noble qualities and are devoted to Him, seeking the path of spiritual wisdom and practice, attain a higher state of understanding. Such individuals, who approach the divine with purity and discernment, achieve a deeper realization and spiritual fulfillment. Krishna underscores the importance of sincerity, discernment, and devotion in attaining true spiritual knowledge and connection
verse17.sanskrit: उदाराः सर्वेऽपि यान्ति माममस्तकृतो न हि सुप्राणसहितो योगात् सात्त्विकः स्याद् विवेकिनः

verse18.english: viddhi ātmānaṁ sva-karma vivekino ’pi sattvam bandha-nirvṛtti sarva-jña partha-sattvam upāstati
verse18.explanation: Krishna explains that among various seekers, the wise are those who understand their true self and live in alignment with their nature. Such individuals act with wisdom and are not bound by material constraints. They achieve liberation by transcending the limitations of material existence and gaining true knowledge and understanding. This verse emphasizes the importance of self-awareness and acting in harmony with one's true nature to attain spiritual freedom.
verse18.sanskrit: विद्धि आत्मानं स्वकर्म विवेकिनोऽपि सत्त्वम बन्धनिर्वृत्ति सर्वज्ञ पार्थसत्त्वमुपास्तते

verse19.english: vijñāna-yoga-niṣhṇātaḥ sadā sarva-bhūtātma-bhūtamaḥ tapasvibhyo ’dhikaḥ so ’dhātuḥ sarvaśhvaṁ samṛicchati
verse19.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that a person who has mastered the yoga of knowledge and understands the divine essence within all beings is superior to those who engage in mere physical austerities. This individual has attained the highest level of spiritual realization and wisdom. Krishna underscores the superiority of profound understanding and self-realization over superficial or ritualistic practices, highlighting the importance of true spiritual insight in achieving ultimate enlightenment.
verse19.sanskrit: विज्ञानयोगनिष्णातः सदा सर्वभूतात्मभूतमः तपस्विभ्योऽधिकः सोऽधातुः सर्वश्वं समृच्छति

verse20.english: avijñāyām ajñānāya sādho ’dharmāḥ prapadyate na hi sattva-pravṛttena sattva-siddhiḥ prapadyate
verse20.explanation: Krishna explains that individuals who are ignorant and lack understanding of the divine truth are prone to perform actions that are contrary to righteousness. Simply engaging in material virtues or practices without a deep understanding of spiritual wisdom will not lead to true realization. This verse highlights the importance of genuine knowledge and understanding in achieving spiritual progress, rather than relying solely on superficial or external actions.
verse20.sanskrit: अविज्ञायाम् अज्ञानाय साधोऽधर्माः प्रपद्यते न हि सत्त्वप्रवृत्तेन सत्त्वसिद्धिः प्रपद्यते

verse21.english: yaḥ śāstra-vidhim uktasya dharma-sya nityam anyathaḥ siddhau na viditvā na anyathaḥ na cha duḥkham uttamaḥ
verse21.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the importance of adhering to scriptural guidelines and the path of righteousness. Deviating from these principles and not striving for perfection as outlined in the scriptures leads to a lack of true understanding and continued suffering. Krishna underscores that following the scriptural path is essential for achieving spiritual growth and liberation.
verse21.sanskrit: यः शास्त्रविधिमुक्तस्य धर्मस्य नित्यमन्यथः सिद्धौ न विदित्वा न अन्यथ न च दुःखमुत्तमः

verse22.english: icchā-dveṣa-samohena sarvātmanā mama-ātmanā sarva-rūpā ātmano vidyān sama-vāyanaṁ param
verse22.explanation: Krishna explains that people who are influenced by desires, aversions, and delusions, and who do not perceive the divine essence in every being, remain bound by the material world. Their attachment to worldly things prevents them from attaining the highest spiritual realization and liberation. This verse underscores the need to overcome personal biases and illusions to perceive the divine truth and achieve spiritual liberation.
verse22.sanskrit: इच्छाद्वेषस्यमोहेन सर्वात्मानं ममात्मना सर्वरूपा आत्मनो विद्यान् समवायनं परम्

verse23.english: antavat tu phalaṁ teṣhām duḥkhalayam aśāśvatam na tasmin manyate bhakto meḍhyāya karma-bhir vinā
verse23.explanation: Krishna explains that the outcomes of actions driven by desire and ego are fleeting and lead to suffering. Those who do not surrender to Him and rely solely on their own efforts will not attain lasting happiness or spiritual fulfillment. This verse highlights the importance of divine devotion for achieving true and enduring contentment.
verse23.sanskrit: अन्तवत्तु फलं तेषां दुःखालयमशाश्वतम् न तस्मिन्मन्यते भक्तो मेध्याय कर्मभिर्विना

verse24.english: na haṁkāra-maṇī hanti karmashakti jātaḥ dharma-arthaṁ tu yoktavyaṁ vedānta-siddhiṁ yathā
verse24.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that understanding the Divine cannot be achieved through intellectual reasoning or actions alone. True realization comes from aligning with spiritual principles and self-realization as outlined in the Vedanta. This verse highlights that deep spiritual knowledge and practice are necessary for understanding the Divine.
verse24.sanskrit: न हंकारमणी हन्ति कर्मशक्ति जातनः धर्मार्थं तु योक्तव्यं वेदान्तसिद्धिं यथा

verse25.english: na haṁkāra-maṇī nārthaṁ dharma-artho ’pi karmaṇi na haṁkāra-maṇī hanti avidyā karma-karmaṇi
verse25.explanation: Krishna explains that He remains hidden from those who are clouded by ignorance and do not recognize His divine nature. Such individuals fail to grasp the true meaning of their actions and spiritual practices. This verse highlights that divine realization requires overcoming ignorance and understanding the true essence of the divine and one's actions.
verse25.sanskrit: न हंकारमणी नार्थं धर्मार्थोऽपि कर्मणि न हंकारमणी हन्ति अविद्या कर्मकर्मणि

verse26.english: aham ātmā guḍākeśa na vādane sadā hanan vivekṣṭām akṛtajñāṁ yaḥ vedāntarāhito ’nayaḥ
verse26.explanation: Krishna reveals that He is the essence within all beings, but is not recognized by those who lack wisdom or fail to seek spiritual knowledge. Ignorance of the true nature of the self prevents individuals from perceiving the divine presence. This verse emphasizes that understanding and recognizing the divine require knowledge and wisdom beyond superficial understanding.
verse26.sanskrit: अहमात्मा गुडाकेश न वदने सदा हनन् विवृत्तामकृतज्ञां यः वेदान्तरहितोऽनयः

verse27.english: iti matvā tattvājñaiḥ sarveṣāṁ manasāṁ yathā sarva-maṅgalataḥ prāṇa sarva-jñāna-arthakaṁ hi tat
verse27.explanation: Krishna explains that those who understand the divine truth recognize it as the ultimate source of all knowledge and the highest purpose of life. For such individuals, this realization is seen as the key to all well-being and the culmination of spiritual efforts. This verse underscores the profound significance of recognizing the divine essence in achieving true spiritual fulfillment.
verse27.sanskrit: इति मत्वा तत्त्वज्ञैः सर्वेषां मनसां यथा सर्वमङ्गलतः प्राण सर्वज्ञानार्थकं हि तत्

verse28.english: jāta-samo ’nayaḥ sarvāṇi punar prāṇa-vijñānam sarva-jñātṛ-bhūtānām jnānaṁ yat tvaraṁ tadā
verse28.explanation: Krishna states that those who have achieved true spiritual knowledge and have transcended material limitations view all beings with equal vision and are liberated from the cycle of rebirth. They have a deep understanding of the divine essence and the true nature of existence. This verse highlights the spiritual elevation and insight gained through the realization of the divine.
verse28.sanskrit: जातसमोऽनयः सर्वाणि पुनः प्राणविज्ञानम् सर्वज्ञातृभूतानां ज्ञानं यत्त्वरं तदा

verse29.english: vivekinaḥ surucayaḥ pāra-īśvara-mātmanāḥ sama-sattva-jñāḥ sādhu sarva-dharmo ’rtha-darśinaḥ
verse29.explanation: Krishna explains that individuals with true discrimination and understanding see the divine essence in all things and transcend material distinctions. They possess wisdom and virtue, recognizing the ultimate reality and understanding the essence of all righteous paths and truths. This verse emphasizes the depth of insight and clarity gained by those who have realized the divine truth.
verse29.sanskrit: विवेकिनः सुरुचयः पारमेश्वरमात्मनः समसत्त्वज्ञा साधू सर्वधर्मोऽर्थदर्शिनः

verse30.english: yaḥ śāstra-vidhim uktas sādā sarvaṁ dharmaṁ vimuchyati sarva-jñaḥ sādhu-rādadhāti sarva-vidnyāya dharmaḥ
verse30.explanation: Krishna explains that a person who faithfully adheres to scriptural principles, detaches from material duties, and embodies wisdom and virtue achieves comprehensive understanding and alignment with the ultimate truth. This verse highlights the importance of following divine guidance and spiritual principles to attain true righteousness and enlightenment.
verse30.sanskrit: यः शास्त्रविधिमुक्तः सदा सर्वं धर्मं विमुच्यति सर्वज्ञः साधुरादधाति सर्वविज्ञाय धर्मः

verse1.english: Arjuna Uvācha | Kiṁ Tad Brahma Kim Adhyātmaṁ Kiṁ Karma Puruṣhottama | Adhibhūtaṁ Cha Kiṁ Proktam Adhidaivaṁ Kimuchyate || 1 ||
verse1.explanation: Arjuna asks Krishna to explain the concepts of Brahman (the ultimate reality), the self, karma, the material world, and the divine.
verse1.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | किं तद्ब्रह्म किमध्यात्मं किं कर्म पुरुषोत्तम | अधिभूतं च किं प्रोक्तमधिदैवं किमुच्यते || 1 ||

verse2.english: Adhiyajñaḥ Kathaṁ Ko’tra Dehe’smin Madhusūdana | Prayāṇa-kāle Cha Kathaṁ Jñeyo’si Niyatātmabhiḥ || 2 ||
verse2.explanation: Arjuna inquires further about the concept of the Lord of sacrifice and how one can realize Krishna at the time of death.
verse2.sanskrit: अधियज्ञः कथं कोऽत्र देहेऽस्मिन्मधुसूदन | प्रयाणकाले च कथं ज्ञेयोऽसि नियतात्मभिः || 2 ||

verse3.english: Śhrī Bhagavānuvācha | Akṣharaṁ Brahma Paramaṁ Svabhāvo’dhyātmamuchyate | Bhūta-bhāvodbhava-karo Visargaḥ Karma-saṁjñitaḥ || 3 ||
verse3.explanation: Krishna answers that Brahman is the imperishable reality, the self is one’s own nature, and karma is the creative force responsible for the existence of all beings.
verse3.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | अक्षरं ब्रह्म परमं स्वभावोऽध्यात्ममुच्यते | भूतभावोद्भवकरो विसर्गः कर्मसंज्ञितः || 3 ||

verse4.english: Adhibhūtaṁ Kṣharo Bhāvaḥ Puruṣhaśh Chādhidaivatam | Adhiyajño’ham Evātra Dehe Deha-bhṛitāṁ Vara || 4 ||
verse4.explanation: Krishna explains that the material world is perishable, the cosmic being represents the divine, and He Himself is the Lord of sacrifice within the body.
verse4.sanskrit: अधिभूतं क्षरो भावः पुरुषश्चाधिदैवतम् | अधियज्ञोऽहमेवात्र देहे देहभृतां वर || 4 ||

verse5.english: Anta-kāle Cha Mām Eva Smaran Muktvā Kalevaram | Yaḥ Prayāti Sa Mad-bhāvaṁ Yāti Nāstyatra Sanśhayaḥ || 5 ||
verse5.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the importance of remembering Him at the time of death, which ensures that the soul attains union with the divine.
verse5.sanskrit: अन्तकाले च मामेव स्मरन्मुक्त्वा कलेवरम् | यः प्रयाति स मद्भावं याति नास्त्यत्र संशयः || 5 ||

verse6.english: Yaṁ Yaṁ Vā’pi Smaran Bhāvaṁ Tyajatyante Kalevaram | Taṁ Tamevaiti Kaunteya Sadā Tad-bhāva-bhāvitaḥ || 6 ||
verse6.explanation: Krishna explains that the final thoughts at the time of death determine one's next state of existence. Hence, it is important to keep one's mind focused on the divine and engage in spiritual practices throughout life to ensure a favorable transition at the end. This verse underscores the significance of constant devotion and remembrance of the divine in achieving spiritual goals and favorable outcomes beyond this life.
verse6.sanskrit: यं यं वाऽपि स्मरन्भावं त्यजत्यन्ते कलेवरम् | तं तमेवैति कौन्तेय सदा तद्भावभावितः || 6 ||

verse7.english: Tasmāt Sarveṣhu Kāleṣhu Mām Anusmara Yudhya Cha | Mayyarpita-mano-buddhir Māmevaiṣhyasyasaṁśhayaṁ || 7 ||
verse7.explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to constantly remember Him and perform his duty (fight), assuring that this dedication will lead to union with the divine.
verse7.sanskrit: तस्मात्सर्वेषु कालेषु मामनुस्मर युध्य च | मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्मामेवैष्यस्यसंशयम् || 7 ||

verse8.english: Abhyāsa-yoga-yuktena Chetasā Nānya-gāminā | Paramaṁ Puruṣhaṁ Divyaṁ Yāti Pārthānuchintayan || 8 ||
verse8.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the importance of consistent spiritual practice (abhyasa) and focused meditation on the Supreme Being to attain divine union.
verse8.sanskrit: अभ्यासयोगयुक्तेन चेतसा नान्यगामिना | परमं पुरुषं दिव्यं याति पार्थानुचिन्तयन् || 8 ||

verse9.english: Kaviṁ Purāṇam Anuśhāsitāram Aṇoraṇīyāṁsamanusmared Yaḥ | Sarvasya Dhātāram Achintya-rūpam Āditya-varṇaṁ Tamasaḥ Parastāt || 9 ||
verse9.explanation: Krishna describes the qualities of the Supreme Being, emphasizing His omniscience, antiquity, subtlety, and transcendence, encouraging meditation on these divine attributes.
verse9.sanskrit: कविं पुराणमनुशासितारमणोरणीयांसमनुस्मरेद्यः | सर्वस्य धातारमचिन्त्यरूपमादित्यवर्णं तमसः परस्तात् || 9 ||

verse10.english: Prayāṇa-kāle Manasā’chalena Bhaktyā Yukto Yoga-balena Chaiva | Bhruvor Madhye Prāṇam Āveśhya Samyak Sa Taṁ Paraṁ Puruṣham Upaiti Divyam || 10 ||
verse10.explanation: Krishna explains that by focusing the mind, breathing, and devotion at the time of death, one can reach the divine presence.
verse10.sanskrit: प्रयाणकाले मनसाऽचलेन भक्त्या युक्तो योगबलेन चैव | भ्रुवोर्मध्ये प्राणमावेश्य सम्यक् स तं परं पुरुषमुपैति दिव्यम् || 10 ||

verse11.english: Yadakṣharaṁ Vedavido Vadanti Viśhanti Yadyatayo Vīta-rāgāḥ | Yadicchhanto Brahmacharyaṁ Charanti Tatte Padaṁ Saṅgraheṇa Pravakṣhye || 11 ||
verse11.explanation: Krishna speaks of the imperishable goal of spiritual seekers, attained through self-discipline, detachment, and dedicated practice.
verse11.sanskrit: यदक्षरं वेदविदो वदन्ति विशन्ति यद्यतयो वीतरागाः | यदिच्छन्तो ब्रह्मचर्यं चरन्ति तत्ते पदं सङ्ग्रहेण प्रवक्ष्ये || 11 ||

verse12.english: Sarva-dvārāṇi Saṁyamya Mano Hṛidi Nirudhya Cha | Mūrdhnyādhāyātmanaḥ Prāṇam Āsthito Yoga-dhāraṇām || 12 ||
verse12.explanation: Krishna describes the process of controlling the senses, focusing the mind, and practicing breath control as part of the yogic path to attain the divine.
verse12.sanskrit: सर्वद्वाराणि संयम्य मनो हृदि निरुध्य च | मूर्ध्न्याधायात्मनः प्राणमास्थितो योगधारणाम् || 12 ||

verse13.english: Omityekākṣharaṁ Brahma Vyāharan Mām Anusmaran | Yaḥ Prayāti Tyajan Dehaṁ Sa Yāti Paramāṁ Gatim || 13 ||
verse13.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the power of chanting "Om" and remembering Him at the time of death as the key to reaching the highest spiritual destination.
verse13.sanskrit:
ओमित्येकाक्षरं ब्रह्म व्याहरन्मामनुस्मरन् |
