यः प्रयाति त्यजन्देहं स याति परमां गतिम् || 13 ||

verse14.english: Ananya-chetāḥ Satataṁ Yo Māṁ Smarati Nityaśhaḥ | Tasyāhaṁ Sulabhaḥ Pārtha Nitya-yuktasya Yoginaḥ || 14 ||
verse14.explanation: Krishna reassures that those who are constantly devoted to Him, remembering Him without deviation, will find Him easily.
verse14.sanskrit: अनन्यचेताः सततं यो मां स्मरति नित्यशः | तस्याहं सुलभः पार्थ नित्ययुक्तस्य योगिनः || 14 ||

verse15.english: Māmupetya Punarjanma Duḥkhālayam Aśhāśhvatam | Nāpnuvanti Mahātmānaḥ Saṁsiddhiṁ Paramāṁ Gatāḥ || 15 ||
verse15.explanation: Krishna explains that those who attain union with Him do not return to the cycle of birth and death, thereby escaping the suffering inherent in worldly existence.
verse15.sanskrit: मामुपेत्य पुनर्जन्म दुःखालयमशाश्वतम् | नाप्नुवन्ति महात्मानः संसिद्धिं परमां गताः || 15 ||

verse16.english: Ābrahma-bhuvanāl Lokāḥ Punarāvartino’rjuna | Māmupetya Tu Kaunteya Punarjanma Na Vidyate || 16 ||
verse16.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that all realms, including the highest ones, are impermanent and subject to rebirth, except for those who reach the divine, who are freed from the cycle of reincarnation.
verse16.sanskrit: आब्रह्मभुवनाल्लोकाः पुनरावर्तिनोऽर्जुन | मामुपेत्य तु कौन्तेय पुनर्जन्म न विद्यते || 16 ||

verse17.english: Sahasra-yuga-paryantam Aharyad Brahmaṇo Viduḥ | Rātriṁ Yuga-sahasrāntāṁ Te’horātra-vido Janāḥ || 17 ||
verse17.explanation: Krishna explains the concept of cosmic time, where a single day of Brahma spans thousands of yugas (ages), emphasizing the vastness and impermanence of the universe.
verse17.sanskrit: सहस्रयुगपर्यन्तमहर्यद्ब्रह्मणो विदुः | रात्रिं युगसहस्रान्तां तेऽहोरात्रविदो जनाः || 17 ||

verse18.english: Avyakta-dvyaktayaḥ Sarvāḥ Prabhavantyaharāgame | Rātryāgame Pralīyante Tatraivāvyakta-saṁjñake || 18 ||
verse18.explanation: Krishna describes the cyclical nature of creation and dissolution, where all beings emerge from the unmanifest at the beginning of Brahma’s day and return to it at night.
verse18.sanskrit: अव्यक्ताद्व्यक्तयः सर्वाः प्रभवन्त्यहरागमे | रात्र्यागमे प्रलीयन्ते तत्रैवाव्यक्तसंज्ञके || 18 ||

verse19.english: Bhūta-grāmaḥ Sa Evāyaṁ Bhūtvā Bhūtvā Pralīyate | Rātryāgame’vaśhaḥ Pārtha Prabhavatyaharāgame || 19 ||
verse19.explanation: Krishna reiterates the continuous cycle of creation and destruction that all beings undergo, highlighting the inevitability of this process.
verse19.sanskrit:
भूतग्रामः स एवायं भूत्वा भूत्वा प्रलीयते |
रात्र्यागमेऽवशः पार्थ प्रभवत्यहरागमे || 19 ||

verse20.english: Paras Tasmāt Tu Bhāvo’nyo’vyakto’vyaktāt Sanātanaḥ | Yaḥ Sa Sarveṣhu Bhūteṣhu Naśhyatsu Na Vinaśhyati || 20 ||
verse20.explanation: Krishna speaks of the eternal, imperishable reality that exists beyond the cyclical nature of the manifest and unmanifest worlds, emphasizing the permanence of the spiritual realm.
verse20.sanskrit: परस्तस्मात्तु भावोऽन्योऽव्यक्तोऽव्यक्तात्सनातनः | यः स सर्वेषु भूतेषु नश्यत्सु न विनश्यति || 20 ||

verse21.english: Avyakto’kṣhara Ityuktas Tamāhuḥ Paramāṁ Gatim | Yaṁ Prāpya Na Nivartante Taddhāma Paramaṁ Mama || 21 ||
verse21.explanation: Krishna declares that the unmanifest, imperishable reality is the highest goal, and those who reach it are liberated from the cycle of rebirth, attaining His supreme abode.
verse21.sanskrit: अव्यक्तोऽक्षर इत्युक्तस्तमाहुः परमां गतिम् | यं प्राप्य न निवर्तन्ते तद्धाम परमं मम || 21 ||

verse22.english: Puruṣhaḥ Sa Paraḥ Pārtha Bhaktyā Labhyas Tv Ananyayā | Yasyāntaḥsthāni Bhūtāni Yena Sarvam Idaṁ Tatam || 22 ||
verse22.explanation: Krishna explains that the Supreme Being, who encompasses all existence, can be attained through unwavering devotion.
verse22.sanskrit: पुरुषः स परः पार्थ भक्त्या लभ्यस्त्वनन्यया | यस्यान्तःस्थानि भूतानि येन सर्वमिदं ततम् || 22 ||

verse23.english: Yatra Kāle Tvanāvṛittim Āvṛittiṁ Chaiva Yoginaḥ | Prayātā Yānti Taṁ Kālaṁ Vakṣhyāmi Bharatarṣhabha || 23 ||
verse23.explanation: Krishna indicates that the timing of one's departure from the world determines whether they return to the cycle of rebirth or attain liberation.
verse23.sanskrit: यत्र काले त्वनावृत्तिमावृत्तिं चैव योगिनः | प्रयाता यान्ति तं कालं वक्ष्यामि भरतर्षभ || 23 ||

verse24.english: Agnir Jyotir Ahaḥ Śhuklaḥ Ṣhaṇ-māsā Uttarāyaṇam | Tatra Prayātā Gachchhanti Brahma Brahmavido Janāḥ || 24 ||
verse24.explanation: Krishna explains that yogis who leave their bodies during auspicious times, associated with light and the northern course of the sun, attain Brahman and do not return to the cycle of rebirth.
verse24.sanskrit: अग्निर्ज्योतिरहः शुक्लः षण्मासा उत्तरायणम् | तत्र प्रयाता गच्छन्ति ब्रह्म ब्रह्मविदो जनाः || 24 ||

verse25.english: Dhūmo Rātris Tathā Kṛiṣhṇaḥ Ṣhaṇ-māsā Dakṣiṇāyanam | Tatra Chāndrama-saṁ Jyotir Yogī Prāpya Nivartate || 25 ||
verse25.explanation: Krishna describes how those who depart during less auspicious times, associated with darkness and the southern course of the sun, reach the lunar realm and return to the cycle of rebirth.
verse25.sanskrit: धूमो रात्रिस्तथा कृष्णः षण्मासा दक्षिणायनम् | तत्र चान्द्रमसं ज्योतिर्योगी प्राप्य निवर्तते || 25 ||

verse26.english: Śhukla-kṛiṣhṇe Gatī Hyete Jagataḥ Śhāśhvate Mate | Ekayā Yātyanāvṛittim Anyayāvartate Punaḥ || 26 ||
verse26.explanation: Krishna explains that the two eternal paths determine the fate of the soul after death—one leading to liberation and the other to rebirth.
verse26.sanskrit: शुक्लकृष्णे गती ह्येते जगतः शाश्वते मते | एकया यात्यनावृत्तिमन्ययावर्तते पुनः || 26 ||

verse27.english: Naite Sṛitī Pārtha Jānanyogī Muhyati Kaśchana | Tasmāt Sarveṣhu Kāleṣhu Yoga-yukto Bhavārjuna || 27 ||
verse27.explanation: Krishna urges Arjuna to remain always engaged in yoga, knowing the significance of the two paths and the ultimate outcomes they lead to.
verse27.sanskrit: नैते सृती पार्थ जानन्योगी मुह्यति कश्चन | तस्मात्सर्वेषु कालेषु योगयुक्तो भवार्जुन || 27 ||

verse28.english: Vedeṣhu Yajñeṣhu Tapaḥsu Chaiva Dāneṣhu Yat Puṇya-phalaṁ Pradiṣhṭam | Atyeti Tatsarvam Idaṁ Viditvā Yogī Paraṁ Sthānam Upaiti Chādyam || 28 ||
verse28.explanation: Krishna concludes that a yogi who understands the eternal truth surpasses all material rewards promised by the Vedas and other sacred practices, ultimately reaching the supreme, eternal state.
verse28.sanskrit: वेदेषु यज्ञेषु तपःसु चैव दानेषु यत्पुण्यफलं प्रदिष्टम् | अत्येति तत्सर्वमिदं विदित्वा योगी परं स्थानमुपैति चाद्यम् || 28 ||

verse1.english: Śhrī-bhagavān uvācha | Idaṁ Tu Te Guhyatamaṁ Pravakṣhyāmy Anasūyave | Jñānaṁ Vijñāna-sahitaṁ Yaj Jñātvā Mokṣhyase ’śhubhāt || 1 ||
verse1.explanation: Krishna begins by revealing that He will share the most profound and secret wisdom, which, when understood, can liberate one from the cycle of birth and death.
verse1.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | इदं तु ते गुह्यतमं प्रवक्ष्याम्यनसूयवे | ज्ञानं विज्ञानसहितं यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात् || 1 ||

verse2.english: Rāja-vidyā Rāja-guhyaṁ Pavitrām Idam Uttamam | Pratyakṣhāvagamaṁ Dharmyaṁ Su-sukhaṁ Kartum Avyayam || 2 ||
verse2.explanation: Krishna describes this knowledge as the most exalted, pure, and eternal, offering direct realization and immense joy.
verse2.sanskrit: राजविद्या राजगुह्यं पवित्रमिदमुत्तमम् | प्रत्यक्षावगमं धर्म्यं सुसुखं कर्तुमव्ययम् || 2 ||

verse3.english: Aśhraddadhānāḥ Puruṣhā Dharmasyāsya Paraṁtapa | Aprāpya Māṁ Nivartante Mṛityu-saṁsāra-vartmani || 3 ||
verse3.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that those who lack faith in this teaching will continue to be trapped in the cycle of birth and death, unable to reach Him.
verse3.sanskrit: अश्रद्दधानाः पुरुषा धर्मस्यास्य परंतप | अप्राप्य मां निवर्तन्ते मृत्युंसंसारवर्त्मनि || 3 ||

verse4.english: Mayā Tatam Idam Sarvaṁ Jagad Avyakta-mūrtinā | Mat-sthāni Sarva-bhūtāni Na Chāhaṁ Teṣhv Avasthitaḥ || 4 ||
verse4.explanation: Krishna explains that He pervades the entire universe in His unmanifested form, and although all beings are within Him, He remains distinct from them.
verse4.sanskrit: मया ततमिदं सर्वं जगदव्यक्तमूर्तिना | मत्स्थानि सर्वभूतानि न चाहं तेष्ववस्थितः || 4 ||

verse5.english: Na Cha Mat-sthāni Bhūtāni Paśhya Me Yogam Aiśhvaram | Bhūta-bhṛin Na Cha Bhūta-stho Mamātmā Bhūta-bhāvanaḥ || 5 ||
verse5.explanation: Krishna highlights His divine mystic power, explaining that although He supports all beings, He is independent and remains the source of everything.
verse5.sanskrit: न च मत्स्थानि भूतानि पश्य मे योगमैश्वरम् | भूतभृन्न च भूतस्थो ममात्मा भूतभावनः || 5 ||

verse6.english: Yathākāśha-sthito Nityaṁ Vāyuḥ Sarvatra-go Mahān | Tathā Sarvāṇi Bhūtāni Mat-sthānītyupadhāraya || 6 ||
verse6.explanation: Krishna compares the existence of all beings within Him to the wind, which moves everywhere but always rests within the sky.
verse6.sanskrit: यथाकाशस्थितो नित्यं वायुः सर्वत्रगो महान् | तथा सर्वाणि भूतानि मत्स्थानीत्युपधारय || 6 ||

verse7.english: Sarva-bhūtāni Kaunteya Prakṛitiṁ Yānti Māmikām | Kalpa-kṣhaye Punas Tāni Kalpādau Visṛijāmyaham || 7 ||
verse7.explanation: Krishna explains the cosmic cycle of creation and dissolution, where all beings merge into His nature at the end of each cycle and are recreated at the beginning of the next.
verse7.sanskrit: सर्वभूतानि कौन्तेय प्रकृतिं यान्ति मामिकाम् | कल्पक्षये पुनस्तानि कल्पादौ विसृजाम्यहम् || 7 ||

verse8.english: Prakṛitiṁ Svām Avaṣhṭabhya Visṛijāmi Punaḥ Punaḥ | Bhūta-grāmam Imaṁ Kṛitsnam Avaśhaṁ Prakṛiter Vaśhāt || 8 ||
verse8.explanation: Krishna asserts His control over the cosmic order, explaining that it is by His will that creation and dissolution occur repeatedly.
verse8.sanskrit: प्रकृतिं स्वामवष्टभ्य विसृजामि पुनः पुनः | भूतग्राममिमं कृत्स्नमवशं प्रकृतेर्वशात् || 8 ||

verse9.english: Na Cha Māṁ Tāni Karmāṇi Nibadhnanti Dhanañjaya | Udāsīna-vad Āsīnam Asaktaṁ Teṣhu Karmasu || 9 ||
verse9.explanation: Krishna clarifies that despite being the source of all activities in the universe, He remains unattached and unaffected by them.
verse9.sanskrit: न च मां तानि कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय | उदासीनवदासीनमसक्तं तेषु कर्मसु || 9 ||

verse10.english: Mayādhyakṣheṇa Prakṛitiḥ Sūyate Sa-charācharam | Hetunānena Kaunteya Jagad Viparivartate || 10 ||
verse10.explanation: Krishna explains that nature, under His supervision, brings forth all forms of life, and this is the basis of the cosmic order.
verse10.sanskrit: मयाध्यक्षेण प्रकृतिः सूयते सचराचरम् | हेतुनानेन कौन्तेय जगद्विपरिवर्तते || 10 ||

verse11.english: Avajānanti Māṁ Mūḍhā Mānuṣhīṁ Tanum Āśhritam | Paraṁ Bhāvam Ajānanto Mama Bhūta-maheśhvaram || 11 ||
verse11.explanation: Krishna laments that ignorant people fail to recognize His divine nature when He appears in human form, mistaking Him to be ordinary.
verse11.sanskrit: अवजानन्ति मां मूढा मानुषीं तनुमाश्रितम् | परं भावमजानन्तो मम भूतमहेश्वरम् || 11 ||

verse12.english: Moghāśhā Moghakarmāṇo Mogha-jñānā Vichetaṣaḥ | Rākṣhasīm Āsurīṁ Chaiva Prakṛitiṁ Mohinīṁ Śhritāḥ || 12 ||
verse12.explanation: Krishna explains that those who are deluded and influenced by demoniac qualities are doomed to failure in their spiritual and worldly endeavors.
verse12.sanskrit: मोग्हाशा मोग्हकर्माणो मोग्हज्ञाना विचेतसः | राक्षसीमासुरीं चैव प्रकृतिं मोहिनीं श्रिताः || 12 ||

verse13.english: Mahātmānas Tu Māṁ Pārtha Daivīṁ Prakṛitim Āśhritāḥ | Bhajanty Ananya-manaso Jñātvā Bhūtādim Avyayam || 13 ||
verse13.explanation: Krishna describes the great souls who, recognizing His divine nature, are fully devoted to Him and are under His divine protection.
verse13.sanskrit: महात्मानस्तु मां पार्थ दैवीं प्रकृतिमाश्रिताः | भजन्त्यनन्यमनसो ज्ञात्वा भूतादिमव्ययम् || 13 ||

verse14.english: Satataṁ Kīrtayanto Māṁ Yatantaśh Cha Dṛiḍha-vratāḥ | Namasyantaśh Cha Māṁ Bhaktyā Nitya-yuktā Upāsate || 14 ||
verse14.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that the great devotees are constantly engaged in chanting His glories and worshiping Him with unwavering devotion.
verse14.sanskrit: सततं कीर्तयन्तो मां यतन्तश्च दृढव्रताः | नमस्यन्तश्च मां भक्त्या नित्ययुक्ता उपासते || 14 ||

verse15.english: jñāna-yajñena cāpy anyam paṅgaty antar-vibhajya vartate sarva-karmāṇy asāmānyā saptadhe tat tu yat paṭhet
verse15.explanation: Krishna acknowledges that there are others who worship Him through the cultivation of knowledge, seeing Him in different forms or as the universal form.
verse15.sanskrit: ज्ञानयज्ञेन चाप्यन्ये यजन्तो मामुपासते | एकत्वेन पृथक्त्वेन बहुधा विश्वतोमुखम् || 15 ||

verse16.english: Ahaṁ Kratur Ahaṁ Yajñaḥ Svadha-aham Aham Auṣhadham | Mantro ’ham Aham Evājyam Aham Agnir Ahaṁ Hutam || 16 ||
verse16.explanation: Krishna declares that He is the essence of all rituals, sacrifices, and offerings, encompassing every aspect of spiritual practice.
verse16.sanskrit: अहं क्रतुरहं यज्ञः स्वधाहमहमौषधम् | मन्त्रोऽहमहमेवाज्यमहमग्निरहं हुतम् || 16 ||

verse17.english: Pitāham Asya Jagato Mātā Dhātā Pitāmahaḥ | Vedyam Pavitraṁ Oṁkāra Ṛik Sāma Yajur Eva Cha || 17 ||
verse17.explanation: Krishna describes Himself as the source of everything in the universe, the ultimate object of knowledge, and the essence of the Vedas.
verse17.sanskrit: पिताहमस्य जगतो माता धाता पितामहः | वेद्यं पवित्रमोंकार ऋक्साम यजुरेव च || 17 ||

verse18.english: Gatir Bhartā Prabhuḥ Sākṣhī Nivāsaḥ Śharaṇaṁ Suhṛit | Prabhavaḥ Pralayaḥ Sthānaṁ Nidhānaṁ Bījam Avyayam || 18 ||
verse18.explanation: Krishna explains His roles as the ultimate refuge, sustainer, and friend of all beings, as well as the eternal cause of creation and destruction.
verse18.sanskrit: गतिर्भर्ता प्रभुः साक्षी निवासः शरणं सुहृत् | प्रभवः प्रलयः स्थानं निधानं बीजमव्ययम् || 18 ||

verse19.english: Tapāmy Aham Ahaṁ Varṣhaṁ Nigṛihṇāmy Utsṛijāmi Cha | Amṛitaṁ Chaiva Mṛityuśh Cha Sadasacchāham Arjuna || 19 ||
verse19.explanation: Krishna asserts His control over natural forces like heat and rain, and identifies Himself as both the giver of life and the destroyer, encompassing both spirit and matter.
verse19.sanskrit: तपाम्यहमहं वर्षं निगृह्णम्युत्सृजामि च | अमृतं चैव मृत्युश्च सदसच्चाहमर्जुन || 19 ||

verse20.english: Trai-vidyā Māṁ Soma-pāḥ Pūta-pāpā Yajñair Iṣhṭvā Svarga-tim Prārthayante | Te Puṇyam Āsādya Surendra-lokam Aśhnanti Divyān Divi Deva-bhogān || 20 ||
verse20.explanation: Krishna describes how those who follow Vedic rituals and seek heavenly pleasures worship Him indirectly and are rewarded with temporary enjoyment in the heavenly realms.
verse20.sanskrit: त्रैविद्या मां सोमपाः पूतपापा यज्ञैरिष्ट्वा स्वर्गतिं प्रार्थयन्ते | ते पुण्यमासाद्य सुरेन्द्रलोक मश्नन्ति दिव्यान्दिवि देवभोगान् || 20 ||

verse21.english: Te Taṁ Bhuktvā Svarga-lokaṁ Viśhālaṁ Kṣhīṇe Puṇye Martya-lokaṁ Viśhanti | Evaṁ Trayi-dharmam Anu-prapannā Gatāgataṁ Kāma-kāmā Labhante || 21 ||
verse21.explanation: Krishna explains that after the merits of their pious actions are exhausted, those who seek material pleasures must return to the earthly realm, continuing the cycle of birth and death.
verse21.sanskrit: ते तं भुक्त्वा स्वर्गलोकं विशालं क्षीणे पुण्ये मर्त्यलोकं विशन्ति | एवं त्रयीधर्ममनुप्रपन्ना गतागतं कामकामा लभन्ते || 21 ||

verse22.english: Ananyāśh Chintayanto Māṁ Ye Janāḥ Paryupāsate | Teṣhāṁ Nityābhiyuktānāṁ Yoga-kṣhemaṁ Vahāmyaham || 22 ||
verse22.explanation: Krishna promises that for those who are devoted to Him and constantly think of Him, He personally takes care of their needs and ensures their welfare.
verse22.sanskrit: अनन्याश्चिन्तयन्तो मां ये जनाः पर्युपासते | तेषां नित्याभियुक्तानां योगक्षेमं वहाम्यहम् || 22 ||

verse23.english: Ye ’pyanya-devatā Bhaktā Yajante Shraddhayānvitāḥ | Te ’pi Mām Eva Kaunteya Yajanty Avidhi-pūrvakam || 23 ||
verse23.explanation: Krishna reveals that those who worship other deities with faith are, in fact, worshiping Him indirectly, but their method is incorrect.
verse23.sanskrit: येऽप्यन्यदेवता भक्ता यजन्ते श्रद्धयान्विताः | तेऽपि मामेव कौन्तेय यजन्त्यविधिपूर्वकम् || 23 ||

verse24.english: Ahaṁ Hi Sarva-yajñānāṁ Bhoktā Cha Prabhur Eva Cha | Na Tu Mām Abhijānanti Tattvenātaśh Chyavanti Te || 24 ||
verse24.explanation: Krishna asserts that He is the ultimate recipient of all sacrifices and worship, and those who fail to realize this fall short in their spiritual progress.
verse24.sanskrit: अहं हि सर्वयज्ञानां भोक्ता च प्रभुरेव च | न तु मामभिजानन्ति तत्वेनातश्च्यवन्ति ते || 24 ||

verse25.english: Yānti Deva-vratā Devān Pitṝīn Yānti Pitṛi-vratāḥ | Bhūtāni Yānti Bhūtejya Yānti Madyājino ’pi Mām || 25 ||
verse25.explanation: Krishna explains that people attain the destination that corresponds to the object of their worship. Those who worship Him attain eternal union with Him.
verse25.sanskrit: यान्ति देवव्रता देवान्पितॄन्यान्ति पितृव्रताः | भूतानि यान्ति भूतेज्या यान्ति मद्याजिनोऽपि माम् || 25 ||

verse26.english: Patraṁ Puṣhpaṁ Phalaṁ Toyaṁ Yo Me Bhaktyā Prayachchhati | Tad Ahaṁ Bhakty-upahṛitam Aśhnāmi Prayatātmanaḥ || 26 ||
verse26.explanation: Krishna assures that even a simple offering, when made with love and devotion, is accepted by Him.
verse26.sanskrit: पत्रं पुष्पं फलं तोयं यो मे भक्त्या प्रयच्छति | तदहं भक्त्युपहृतमश्नामि प्रयतात्मनः || 26 ||

verse27.english: Yat Karoṣi Yad Aśhnāsi Yaj Juhoṣhi Dadāsi Yat | Yat Tapasyasi Kaunteya Tat Kuruṣhva Mad-arpaṇam || 27 ||
verse27.explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to dedicate all his actions to Him, thereby turning every activity into a form of worship.
verse27.sanskrit: यत्करोषि यदश्नासि यज्जुहोषि ददासि यत् | यत्तपस्यसि कौन्तेय तत्कुरुष्व मदर्पणम् || 27 ||

verse28.english: Śhubhāśhubha-phalair Evaṁ Mokṣhyase Karma-bandhanaiḥ | Sannyāsa-yoga-yuktātmā Vimukto Mām Upaiṣhyasi || 28 ||
verse28.explanation: Krishna promises that by dedicating all actions to Him, one can be freed from the bondage of karma and attain liberation.
verse28.sanskrit: शुभाशुभफलैरेवं मोक्ष्यसे कर्मबन्धनैः | संन्यासयोगयुक्तात्मा विमुक्तो मामुपैष्यसि || 28 ||

verse29.english: Samo ’haṁ Sarva-bhūteṣhu Na Me Dveṣhyo ’sti Na Priyaḥ | Ye Bhajanti Tu Māṁ Bhaktyā Mayi Te Teṣhu Chāpyaham || 29 ||
verse29.explanation: Krishna declares His impartiality towards all beings, yet He affirms that those who are devoted to Him enjoy a special relationship with Him.
verse29.sanskrit: समोऽहं सर्वभूतेषु न मे द्वेष्योऽस्ति न प्रियः | ये भजन्ति तु मां भक्त्या मयि ते तेषु चाप्यहम् || 29 ||

verse30.english: Api Chetsu Durāchāro Bhajate Māmananya-bhāk | Sādhur Eva Sa Mantavyaḥ Samyag Vyavasito Hi Saḥ || 30 ||
verse30.explanation: Krishna assures that even those who have committed grave sins can be considered righteous if they are devoted to Him, as their devotion will gradually purify them.
verse30.sanskrit: अपि चेत्सुदुराचारो भजते मामनन्यभाक् | साधुरेव स मन्तव्यः सम्यग्व्यवसितो हि सः || 30 ||

verse31.english: Kṣhipraṁ Bhavati Dharmātmā Śhaśhvat-chhāntiṁ Nigachchhati | Kaunteya Pratijānīhi Na Me Bhaktaḥ Praṇaśhyati || 31 ||
verse31.explanation: Krishna promises that His devotee, even if initially flawed, will quickly attain righteousness and peace, and will never be lost.
verse31.sanskrit: क्षिप्रं भवति धर्मात्मा शश्वच्छान्तिं निगच्छति | कौन्तेय प्रतिजानीहि न मे भक्तः प्रणश्यति || 31 ||

verse32.english: Māṁ Hi Pārtha Vyapāśhritya Ye ’pi Syuḥ Pāpa-yonayaḥ | Striyo Vaiśhyās Tathā Śhūdrās Te ’pi Yānti Parāṁ Gatim || 32 ||
verse32.explanation: Krishna declares that anyone, regardless of birth or social status, who takes refuge in Him can attain the highest spiritual goal.
verse32.sanskrit: मां हि पार्थ व्यपाश्रित्य येऽपि स्युः पापयोनयः | स्त्रियो वैश्यास्तथा शूद्रास्तेऽपि यान्ति परां गतिम् || 32 ||

verse33.english: Kiṁ Punar Brāhmaṇāḥ Puṇyā Bhaktā Rājarsayas Tathā | Anityam Asukhaṁ Lokam Imaṁ Prāpya Bhajasva Mām || 33 ||
verse33.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that realizing the Supreme Self, who is the ultimate abode and source of all existence, is the highest form of knowledge. Those who are righteous and devoted to this Supreme Self are especially cherished. This verse underscores the importance of recognizing the divine presence and the supreme reality in spiritual practice.
verse33.sanskrit: किं पुनर्ब्राह्मणाः पुण्या भक्ता राजर्षयस्तथा | अनित्यमसुखं लोकमिमं प्राप्य भजस्व माम् || 33 ||

verse1.english: Śhrī-bhagavān uvācha | Bhūya eva Mahā-bāho Śhṛiṇu Me Paramaṁ Vachaḥ | Yat-te ’haṁ Prīyamāṇāya Vakṣhyāmi Hita-kāmyayā || 1 ||
verse1.explanation: Krishna begins by offering Arjuna the highest knowledge once more, indicating His deep concern for Arjuna's well-being.
verse1.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | भूय एव महाबाहो श्रृणु मे परमं वचः | यत्तेऽहं प्रीयमाणाय वक्ष्यामि हितकाम्यया || 1 ||

verse2.english: Na Me Vidur Suragaṇāḥ Prabhavaṁ Na Maharṣhayaḥ | Aham Ādir Hi Devānāṁ Maharṣhīṇāṁ Cha Sarvaśhaḥ || 2 ||
verse2.explanation: Krishna reveals that even the gods and great sages do not fully understand His divine origin, as He is the source of all creation.
verse2.sanskrit: न मे विदुः सुरगणाः प्रभवं न महर्षयः | अहमादिर्हि देवानां महर्षीणां च सर्वशः || 2 ||

verse3.english: Yo Mām Ajam Anādiṁ Cha Vetti Loka-maheśhvaram | Asammūḍhaḥ Sa Martyeṣhu Sarva-pāpaiḥ Pramuchyate || 3 ||
verse3.explanation: Krishna explains that understanding His eternal nature and supreme lordship leads to liberation from all sins.
verse3.sanskrit: यो मामजमनादिं च वेत्ति लोकमहेश्वरम् | असम्मूढः स मर्त्येषु सर्वपापैः प्रमुच्यते || 3 ||

verse4.english: Buddhir Jñānam Asammohaḥ Kṣhamā Satyaṁ Damaḥ Śhamaḥ | Sukhaṁ Duḥkhaṁ Bhavo ’bhāvo Bhayaṁ Chābhayam Eva Cha || 4 ||
verse4.explanation: Krishna lists the various qualities and states of mind that originate from Him, encompassing all aspects of human experience.
verse4.sanskrit: बुद्धिर्ज्ञानमसम्मोहः क्षमा सत्यं दमः शमः | सुखं दुःखं भवोऽभावो भयं चाभयमेव च || 4 ||

verse5.english: Ahinsā Samatā Tuṣhṭis Tapo Dānaṁ Yaśho ’Yaśhaḥ | Bhavanti Bhāvā Bhūtānāṁ Matta Eva Pṛithag-vidhāḥ || 5 ||
verse5.explanation: Krishna asserts that all moral and ethical qualities, whether good or bad, originate from Him.
verse5.sanskrit: अहिंसा समता तुष्टिस्तपो दानं यशोऽयशः | भवन्ति भावा भूतानां मत्त एव पृथग्विधाः || 5 ||

verse6.english: Maharṣhayaḥ Sapta Pūrve Chatvāro Manavas Tathā | Mad-bhāvā Mānasā Jātā Yeṣhāṁ Loka Imāḥ Prajāḥ || 6 ||
verse6.explanation: Krishna mentions that the great sages and Manus, who are the progenitors of all beings, were born from His mind.
verse6.sanskrit: महर्षयः सप्त पूर्वे चत्वारो मनवस्तथा | मद्भावा मानसा जाता येषां लोक इमाः प्रजाः || 6 ||

verse7.english: Etāṁ Vibhūtiṁ Yogaṁ Cha Mama Yo Vetti Tattvataḥ | So ’vikampena Yogena Yujyate Nātra Sanśhayaḥ || 7 ||
verse7.explanation: Krishna states that one who understands His divine powers and manifestations becomes firmly established in spiritual union with Him.
verse7.sanskrit: एतां विभूतिं योगं च मम यो वेत्ति तत्वतः | सोऽविकम्पेन योगेन युज्यते नात्र संशयः || 7 ||

verse8.english: Ahaṁ Sarvasya Prabhavo Mattaḥ Sarvaṁ Pravartate | Iti Matvā Bhajante Māṁ Budhā Bhāva-samanvitāḥ || 8 ||
verse8.explanation: Krishna declares that He is the origin of everything. The wise, recognizing this truth, worship Him with deep devotion and reverence.
verse8.sanskrit: अहं सर्वस्य प्रभवो मत्तः सर्वं प्रवर्तते | इति मत्वा भजन्ते मां बुधा भावसमन्विताः || 8 ||

verse9.english: Mac-Cittaḥ Mad-Gata-Prāṇā Bodhayantaḥ Parasparam | Kathayantaśh Cha Māṁ Nityaṁ Tuṣhyanti Cha Ramanti Cha || 9 ||
verse9.explanation: Devotees who focus their minds and lives on Krishna find joy and contentment in discussing His glories and enlightening one another.
verse9.sanskrit: मच्चित्तः मद्गतप्राणा बोधयन्तः परस्परम् | कथयन्तश्च मां नित्यं तुष्यन्ति च रमन्ति च || 9 ||

verse10.english: "dajñānam jānavantībhyaḥ, prajñānāṁ śreṣṭhaṁ tathā | yuñjāṁ te mahāprājña, tvāṁ vijñāyāṁ śaktitaḥ || 10.10 ||"
verse10.explanation: This verse emphasizes that those who are devoted and worship Krishna with love receive divine knowledge and understanding, which guides them towards spiritual realization.
verse10.sanskrit: तेषां सततयुक्तानां भजतां प्रीतिपूर्वकम् | ददामि बुद्धियोगं तं येन मामुपयान्ति ते || 10 ||

verse11.english: "teṣāṁ evānukampārtham aham ajñāna-jaṁ tamaḥ nāśayāmy ātmabhāvastho jñāna-dīpena bhāsvarā || 10.11 ||"
verse11.explanation: Lord Krishna shows compassion to devoted souls by granting them divine wisdom, removing ignorance and illuminating their minds to realize the Supreme Truth.
verse11.sanskrit: "तेषां एवānukampārtham अहम् अजñāna-जं तमः | नाशयामि आत्मभावस्थो ज्ञानदीपेना भास्वता || 10.11 ||"

verse12.english: "arjuna uvāca | paraṁ brahma paraṁ dhāma pavitraṁ paramaṁ bhagavān | puruṣaṁ śāśvataṁ divyam ādidevam ajam vibhum || 10.12 ||"
verse12.explanation: "Arjuna said: You are the Supreme Brahman, the ultimate abode, the purest, the supreme Lord, the eternal, divine person, the primordial God, and the all-pervading one."
verse12.sanskrit: "अरजुन उवाच | परं ब्रह्म परं धाम पवित्रं परमं भगवान् | पुरुषं शाश्वतं दिव्यम् आदिदेवम् अजम् विभुम् || 10.12 ||"

verse13.english: "brahmaṇyaḥ brahma-vidām brahma vāyuḥ brahma janārdanaḥ | brahma vidyā vidyānāṁ brahma śāstraṁ mamāyam || 10.13 ||"
verse13.explanation: Krishna is recognized as the essence of the Supreme Brahman and the ultimate source of all spiritual knowledge.
verse13.sanskrit: "ब्रह्मण्यः ब्रह्मविदां ब्रह्म वायुः ब्रह्म जनार्दनः | ब्रह्म विद्या विद्यानां ब्रह्म शास्त्रं ममायम् || 10.13 |

verse14.english: "aham ātmā guḍākeśa sarva-bhūtāśayas tithaḥ | aham ādiś ca madhyaṁ ca bhūtānām anta eva ca || 10.14 ||"
verse14.explanation: Krishna reveals to Arjuna that He is the essence within all beings, existing in their hearts. He is the origin, sustainer, and ultimate end of all creation.
verse14.sanskrit: "अहम् आत्मा गुडाकेश सर्वभूताशयस्तिथः | अहम् आदिश्च मध्यं च भूतानामन्त एव च || 10.14 ||"

verse15.english: "yan-mayātmakam ānāsyaṁ brahmaṇi ved vidyate | praṇamya aham svadharmajñaṁ tattvam advayam amṛtam || 10.15 ||"
verse15.explanation: Krishna is recognized as the ultimate reality and supreme knowledge embodied in all sacred texts. He is the non-dual, immortal essence of existence, to which all devotion and understanding are directed.
verse15.sanskrit: "यन्मयात्मकमाणस्यं ब्रह्मणी वेद विद्यते | प्रणम्यहम् स्वधर्मज्ञं तत्त्वम् अद्वयम् अमृतम् || 10.15 ||"

verse16.english: "na haṁ prapadyate yastv ātmanam nītya-nāryam | atyānāryam svadharmajñaṁ tattvam advayam amṛtam || 10.16 ||"
verse16.explanation: One who fails to acknowledge or submit to the eternal and imperishable truth of the self is not regarded as a genuine seeker of spiritual knowledge or liberation.
verse16.sanskrit: "न हं प्रपद्यते यस्त्वात्मनं नीत्यनार्यम् | अत्यानार्यम् स्वधर्मज्ञं तत्त्वम् अद्वयम् अमृतम् || 10.16 ||"

verse17.english: "ko’smin sattva-nāśāya kuśeyāmi tattva-vit | na prasaktāsmyaṇer avyayaṁ śāśvataṁ ca || 10.17 ||"
verse17.explanation: Krishna declares Himself as the ultimate truth, beyond all forms of decay, embodying an eternal and unchanging reality that transcends the physical realm.
verse17.sanskrit: "कोऽस्मिन्सत्त्वनाशाय कुशेयामि तत्त्ववित् | न प्रसक्तास्म्यणेरव्ययं शाश्वतं च || 10.17 ||"

verse18.english: "yaḥ śāstra-vidhi-karmāṇi na ved na dhāraṇam | tasya parādharmaḥ syām sa eva parāyaṇam || 10.18 ||"
verse18.explanation: A person who disregards the scriptural guidelines for performing actions and fails to adhere to them is following a lower path and is not genuinely committed to the true spiritual practice.
verse18.sanskrit: "यः शास्त्रविधि कर्माणि न वेद न धारणम् | तस्य पराधर्मोऽयं स एव परायणम् || 10.18 ||"

verse19.english: "tava tattvam paraṁ brahma yat tattvaṁ ca dṛṣṭam | bhaktiḥ sad-vidyā tava parāmaruṇāṁ sadā || 10.19 ||"
verse19.explanation: The supreme reality of Krishna is recognized as the highest Brahman. Understanding this truth is achieved through unwavering devotion, reflecting the constant pursuit of spiritual knowledge and connection.
verse19.sanskrit: "तव तत्त्वम परं ब्रह्म यत्तत्त्वं च दृष्टम् | भक्तिः सद्विद्या तव परामरुणां सदा || 10.19 ||"

verse20.english: "aham ātmā guḍākeśa sarva-bhūtāśayas tithaḥ | aham ādiś ca madhyaṁ ca bhūtānām anta eva ca || 10.20 ||"
verse20.explanation: Krishna declares that He is the essence within every being, the source of all creation, and the ultimate end. He is present in the hearts of all creatures and is the fundamental reality that encompasses the entire existence.
verse20.sanskrit: "अहम् आत्मा गुडाकेश सर्वभूताशयस्तिथः | अहम् आदिश्च मध्यं च भूतानामन्त एव च || 10.20 ||"

verse21.english: "vīryaṁ śuklaṁ mahadaṁ prajñā sattvaṁ śuddhaṁ ca | dharmaḥ satyam ācāryaṁ kriyā yatra tattvataḥ || 10.21 ||"
verse21.explanation: The verse emphasizes that qualities such as strength, purity, wisdom, virtue, and righteousness are integral to understanding the highest truth. Engaging in these practices helps one achieve true spiritual realization.
verse21.sanskrit: "वीर्यं शुक्लं महदं प्रज्ञा सत्त्वं शुद्धं च | धर्मः सत्यम् आचार्यं क्रिया यत्र तत्त्वतः || 10.21 ||"

verse22.english: "hṛṣīkeśaḥ tattva-siddhaḥ sattvaṁ puruṣottamaḥ | avikāryaḥ paraṁ brahma śāśvataṁ sarva-dharmaṁ || 10.22 ||"
verse22.explanation: Krishna is acknowledged as the Supreme Person, the ultimate reality who governs the senses and remains unchanged and eternal. He is the immutable essence that upholds all duties and righteousness.
verse22.sanskrit: "हृषीकेशः तत्त्वसिद्धः सत्त्वं पुरुषोत्तमः | अविकार्यः परं ब्रह्म शाश्वतं सर्वधर्मं || 10.22 ||"

verse23.english: "govindaḥ sarva-bhūtānāṁ nānyaḥ paravadhaḥ svayam | prabhavaḥ śveṣu vidyānām parāde’smiṁś ca yad-vidhaḥ || 10.23 ||"
verse23.explanation: Krishna, referred to as Govinda, is recognized as the ultimate source and foundation of all beings and knowledge. He is the supreme entity from which all things arise, and there is no higher source than Him
verse23.sanskrit: "गोविन्दः सर्वभूतानां नान्यः परवधः स्वयम् | प्रभवः श्वेषु विद्यानाम् परादेऽस्मिंश्च यद्विधः || 10.23 ||"

verse24.english: "vedanam samavedasya hṛdayasya tapasvinām | śivaṁ buddhiḥ śrutam ca sākṣād adhikarma-kṛt || 10.24 ||"
verse24.explanation: Krishna declares that among the Vedas, He represents the Sama Veda, and among hymns, He embodies the essence of the Sama Veda. He is the ultimate realization of wisdom and the heart of all austerities, reflecting the supreme truth.
verse24.sanskrit: "वेदनं समवेदस्य हृदयस्य तपस्विनाम् | शिवं बुद्धिः श्रुतं च साक्षादधिकर्मकृत् || 10.24 ||"

verse25.english: "akṣaraṁ brahma yad yasya vidyānām adhigamyate | akarmaṇo’sminsattvaṁ sattvam atyartha-praṇāyanam || 10.25 ||"
verse25.explanation: Krishna declares that He is the imperishable Brahman, the ultimate reality realized through the highest knowledge. He represents the supreme essence and truth behind all forms of wisdom and non-action.

verse26.english: "vṛkṣāṇāṁ aśvattho’ham rṣīṇāṁ śvetapadmakah | dhanuṣāṁ sandhipo’ham āsmi devatānāṁ maheśvaraḥ || 10.26 ||"
verse26.explanation: Krishna states that He is represented by the Ashvattha tree among trees, the sage Brhaspati among sages, the bow among weapons, and Shiva among deities. This highlights His divine presence and significance in various aspects of existence.
verse26.sanskrit: "वृक्षाणां अश्वत्थोऽहम् रिषणां श्वेतपद्मकः | धनुषां सन्धिपोऽहं आस्मि देवतानां महेश्वरः || 10.26 ||"

verse27.english: "aham aiśvaryo’sminsarva-bhūtānāṁ hi | tvattaḥ sākṣād aham bhūtānāṁ mahad-vād asmins-smṛtam || 10.27 ||"
verse27.explanation: Krishna declares that He is the embodiment of supreme wealth and glory, representing the highest essence and source of greatness among all beings. This verse emphasizes His integral role in the magnificence of creation.
verse27.sanskrit: "अहम् ऐश्वर्योऽस्मिन्सर्वभूतानां हि | त्वत्तः साक्षादहम् भूतानां महद्वादस्मिन्स्मृतम् || 10.27 ||"

verse28.english: sarvasya cāhaṁ hṛdi sanniviṣṭo mattāḥ smṛtir jñānam apohanaṁ ca vedaiś ca sarvair ahaṁ eva vedyo vedānta-kṛd vedavid eva cāham
verse28.explanation: Krishna identifies Himself as the Ganges among rivers and the ultimate reality symbolized by dreams, emphasizing His transcendence beyond direct perception. This verse highlights His divine essence that surpasses ordinary experience.
verse28.sanskrit: "नद्यः स्वप्नं श्वेतपद्मकः न चैनम् आत्मनः | स्वप्नाश्वरूपमध्यस्तं प्रत्यक्षं न दृश्यते || 10.28 ||"

verse29.english: āyur yasya hi so’ntarikṣa-vākya-sannikṛṣaḥ āntar-jvala āntar-nava-śabda-meṣayed prāyaḥ sarvasya vaśnanti veda-samanviti yasya brahmā sṛjati sattva-saṅgān
verse29.explanation: Krishna asserts that He is the highest form of wisdom and the ultimate realization of true gratitude. He is the essence of pure understanding and is beyond all difficulties, representing the ultimate realization of the Self.
verse29.sanskrit: "विज्ञानं कृतज्ञा च मैंवमस्ति दुरासदा | सद्भावं संवितां प्राप्य शुद्धमात्मन्यवेक्षते || 10.29 ||"

verse30.english: "maharṣayo’smi rājārṣayo’smi śvetapadmakāḥ | nadyāḥ śvetapadmakāḥ nāyamasmi tatr te || 10.30 ||"
verse30.explanation: Krishna identifies Himself as Vyasa among sages, Janaka among kings, and the Ganges among rivers, highlighting His divine presence and significance in these revered aspects of existence.
verse30.sanskrit: "महर्षयोऽस्मि राजर्षयोऽस्मि श्वेतपद्मकः | नद्यः श्वेतपद्मकः नायमस्ति तत्र ते || 10.30 ||"

verse31.english: "aham ācāryāyāmi yathāśritaṁ ca me sadā | dharmaṁ dānaṁ ca bhaktiṁ ca śaraṇaṁ ca yathā mama || 10.31 ||"
verse31.explanation: Krishna declares that He is the greatest of teachers and the ultimate refuge for those seeking protection. He represents righteousness, charity, devotion, and protection, embodying the highest principles of dharma.
verse31.sanskrit: "अहम् आचार्यायामि यथाश्रितं च मे सदा | धर्मं दानं च भक्तिं च शरणं च यथा मम || 10.31 ||"

verse32.english: "śrī-bhagavān uvāca | aham ātmā guḍākeśa sarva-bhūtāśayas tithaḥ | aham ādiś ca madhyaṁ ca bhūtānām anta eva ca || 10.32 ||"
verse32.explanation: Krishna reveals that He is the Self present in the hearts of all living beings. He is the source (beginning), the sustainer (middle), and the ultimate end of all creatures, signifying His omnipresence and fundamental role in the universe.
verse32.sanskrit: "श्रीभगवानुवाच | अहम् आत्मा गुडाकेश सर्वभूताशयस्तिथः | अहम् आदिश्च मध्यं च भूतानामन्त एव च || 10.32 ||"

verse33.english: "dvādaśānāṁ samāseḍhyāṁ śarvasya vakṣye’nuśāsanam | śāsanam ca pravakṣyāmi saṁhitā siddhimā vayaṁ || 10.33 ||"
verse33.explanation: Krishna declares that He is Vishnu among the twelve Adityas, the Moon among the stars, the Samaveda among the Vedas, and the mind among the senses. This highlights His divine presence and significance in these aspects of existence.
verse33.sanskrit: "द्वादशानां समासेध्यां शर्वस्य वक्ष्येऽनुशासनम् | शासनं च प्रवक्ष्यामि संहिता सिद्धिमा वयं || 10.33 ||"

verse34.english: "ahaṁ sarvasya prabhavo mattāḥ sarvaṁ pravartate | iti matvā bhajante māṁ buddhā bhāgavataḥ sadā || 10.34 ||"
verse34.explanation: "Krishna reveals that He is the origin of all creation and everything comes from Him; those who understand this truth worship Him with devotion, recognizing Him as the ultimate source and maintaining constant devotion."
verse34.sanskrit: "अहं सर्वस्य प्रभवो मत्तः सर्वं प्रवर्तते | इति मत्वा भजन्ते मां बुधा भागवता सदा || 10.34 ||"

verse35.english: "vīryāni daityānāṁ dhruvā samācaranti | dāyinaṁ rudrānāṁ prabhave svasitastvayā || 10.35 ||"
verse35.explanation: Krishna asserts that among the powerful, He is the strength; among the virtuous, He is the virtue; among the righteous, He is the truth; and among the cruel, He is the fury, signifying His omnipresence in various aspects of existence.
verse35.sanskrit: "वीर्यानि दैत्य्यानि ध्रुवा समाचरन्ति | दायिनां रुद्रानां प्रभवे सस्वितस्त्वया || 10.35 ||"

verse36.english: "dharma-jñānaṁ sravāsto’ham anartha-niṣūdanaṁ | sarva-dharma-saṁnyasto dharmo dharmāḥ pracetanaṁ || 10.36 ||"
verse36.explanation: Krishna identifies Himself as the essence of righteousness and the destroyer of all evils. He represents the culmination and origin of all forms of dharma, embodying both the end and the beginning of righteous principles.
verse36.sanskrit: "धर्मज्ञानं स्रवास्तोऽहम् अनर्थनिषूदनम् | सर्वधर्मसंन्यस्तो धर्मो धर्माः प्रचेतनम् || 10.36 ||"

verse37.english: "ahaṁ krodhaḥ paraṁ śānti śīlam ātmā mahā-dyutaḥ | jighāṁsituḥ paramaś ca tatra buddhir bhaya-bhōginī || 10.37 ||"
verse37.explanation: Krishna explains that He manifests as various powerful forces and attributes. He represents anger, peace, self-nature, and supreme radiance, as well as desire, intelligence, and the source of both fear and pleasure.
verse37.sanskrit: "अहं क्रोधः परं शांति शीलमात्मा महाद्युतः | जिघांसितुः परमश्च तत्र बुद्धिर्भयभोगिनी || 10.37 ||"

verse38.english: dṛtiḥ śaktiḥ rater vaiṣṇavasya santānaṁ yasya tu pūrvapunaḥ yena vāñchati tattvena tasyodho’graviṣannataḥ
verse38.explanation: Krishna declares Himself as the embodiment of righteousness and virtue, representing the essence of charitable acts, wisdom, eternal wealth, and peace.
verse38.sanskrit: धृतिः शक्तिः रतेर्वैष्णवस्य सन्तानं यस्य तु पूर्वपुनः येन वाञ्छति तत्त्वेण तस्योऽधोऽग्रविषन्नतः ||

verse39.english: "ahaṁ cā’smi dadhāti bhūtāni yamaḥ sadā sadā | na vivekṣyastadarthatvā prāṇasvātyāyanam || 10.39 ||"
verse39.explanation: Krishna reveals that He is the fundamental force sustaining all life and natural law, transcending temporal limitations and embodying the essence of existence.
verse39.sanskrit: "अहं चोऽस्मि दधाति भूतानि यमः सदा सदा | न विवेक्ष्यस्तदर्थत्वा प्राणस्वात्यायनम् || 10.39 ||"

verse40.english: "na haṁ anuṣṭhitāṁ vidhiṁ svadharmaṁ na tyajāmy aham | ahaṁ svadharmayojñāmi vastrāṇi saṁdhinō’smi || 10.40 ||"
verse40.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that He upholds the adherence to duties and righteousness. He supports and maintains the principles of virtue and proper conduct, ensuring that the observance of one's duties is always guided by the right principles.
verse40.sanskrit: "न हं अनुष्ठितां विधिं स्वधर्मं न त्यजाम्यहम् | अहं स्वधर्मयोज्ञामि वस्त्राणि संधिनोऽस्मि || 10.40 ||"

verse41.english: "ahaṁ brahmā mahā-devo devānāṁ ca satāṁ kṛtaḥ | bhūtānāṁ harir gātre taṁ sṛṣṭe’smin mahā-dhvanam || 10.41 ||"
verse41.explanation: Krishna identifies Himself as the supreme deity responsible for creation, including the gods and righteous beings. He represents the essential force behind the process of creation and is the ultimate source in the cosmic order.
verse41.sanskrit: "अहं ब्रह्मा महादेवो देवानां च सतां कृतः | भूतानां हरिर्गात्रे तं सृष्टेऽस्मिन्महाध्वनम् || 10.41 ||"

verse42.english: "sarva-dharmaṁ prapadyatvā mama sarveśvarāt manaḥ | sarva-dharmaḥ punar yuktō mama te paramātmanah || 10.42 ||"
verse42.explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to surrender all his duties to Him and assures that He will bestow supreme knowledge. This surrender will lead to liberation by reuniting with the Supreme Self.
verse42.sanskrit: "सर्वधर्मं प्रपद्यत्वा मम सर्वेश्वरात्मनः | सर्वधर्मः पुनर्युक्तो मम ते परमात्मनः || 10.42 ||"

verse43.english: "na haṁ doṣāṇi kartāraṁ uṣṇeṣu prapadyate | sarvaṁ dharma-yuktaṁ ca śuddham tattvam ayātmani || 10.43 ||"
verse43.explanation: Krishna indicates that He does not hold the faults of the doer against them. Instead, He focuses on the righteousness of actions, which are aligned with the ultimate truth and the Supreme Self.
verse43.sanskrit: "न हं दोषाणि कर्तारमुष्णेषु प्रपद्यते | सर्वं धर्मयुक्तं च शुद्धं तत्त्वमयात्मनि || 10.43 ||"

verse44.english: "sarva-dharmaṁ bhṛtaḥ putra mahāntaṁ paramātmanah | vijñāna-yogam astu sattvasya sarva-dharmataḥ || 10.44 ||"
verse44.explanation: Krishna declares that the Supreme Self is the essence of all beings and that the path of knowledge and devotion represents the highest form of righteousness for everyone.
verse44.sanskrit: "सर्वधर्मं भृतः पुत्र महान्तं परमात्मनः | विज्ञानयोगमस्तु सत्त्वस्य सर्वधर्मतः || 10.44 ||"

verse45.english: "ahaṁ svadharma-vijñāya yathārthaṁ japāmy aham | pravṛtti-saṁyuktā bhūtāni paramātmanah || 10.45 ||"
verse45.explanation: Krishna explains that He acts in accordance with His own understanding of duty and guides all beings in alignment with the will of the Supreme Self.
verse45.sanskrit: "अहं स्वधर्मविज्ञाय यथार्थं जपाम्यहम् | प्रवृत्तिसंयुक्ता भूतानि परमात्मनः || 10.45 ||"

verse1.english: arjuna uvāca | madanugrahāya paramaṁ guhyamadhyātmasaṁjñitam | yattvayoktaṁ vacastena moho'yaṁ vigato mama || 1 ||
verse1.explanation: Arjuna expresses his gratitude to Krishna for the teachings given to him. He acknowledges that Krishna's instructions have removed his confusion and ignorance, especially regarding the true nature of the self and the ultimate reality. This sets the stage for the forthcoming revelation of Krishna's universal form (Vishvarupa).
verse1.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | मदनुग्रहाय परमं गुह्यमध्यात्मसंज्ञितम् | यत्त्वयोक्तं वचस्तेन मोहोऽयं विगतो मम || 1 |

verse2.english: bhavāpyayau hi bhūtānāṁ śrutau vistaraśo mayā | tvattaḥ kamalapatrākṣa māhātmyamapi cāvyayam || 2 ||
verse2.explanation: Arjuna continues to express his understanding of Krishna's teachings. He acknowledges that he has learned about the creation and destruction of all beings and has also gained insight into Krishna's eternal and divine greatness. The reference to Krishna as "lotus-eyed" signifies his divine beauty and purity.
verse2.sanskrit: भवाप्ययौ हि भूतानां श्रुतौ विस्तरशो मया | त्वत्त: कमलपत्राक्ष माहात्म्यमपि चाव्ययम् || 2 ||

verse3.english: evametadyathāttha tvamātmānaṁ parameśvara | draṣṭumicchāmi te rūpamaīśvaraṁ puruṣottama || 3 ||
verse3.explanation: Arjuna, now fully convinced of Krishna's divine nature, expresses his desire to witness Krishna's universal form. He refers to Krishna as "Parameshwara" (Supreme Lord) and "Purushottama" (the best of beings), acknowledging His supreme position.
verse3.sanskrit: एवमेतद्यथात्थ त्वमात्मानं परमेश्वर | द्रष्टुमिच्छामि ते रूपमैश्वरं पुरुषोत्तम || 3 ||

verse4.english: manyase yadi tacchakhyaṁ mayā draṣṭumiti prabho | yogeśvara tato me tvaṁ darśayātmānamavyayam || 4 ||
verse4.explanation: Arjuna humbly requests Krishna to reveal His universal form, but only if Krishna deems him worthy of witnessing it. By addressing Krishna as "Yogeshwara," Arjuna recognizes Krishna as the master of all mystic powers and divine manifestations.
verse4.sanskrit: मन्यसे यदि तच्छक्यं मया द्रष्टुमिति प्रभो | योगेश्वर ततो मे त्वं दर्शयात्मानमव्ययम् || 4 ||

verse5.english: śrībhagavānuvāca | paśya me pārtha rūpāṇi śataśo'tha sahasraśaḥ | nānāvidhāni divyāni nānāvarṇākṛtīni ca || 5 ||
verse5.explanation: Krishna begins to reveal His universal form to Arjuna. He invites Arjuna to observe His numerous divine forms, which are of various colors and shapes, indicating the infinite variety and diversity of the divine manifestation.
verse5.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | पश्य मे पार्थ रूपाणि शतशोऽथ सहस्रश: | नानाविधानि दिव्यानि नानावर्णाकृतीनि च || 5 ||

verse6.explanation: Krishna continues to describe the beings within His universal form, including the Adityas (solar deities), Vasus (elemental gods), Rudras (forms of Shiva), Ashvins (divine twin horsemen), and Maruts (storm gods). He emphasizes that Arjuna is witnessing extraordinary phenomena that have never been seen before.

verse7.english: ihaikasthaṁ jagatkṛtsnaṁ paśyādya sacarācaram | mama dehe guḍākeśa yaccānyaddraṣṭumicchasi || 7 ||
verse7.explanation: Krishna invites Arjuna to see the entire universe within His body, emphasizing His omnipresence. The term "Gudakesha," meaning conqueror of sleep, is used to address Arjuna, highlighting his spiritual readiness. Krishna asserts that everything in existence is contained within His divine form.
verse7.sanskrit: इहैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं पश्याद्य सचराचरम् | मम देहे गुडाकेश यच्चान्यद्द्रष्टुमिच्छसि || 7 ||

verse8.english: na tu māṁ śakyase draṣṭumanenaiva svacakṣuṣā | divyaṁ dadāmi te cakṣuḥ paśya me yogamaīśvaram || 8 ||
verse8.explanation: Krishna informs Arjuna that his ordinary eyes are not capable of perceiving the divine universal form. Hence, Krishna grants Arjuna divine vision (divya chakshu) so that he can witness the awe-inspiring manifestation of Krishna's supreme power, which transcends human perception.
verse8.sanskrit: न तु मां शक्यसे द्रष्टुमनेनैव स्वचक्षुषा | दिव्यं ददामि ते चक्षु: पश्य मे योगमैश्वरम् || 8 ||

verse9.english: sañjaya uvāca | evamuktvā tato rājann mahāyogeśvaro hariḥ | darśayāmāsa pārthāya paramaṁ rūpamaīśvaram || 9 ||
verse9.explanation: Sanjaya, the narrator, describes how Krishna, after speaking to Arjuna, reveals His universal form. The term "Hari" refers to Krishna, and "Mahayogeshwara" emphasizes Krishna's mastery over all yogic powers. The revelation marks a significant moment in the Bhagavad Gita, as Arjuna witnesses the divine form.
verse9.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच | एवमुक्त्वा ततो राजन्महायोगेश्वरो हरि: | दर्शयामास पार्थाय परमं रूपमैश्वरम् || 9 ||

verse10.explanation: Krishna's universal form is described as having countless faces and eyes, adorned with divine ornaments, and wielding various celestial weapons. He is seen wearing heavenly garlands and garments, and His form is anointed with divine fragrances. This form is infinite and faces in all directions, symbolizing His omnipresence and the awe-inspiring nature of the divine.

verse11.english: divyamālyāmbaradharaṁ divyagandhānulepanam | sarvāścaryamayaṁ devam anantaṁ viśvatomukham || 11 ||
verse11.explanation: Krishna's universal form is described as having countless faces and eyes, adorned with divine ornaments, and wielding various celestial weapons. He is seen wearing heavenly garlands and garments, and His form is anointed with divine fragrances. This form is infinite and faces in all directions, symbolizing His omnipresence and the awe-inspiring nature of the divine.

verse12.english: divi sūrya-sahasrasya bhaved yugapad utthitā | yadi bhāḥ sadṛśī sā syād bhāsas tasya mahātmanaḥ || 12 ||
verse12.explanation: This verse conveys the overwhelming brilliance of Krishna's universal form. The light emitted by this form is compared to the combined radiance of a thousand suns. This metaphor illustrates the dazzling, almost unimaginable glory of Krishna's divine form.
verse12.sanskrit: दिवि सूर्यसहस्रस्य भवेद्युगपदुत्थिता | यदि भा: सदृशी सा स्याद्भासस्तस्य महात्मन: || 12 ||

verse13.english: tatraikasthaṁ jagat kṛtsnaṁ pravibhaktam anekadhā | apaśyad devadevasya śarīre pāṇḍavas tadā || 13 ||
verse13.explanation: Arjuna, now endowed with divine vision, perceives the entire cosmos within Krishna's universal form. This form encompasses everything, from the smallest particles to the largest celestial bodies, all contained within Krishna's divine body.
verse13.sanskrit: तत्रैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं प्रविभक्तमनेकधा | अपश्यद्देवदेवस्य शरीरे पाण्डवस्तदा || 13 ||

verse14.english: tataḥ sa vismayāviṣṭo hṛṣṭaromā dhanañjayaḥ | praṇamya śirasā devaṁ kṛtāñjalir abhāṣata || 14 ||
verse14.explanation: Arjuna is overwhelmed by the sight of Krishna's universal form. His emotions manifest physically as his hair stands on end, a sign of intense spiritual experience. He bows before Krishna in reverence and prepares to express his feelings.
verse14.sanskrit: तत: स विस्मयाविष्टो हृष्टरोमा धनञ्जय: | प्रणम्य शिरसा देवं कृताञ्जलिरभाषत || 14 ||

verse15.english: arjuna uvāca | paśyāmi devāṁs tava deva dehe sarvāṁs tathā bhūta-viśeṣa-saṅghān | brahmāṇam īśaṁ kamalāsana-stham ṛṣīṁś ca sarvān uragāṁś ca divyān || 15 ||
verse15.explanation: Arjuna describes what he sees within Krishna's universal form: all the gods, the different beings of creation, Lord Brahma (the creator), Lord Shiva (the destroyer), sages, and divine serpents. This vision underscores Krishna's role as the ultimate container of all beings and entities in the universe.
verse15.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | पश्यामि देवांस्तव देव देहे सर्वांस्तथा भूतविशेषसङ्घान् | ब्रह्माणमीशं कमलासनस्थ- मृषींश्च सर्वानुरगांश्च दिव्यान् || 15 ||

verse16.english: anekabāhūdara-vaktra-netraṁ paśyāmi tvāṁ sarvato’nanta-rūpam | nāntaṁ na madhyaṁ na punas tavādiṁ paśyāmi viśveśvara viśvarūpa || 16 ||
verse16.explanation: Arjuna is unable to comprehend the limits of Krishna's universal form. He sees countless limbs and features expanding endlessly in all directions. The form has no discernible beginning, middle, or end, reflecting the infinite and eternal nature of Krishna.
verse16.sanskrit: अनेकबाहूदरवक्त्रनेत्रं पश्यामि त्वां सर्वतोऽनन्तरूपम् | नान्तं न मध्यं न पुनस्तवादिं पश्यामि विश्वेश्वर विश्वरूप || 16 ||

verse17.english: kiritinaṁ gadinaṁ cakriṇaṁ ca tejorāśiṁ sarvato dīptimantam | paśyāmi tvāṁ durnirīkṣyaṁ samantād dīptānalārka-dyutim aprameyam || 17 ||
verse17.explanation: Arjuna describes Krishna's universal form as resplendent, wearing a crown, and wielding a mace and discus, symbols of divine authority and power. The radiance of this form is so intense that it is difficult to look at, likened to the combined brightness of fire and the sun, emphasizing its immeasurable nature.
verse17.sanskrit: किरिटिनं गदिनं चक्रिणं च तेजोराशिं सर्वतो दीप्तिमन्तम् | पश्यामि त्वां दुर्निरीक्ष्यं समन्ताद् दीप्तानलार्कद्युतिमप्रमेयम् || 17 ||

verse18.english: tvam akṣaraṁ paramaṁ veditavyaṁ tvam asya viśvasya paraṁ nidhānam | tvam avyayaḥ śāśvata-dharma-goptā sanātanas tvaṁ puruṣo mato me || 18 ||
verse18.explanation: Arjuna acknowledges Krishna as the imperishable and supreme reality that must be realized. Krishna is the ultimate refuge and support of the entire universe, the eternal guardian of righteousness (dharma), and the timeless Supreme Person (Purusha), the highest being in existence.
verse18.sanskrit: त्वमक्षरं परमं वेदितव्यं त्वमस्य विश्वस्य परं निधानम् | त्वमव्यय: शाश्वतधर्मगोप्ता सनातनस्त्वं पुरुषो मतो मे || 18 ||

verse19.english: anādi-madhyāntam ananta-vīryam ananta-bāhuṁ śaśi-sūrya-netram | paśyāmi tvāṁ dīpta-hutāśa-vaktraṁ svatejasā viśvam idaṁ tapantam || 19 ||
verse19.explanation: Arjuna continues to describe Krishna's form as boundless, with no discernible beginning, middle, or end. Krishna's power is infinite, His arms countless, and His eyes are the sun and moon, symbolizing illumination and omnipresence. The fiery brilliance emanating from Krishna's mouth represents His ability to consume and transform all things, scorching the universe with divine light.
verse19.sanskrit: अनादिमध्यान्तमनन्तवीर्य- मनन्तबाहुं शशिसूर्यनेत्रम् | पश्यामि त्वां दीप्तहुताशवक्त्रं स्वतेजसा विश्वमिदं तपन्तम् || 19 ||

verse20.english: dyāvāpṛthivyor idam antaraṁ hi vyāptaṁ tvayaikena diśaś ca sarvāḥ | dṛṣṭvādbhutaṁ rūpam ugraṁ tavedaṁ lokatrayaṁ pravyathitaṁ mahātman || 20 ||
verse20.explanation: Arjuna observes that Krishna’s universal form fills all of existence, encompassing the entire universe. The overwhelming and fearsome aspect of this form causes great fear and agitation among all beings in the three worlds (heaven, earth, and the underworld), demonstrating Krishna's boundless power.
verse20.sanskrit: द्यावापृथिव्योरिदमन्तरं हि व्याप्तं त्वयैकेन दिशश्च सर्वा: | दृष्ट्वाद्भुतं रूपमुग्रं तवेदं लोकत्रयं प्रव्यथितं महात्मन् || 20 ||

verse21.english: amī hi tvāṁ surasaṅghā viśanti kecid bhītāḥ prāñjalayo gṛṇanti | svastīty uktvā maharṣi-siddha-saṅghāḥ stuvanti tvāṁ stutibhiḥ puṣkalābhiḥ || 21 ||
verse21.explanation: In Krishna's universal form, Arjuna sees divine beings, some of whom enter into Krishna, indicating that He is their ultimate refuge. Out of fear and reverence, many beings offer prayers and hymns, seeking protection and blessing. The sages and perfected beings, who recognize Krishna's supreme position, also offer their praises
verse21.sanskrit: अमी हि त्वां सुरसङ्घा विशन्ति केचिद्भीताः प्राञ्जलयो गृणन्ति | स्वस्तीत्युक्त्वा महर्षिसिद्धसङ्घा: स्तुवन्ति त्वां स्तुतिभि: पुष्कलाभि: || 21 ||

verse22.english: rudrādityā vasavo ye ca sādhyā viśve’śvinau marutaś coṣmapāś ca | gandharva-yakṣāsura-siddha-saṅghā vīkṣante tvāṁ vismitāś caiva sarve || 22 ||
verse22.explanation: Arjuna sees in Krishna's form all the gods and celestial beings from various divine orders—the Rudras (forms of Shiva), Adityas (solar deities), Vasus (elemental gods), Sadhyas (demi-gods), and others. These divine entities are struck with wonder and awe as they witness Krishna's universal form.
verse22.sanskrit: रुद्रादित्या वसवो ये च साध्या विश्वेऽश्विनौ मरुतश्चोष्मपाश्च | गन्धर्वयक्षासुरसिद्धसङ्घा वीक्षन्ते त्वां विस्मिताश्चैव सर्वे || 22 ||

verse23.english: rūpaṁ mahat te bahu-vaktra-netraṁ mahābāho bahu-bāhūru-pādam | bahūdaraṁ bahu-daṁṣṭrā-karālaṁ dṛṣṭvā lokāḥ pravyathitās tathāham || 23 ||
verse23.explanation: Arjuna expresses his fear and awe upon seeing Krishna’s universal form. The multitude of faces, limbs, and terrifying teeth reflect the vastness and fearsome power of Krishna. This form, which represents both creation and destruction, causes widespread fear among all beings, including Arjuna.
verse23.sanskrit: रूपं महत्ते बहुवक्त्रनेत्रं महाबाहो बहुबाहूरुपादम् | बहूदरं बहुदंष्ट्राकरालं दृष्ट्वा लोकाः प्रव्यथितास्तथाहम् || 23 ||

verse24.english: nabhaḥ-spṛśaṁ dīptam aneka-varṇaṁ vyāttānanaṁ dīpta-viśāla-netram | dṛṣṭvā hi tvāṁ pravyathitāntarātmā dhṛtiṁ na vindāmi śamaṁ ca viṣṇo || 24 ||
verse24.explanation: Arjuna is overwhelmed by the grandeur and terrifying aspects of Krishna's universal form. The form, which appears to touch the sky and blazes with various colors, adds to Arjuna’s fear. He feels disoriented and unable to find any inner peace or stability in the face of such an awe-inspiring vision.
verse24.sanskrit: नभःस्पृशं दीप्तमनेकवर्णं व्यात्ताननं दीप्तविशालनेत्रम् | दृष्ट्वा हि त्वां प्रव्यथितान्तरात्मा धृतिं न विन्दामि शमं च विष्णो || 24 ||

verse25.english: daṁṣṭrā-karālāni ca te mukhāni dṛṣṭvaiva kālānala-sannibhāni | diśo na jāne na labhe ca śarma prasīda deveśa jagan-nivāsa || 25 ||
verse25.explanation: Arjuna is further frightened by the sight of Krishna's mouths filled with sharp, terrifying teeth that appear like the flames of the end times (Pralaya). Overwhelmed by this vision, he loses his sense of direction and begs Krishna, the refuge of all beings, to show mercy and alleviate his fear.
verse25.sanskrit: दंष्ट्राकरालानि च ते मुखानि दृष्ट्वैव कालानलसन्निभानि | दिशो न जाने न लभे च शर्म प्रसीद देवेश जगन्निवास || 25 ||

verse26.english: amī ca tvāṁ dhṛtarāṣṭrasya putrāḥ sarve sahaivāvanipāla-saṅghaiḥ | bhīṣmo droṇaḥ sūta-putras tathāsau sahāsmadīyair api yodha-mukhyaiḥ || 26 ||
verse26.explanation: Arjuna vividly describes the horrifying sight of warriors from both sides, including the greatest heroes, being devoured by the fierce mouths of Krishna's universal form. This represents the inevitable destruction of all beings, even the most powerful, under the influence of time.
verse26.sanskrit: अमी च त्वां धृतराष्ट्रस्य पुत्रा: सर्वे सहैवावनिपालसङ्घै: | भीष्मो द्रोण: सूतपुत्रस्तथासौ सहास्मदीयैरपि योधमुख्यै: || 26 ||

verse27.english: vaktrāṇi te tvaramāṇā viśanti daṁṣṭrā-karālāni bhayānakāni | kecid vilagnā daśanāntareṣu sandṛśyante cūrṇitair uttamāṅgaiḥ || 27 ||
verse27.explanation: Arjuna continues to describe the terrifying vision of Krishna's universal form. The warriors on both sides are seen rushing into Krishna's mouths, where their heads are crushed by His fearsome teeth. This symbolizes the inevitable destruction that awaits all beings in the cycle of life and death, which is controlled by the divine will.
verse27.sanskrit: वक्त्राणि ते त्वरमाणा विशन्ति दंष्ट्राकरालानि भयानकानि | केचिद्विलग्ना दशनान्तरेषु सन्दृश्यन्ते चूर्णितैरुत्तमाङ्गै: || 27 ||

verse28.english: yathā nadīnāṁ bahavo ’mbu-vegāḥ samudram evābhimukhā dravanti | tathā tavāmī nara-loka-vīrā viśanti vaktrāṇy abhivijvalanti || 28 ||
verse28.explanation: Arjuna compares the warriors entering Krishna's mouths to rivers flowing into the ocean. Just as rivers are drawn to the ocean by their natural course, the warriors are drawn to their destruction, illustrating the inescapable fate of all living beings and the irresistible force of time.
verse28.sanskrit: यथा नदीनां बहवोऽम्बुवेगाः समुद्रमेवाभिमुखा द्रवन्ति | तथा तवामी नरलोकवीरा विशन्ति वक्त्राण्यभिविज्वलन्ति || 28 ||

verse29.english: yathā pradīptaṁ jvalanaṁ pataṅgā viśanti nāśāya samṛddha-vegāḥ | tathaiva nāśāya viśanti lokās tavāpi vaktrāṇi samṛddha-vegāḥ || 29 ||
verse29.explanation: The analogy of moths rushing into a fire signifies the self-destructive behavior of beings who, unaware of the consequences, are drawn to their doom. Similarly, the warriors on the battlefield are inevitably drawn to their destruction by Krishna’s divine plan.
verse29.sanskrit: यथा प्रदीप्तं ज्वलनं पतङ्गा विशन्ति नाशाय समृद्धवेगाः | तथैव नाशाय विशन्ति लोका- स्तवापि वक्त्राणि समृद्धवेगाः || 29 ||

verse30.english: lelihyase grasamānaḥ samantāl lokān samagrān vadanair jvaladbhiḥ | tejobhir āpūrya jagat samagraṁ bhāsas tavogrāḥ pratapanti viṣṇo || 30 ||
verse30.explanation: Krishna's universal form is depicted as all-consuming and omnipresent. His flaming mouths symbolize the destructive force that engulfs the entire creation, while His blinding radiance represents the inescapable and overwhelming power of divine will.
verse30.sanskrit: लेलिह्यसे ग्रसमानः समन्ता- ल्लोकान्समग्रान्वदनैर्ज्वलद्भिः | तेजोभिरापूर्य जगत्समग्रं भासस्तवोग्राः प्रतपन्ति विष्णो || 30 ||

verse31.english: ākhyāhi me ko bhavān ugra-rūpo namo ’stu te deva-vara prasīda | vijñātum icchāmi bhavantam ādyaṁ na hi prajānāmi tava pravṛttim || 31 ||
verse31.explanation: Arjuna is confused and terrified by Krishna's fearsome universal form. He asks Krishna to reveal His identity in this aspect and expresses a desire to understand His true nature and purpose. Arjuna humbly bows before Krishna, acknowledging His supreme position.
verse31.sanskrit: आख्याहि मे को भवानुग्ररूपो नमोऽस्तु ते देववर प्रसीद | विज्ञातुमिच्छामि भवन्तमाद्यं न हि प्रजानामि तव प्रवृत्तिम् || 31 ||

verse32.english: śrī-bhagavān uvāca | kālo ’smi loka-kṣhaya-kṛit pravṛiddho lokān samāhartum iha pravṛittaḥ | ṛite ’pi tvāṁ na bhaviṣhyanti sarve ye ’vasthitāḥ pratyanīkeṣhu yodhāḥ || 32 ||
verse32.explanation: Krishna reveals that He is Time (Kala), the ultimate force of destruction that brings about the end of all things. He declares that all the warriors present on the battlefield, except for the Pandavas, are destined to perish. This statement underscores the inevitability of death and the cosmic role Krishna plays in the cycle of creation and destruction.
verse32.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | कालोऽस्मि लोकक्षयकृत् प्रवृद्धो लोकान्समाहर्तुमिह प्रवृत्त: | ऋतेऽपि त्वां न भविष्यन्ति सर्वे येऽवस्थिता: प्रत्यनीकेषु योधा: || 32 ||

verse33.english: tasmāt tvam uttiṣṭha yaśo labhasva jitvā śhatrūn bhuṅkṣhva rājyaṁ samṛiddham | mayaivāite nihatāḥ pūrvam eva nimitta-mātraṁ bhava savya-sāchin || 33 ||
verse33.explanation: Krishna urges Arjuna to stand up and fight, assuring him that victory is certain because the enemies have already been defeated by His divine will. Arjuna’s role is simply to act as an instrument in the divine plan, emphasizing the idea that human actions are guided by a higher power.
verse33.sanskrit: तस्मात्त्वमुत्तिष्ठ यशो लभस्व जित्वा शत्रून् भुङ्क्ष्व राज्यं समृद्धम् | मयैवैते निहता: पूर्वमेव निमित्तमात्रं भव सव्यसाचिन् || 33 ||

verse34.english: droṇaṁ ca bhīṣhmaṁ ca jayadrathaṁ ca karṇaṁ tathānyān api yodha-vīrān | mayā hatāṁs tvaṁ jahi mā vyathiṣhṭhāḥ yudhyasva jetāsi raṇe sapatnān || 34 ||
verse34.explanation: Krishna reassures Arjuna that the fate of the key warriors opposing him has already been sealed by divine will. Arjuna’s role is to act without hesitation, as victory is assured by Krishna.
verse34.sanskrit: द्रोणं च भीष्मं च जयद्रथं च कर्णं तथान्यानपि योधवीरान् | मया हतांस्त्वं जहि माव्यथिष्ठा: युद्ध्यस्व जेतासि रणे सपत्नान् || 34 ||

verse35.english: sañjaya uvācha | etach-chhrutvā vachanaṁ keśhavasya kṛitāñjalir vepamānaḥ kirīṭī | namaskṛitvā bhūya evāha kṛiṣhṇaṁ sa-gadgadaṁ bhīta-bhītaḥ praṇamya || 35 ||
verse35.explanation: Sanjaya narrates how Arjuna, overwhelmed by the terrifying vision and the revelations of Krishna, bows in reverence and speaks with a voice choked with fear.
verse35.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच | एतच्छ्रुत्वा वचनं केशवस्य कृताञ्जलिर्वेपमानः किरीटी | नमस्कृत्वा भूय एवाह कृष्णं सगद्गदं भीतभीतः प्रणम्य || 35 ||

verse36.english: arjuna uvācha | sthāne hṛṣhīkeśha tava prakīrtyā jagat prahṛiṣhyaty anurajyate cha | rakṣhāṁsi bhītāni diśho dravanti sarve namasyanti cha siddha-saṅghāḥ || 36 ||
verse36.explanation: Arjuna acknowledges that the entire universe is appropriately responding to Krishna’s divine power—while the righteous are filled with joy and devotion, the wicked are terrified.
verse36.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | स्थाने हृषीकेश तव प्रकीर्त्या जगत्प्रहृष्यत्यनुरज्यते च | रक्षांसि भीतानि दिशो द्रवन्ति सर्वे नमस्यन्ति च सिद्धसङ्घाः || 36 ||

verse37.english: kasmāchcha te na nameran mahātman garīyase brahmaṇo ’py ādi-kartre | ananta deveśha jagan-nivāsa tvam akṣharaṁ sad-asat tat-paraṁ yat || 37 ||
verse37.explanation: Arjuna expresses the supreme greatness of Krishna, recognizing Him as the source of all creation and the ultimate reality that transcends both the physical and spiritual realms.
verse37.sanskrit: कस्माच्च ते न नमेरन्महात्मन् गरीयसे ब्रह्मणोऽप्यादिकर्त्रे | अनन्त देवेश जगन्निवास त्वमक्षरं सदसत्तत्परं यत् || 37 ||

verse38.english: tvam ādi-devaḥ puruṣhaḥ purāṇaḥ tvam asya viśhvasya paraṁ nidhānam | vettāsi vedyaṁ cha paraṁ cha dhāma tvayā tataṁ viśhvam ananta-rūpa || 38 ||
verse38.explanation: Arjuna continues to praise Krishna, recognizing Him as the eternal and original being who pervades and sustains all existence.
verse38.sanskrit: त्वमादिदेवः पुरुषः पुराणः त्वमस्य विश्वस्य परं निधानम् | वेत्तासि वेद्यं च परं च धाम त्वया ततं विश्वमनन्तरूप || 38 ||

verse39.english: vāyur yamo ’gnir varuṇaḥ śhaśhāṅkaḥ prajāpatis tvaṁ prapitāmahaśh cha | namo namas te ’stu sahasra-kṛitvaḥ punaśh cha bhūyo ’pi namo namas te || 39 ||
verse39.explanation: Arjuna acknowledges Krishna as the embodiment of various divine entities and forces of nature, offering repeated reverence and respect.
verse39.sanskrit: वायुर्यमोऽग्निर्वरुणः शशाङ्कः प्रजापतिस्त्वं प्रपितामहश्च | नमो नमस्तेऽस्तु सहस्रकृत्वः पुनश्च भूयोऽपि नमो नमस्ते || 39 ||

verse40.english: namaḥ purastād atha pṛiṣhṭhatas te namo ’stu te sarvata eva sarva | ananta-vīryāmita-vikramas tvaṁ sarvaṁ samāpnoṣhi tato ’si sarvaḥ || 40 ||
verse40.explanation: Arjuna offers his reverence from all directions, acknowledging Krishna’s omnipresence and infinite power, recognizing Him as the all-encompassing reality.
verse40.sanskrit: नमः पुरस्तादथ पृष्ठतस्ते नमोऽस्तु ते सर्वत एव सर्व | अनन्तवीर्यामितविक्रमस्त्वं सर्वं समाप्नोषि ततोऽसि सर्वः || 40 ||

verse41.english: sakheti matvā prasabhaṁ yad uktaṁ he kṛiṣhṇa he yādava he sakheti | ajānatā mahimānaṁ tavedaṁ mayā pramādāt praṇayena vāpi || 41 ||
verse41.explanation: Arjuna seeks forgiveness from Krishna for having addressed Him casually in the past, not realizing His divine greatness. He acknowledges that his familiarity with Krishna had previously led him to overlook Krishna's true nature.
verse41.sanskrit: सखेति मत्वा प्रसभं यदुक्तं हे कृष्ण हे यादव हे सखेति | अजानता महिमानं तवेदं मया प्रमादात्प्रणयेन वापि || 41 ||

verse42.english: yac cāvahāsārtham asat-kṛito ’si vihāra-śhayyāsana-bhojaneṣhu | eko ’tha vāpy achyuta tat-samakṣhaṁ tat kṣhāmaye tvām aham aprameyam || 42 ||
verse42.explanation: Arjuna continues to seek forgiveness from Krishna for any unintentional disrespect shown towards Him, either in private or in public, recognizing Krishna's divine nature and immeasurable greatness.
verse42.sanskrit: यच्चावहासार्थमसत्कृतोऽसि विहारशय्यासनभोजनेषु | एकोऽथवा अप्यच्युत तत्समक्षं तत्क्षामये त्वामहमप्रमेयम् || 42 ||

verse43.english: pitāsi lokasya charācharasya tvam asya pūjyaśh cha gurur garīyān | na tvat-samo ’sty abhyadhikaḥ kuto ’nyo loka-traye ’py apratima-prabhāva || 43 ||
verse43.explanation: Arjuna acknowledges Krishna as the creator and father of all beings, the supreme teacher, and the most revered being in all existence. He emphasizes that there is none equal to Krishna, much less anyone greater.
verse43.sanskrit: पिताऽसि लोकस्य चराचरस्य त्वमस्य पूज्यश्च गुरुर्गरीयान् | न त्वत्समोऽस्त्यभ्यधिकः कुतोऽन्यो लोकत्रयेऽप्यप्रतिमप्रभाव || 43 ||

verse44.english: tasmāt praṇamya praṇidhāya kāyaṁ prasādaye tvām aham īśham īḍyam | pitevaputrasya sakheva sakhyuḥ priyaḥ priyāyārhasi deva soḍhum || 44 ||
verse44.explanation: Arjuna humbly seeks Krishna’s mercy and forgiveness, comparing his relationship with Krishna to that of a son with a father, a friend with a friend, and a lover with the beloved, pleading for understanding and pardon.
verse44.sanskrit: तस्मात्प्रणम्य प्रणिधाय कायं प्रसादये त्वामहमीशमीड्यम् | पितेव पुत्रस्य सखेव सख्युः प्रियः प्रियायार्हसि देव सोढुम् || 44 ||

verse45.english: adṛiṣhṭa-pūrvaṁ hṛiṣhito ’smi dṛiṣhṭvā bhayena cha pravyathitaṁ mano me | tad eva me darśhaya deva rūpaṁ prasīda deveśha jagan-nivāsa || 45 ||
verse45.explanation: Arjuna is both thrilled and terrified by Krishna’s universal form. He requests Krishna to revert to His more familiar, gentle form, seeking relief from the overwhelming vision.
verse45.sanskrit: अदृष्टपूर्वं हृषितोऽस्मि दृष्ट्वा भयेन च प्रव्यथितं मनो मे | तदेव मे दर्शय देव रूपं प्रसीद देवेश जगन्निवास || 45 ||

verse46.english: kirīṭinaṁ gadinaṁ chakra-hastam ichchhāmi tvāṁ draṣhṭum ahaṁ tathaiva | tenaiva rūpeṇa chatur-bhujena sahasra-bāho bhava viśhva-mūrte || 46 ||
verse46.explanation: Arjuna requests Krishna to return to His familiar four-armed form, holding the symbols of divine power— the mace and discus— which are comforting to Arjuna and reflect Krishna’s divine majesty in a form he can relate to.
verse46.sanskrit: किरीटिनं गदिनं चक्रहस्तं इच्छामि त्वां द्रष्टुमहं तथैव | तेनैव रूपेण चतुर्भुजेन सहस्रबाहो भव विश्वमूर्ते || 46 ||

verse47.english: śhrī-bhagavān uvācha | mayā prasannena tavārjunedaṁ rūpaṁ paraṁ darśhitam ātma-yogāt | tejo-mayaṁ viśhvam anantam ādyaṁ yan me tvad anyena na dṛiṣhṭa-pūrvam || 47 ||
verse47.explanation: Krishna explains that the universal form Arjuna witnessed was revealed by His divine grace and power, a vision that no one else had ever seen. This emphasizes the special relationship between Krishna and Arjuna.
verse47.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | मया प्रसन्नेन तवार्जुनेदं रूपं परं दर्शितमात्मयोगात् | तेजोमयं विश्वमनन्तमाद्यं यन्मे त्वदन्येन न दृष्टपूर्वम् || 47 ||

verse48.english: na veda-yajñādhyayanair na dānair na cha kriyābhir na tapobhir ugraiḥ | evaṁ rūpaḥ śhakya ahaṁ nṛiloke draṣhṭuṁ tvad anyena kuru-pravīra || 48 ||
verse48.explanation: Krishna reveals that the vision of His universal form cannot be attained through traditional religious practices such as studying the scriptures, performing rituals, or austerities. This form was revealed only to Arjuna by Krishna’s special grace.
verse48.sanskrit: न वेदयज्ञाध्ययनैर्न दानै- र्न च क्रियाभिर्न तपोभिरुग्रैः | एवंरूपः शक्य अहं नृलोके द्रष्टुं त्वदन्येन कुरुप्रवीर || 48 ||

verse49.english: mā te vyathā mā cha vimūḍha-bhāvo dṛiṣṭvā rūpaṁ ghoram īdṛiṅ mamedam | vyapeta-bhīḥ prīta-manāḥ punas tvaṁ tad eva me rūpam idaṁ prapaśhya || 49 ||
verse49.explanation: Krishna reassures Arjuna, who is frightened and confused after witnessing the terrifying universal form. Krishna tells Arjuna not to be afraid or bewildered and to return to a state of calmness. He then prepares to show Arjuna His more familiar, gentle form to restore Arjuna's peace of mind. This highlights Krishna's compassion and the importance of devotion in overcoming fear and confusion.
verse49.sanskrit: मा ते व्यथा मा च विमूढभावो दृष्ट्वा रूपं घोरमीदृङ्ममेदम् | व्यपेतभीः प्रीतमना: पुनस्त्वं तदेव मे रूपमिदं प्रपश्य || 49 ||

verse50.english: sañjaya uvācha | ity arjunaṁ vāsudevas tathoktvā svakaṁ rūpaṁ darśhayām āsa bhūyaḥ | āśhvāsayām āsa cha bhītam enaṁ bhūtvā punaḥ saumya-vapur mahātmā || 50 ||
verse50.explanation: After revealing His universal form, Krishna reassumes His gentle, more familiar form to comfort Arjuna, who had been overwhelmed by the terrifying vision.
verse50.sanskrit: सञ्जय उवाच | इत्यर्जुनं वासुदेवस्तथोक्त्वा स्वकं रूपं दर्शयामास भूयः | आश्वासयामास च भीतमेनं भूत्वा पुनः सौम्यवपुर्महात्मा || 50 ||

verse51.english: arjuna uvācha | dṛiṣṭvedaṁ mānuṣhaṁ rūpaṁ tava saumyaṁ janārdana | idānīm asmi saṁvṛittaḥ sachetāḥ prakṛitiṁ gataḥ || 51 ||
verse51.explanation: Arjuna feels relief and comfort upon seeing Krishna in His gentle, human-like form. The terrifying vision had unsettled him, but now he feels calm and collected again.
verse51.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | दृष्ट्वेदं मानुषं रूपं तव सौम्यं जनार्दन | इदानीमस्मि संवृत्तः सचेता: प्रकृतिं गतः || 51 ||

verse52.english: śhrī-bhagavān uvācha | sudurdarśham idaṁ rūpaṁ dṛiṣṭavān asi yan mama | devā apy asya rūpasya nityaṁ darśhana-kāṅkṣhiṇaḥ || 52 ||
verse52.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the rarity and significance of the vision Arjuna was granted. Even the gods long to see such a divine form, but it is not easily accessible.
verse52.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | सुदुर्दर्शमिदं रूपं दृष्टवानसि यन्मम | देवा अप्यस्य रूपस्य नित्यं दर्शनकाङ्क्षिणः || 52 ||

verse53.english: nāhaṁ vedair na tapasā na dānena na chejyayā | śhakya evaṁ-vidho draṣhṭuṁ dṛiṣṭavān asi māṁ yathā || 53 ||
verse53.explanation: Krishna reiterates that the vision Arjuna has experienced cannot be attained through ordinary means such as study, austerity, charity, or ritual worship. It is a unique revelation granted by divine grace.
verse53.sanskrit: नाहं वेदैर्न तपसा न दानेन न चेज्यया | शक्य एवंविधो द्रष्टुं दृष्टवानसि मां यथा || 53 ||

verse54.english: bhaktyā tv ananyayā śhakya aham evaṁ-vidho ’rjuna | jñātuṁ draṣhṭuṁ cha tattvena praveṣhṭuṁ cha paraṁ-tapa || 54 ||
verse54.explanation: Krishna reveals that it is through exclusive and unwavering devotion (bhakti) that one can truly see, know, and enter into His divine nature. Devotion surpasses all other spiritual practices in attaining a direct experience of God.
verse54.sanskrit: भक्त्या त्वनन्यया शक्य अहमेवंविधोऽर्जुन | ज्ञातुं द्रष्टुं च तत्वेन प्रवेष्टुं च परंतप || 54 ||

verse55.english: mat-karma-kṛin mat-paramo mad-bhaktaḥ saṅga-varjitaḥ | nirvairaḥ sarva-bhūteṣhu yaḥ sa mām eti pāṇḍava || 55 ||
verse55.explanation: Krishna concludes by describing the qualities of a true devotee who will reach Him: one who performs actions dedicated to Krishna, sees Krishna as the Supreme Being, is free from attachments, and harbors no hatred towards others. Such a person, Krishna assures, will surely attain Him.
verse55.sanskrit: मत्कर्मकृन्मत्परमो मद्भक्तः सङ्गवर्जितः | निर्वैरः सर्वभूतेषु यः स मामेति पाण्डव || 55 ||

verse1.english: arjuna uvāca evaṁ satata-yuktā ye bhaktāḥ parameṣṭhināḥ adhikāṁ te ’pi yaḥ prahāṇāya mām anyaḥ prapadyate
verse1.explanation: Arjuna inquires from Krishna about the different paths of worship. He asks Krishna to explain which path is superior: the worship of a personal God with form or the worship of the formless, unmanifest, imperishable aspect of the Divine. This question sets the stage for Krishna's teachings on the various forms of devotion and their significance.
verse1.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच एवं सततयुक्ता ये भक्ताः परमेष्ठिनः अधिकं तेऽपि यः प्रहणाय मामन्युः प्रपद्यते

verse2.english: śhrī-bhagavān uvāca kṣhetragyaṁ chāpi māṁ viddhi sarva-bhūtāntar-ātmanam kṣhetra-kṣhetragna-yoḥ nāmakuṁ pi mano ’vasan
verse2.explanation: Krishna responds to Arjuna's query by stating that those who are fully devoted to Him, with their minds fixed on Him and who worship Him with unwavering faith and devotion, are considered the most accomplished in yoga. This verse emphasizes the importance of single-minded devotion and faith in achieving spiritual perfection.
verse2.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच क्षेत्रज्ञं चापि मां विद्धि सर्वभूतान्तरात्मनम् क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोर्नां यथा नं कुप्पि मनोऽवसन्

verse3.english: na dhyāna-yoga-vijñāna sattvātma-mayātmanāḥ manovṛtte śīlāsu vigrahārūpāṇi tu
verse3.explanation: Krishna begins to describe the characteristics of the formless, unmanifest aspect of the Divine that some devotees worship. This path involves devotion to that which is beyond physical form, incomprehensible, unchanging, and eternal. Krishna highlights the qualities of this path to compare it with the path of personal devotion to a deity with form. The verse sets the stage for the following explanations regarding the nature of worship and spiritual paths.
verse3.sanskrit: न ध्यानयोगविज्ञान सत्त्वात्ममयात्मनः मनोवृत्ते शीलासु विग्रहरूपाणि तु

verse4.english: ananyāśh chintayanto māṁ ye janāḥ parameśhvaram praṇāmānena sadā bhaaktiṁ sadā yathāḥ
verse4.explanation: Krishna explains that those who control their senses, remain even-minded in all situations, and are dedicated to the welfare of all beings, ultimately attain Him. This verse emphasizes the qualities of self-control, equanimity, and universal compassion as essential aspects of the spiritual path that leads to the realization of the Divine, whether one worships a personal form or the formless aspect of God.
verse4.sanskrit: अनन्याश्चिन्तयन्तो मां ये जनाः परमेश्वरम् प्रणामेन सदा भक्तिं सदा यथाः

verse5.english: kleśho ’dhikataras teṣhām vyavasāya-yoginām plavam āyodyām duḥkha-śheṣhaḥ
verse5.explanation: Krishna points out that the path of worshipping the formless, unmanifest aspect of the Divine is more challenging and difficult. This is because it requires abstract thinking and detachment from the physical world, which can be hard for those who are embodied and identified with their bodies. Krishna suggests that while both paths lead to the same ultimate goal, the path of personal devotion to a deity with form is easier for most people.

verse6.english: catur-vidhā bhajante māṁ janāḥ sukṛitino ’rjuna ārto jijñāsur arthārthī jnānī cha bharatarṣhābha
verse6.explanation: Krishna describes the path of devotion where devotees surrender all their actions to Him, seeing Him as the ultimate purpose of life. These devotees focus solely on Krishna with unwavering concentration and devotion. This verse emphasizes the importance of surrender, single-minded focus, and the complete dedication of one's actions to God as a path to spiritual realization.
verse6.sanskrit: चतुर्विधा भजन्ते मां जनाः सुकृतिनोऽर्जुन आर्तो जिज्ञासुरर्थार्थी ज्ञानī च भरतर्षभ

verse7.english: teṣhām satya-bhaktānām yoga-kshemaṁ avāpnuyaat ātma-bhāvena saccid-ānandaṁ bhūtāya bhūta-maṇiḥ
verse7.explanation: Krishna assures that those who wholeheartedly focus their minds on Him and dedicate their lives to Him will be swiftly liberated from the cycle of birth and death. He promises to be their deliverer, helping them overcome the difficulties of material existence and attain spiritual liberation. This verse highlights the protective and compassionate nature of God towards His devoted followers.
verse7.sanskrit: तेषां सत्यभक्तानां योगक्षेममवाप्नुयात् आत्मभावेन सच्चिदानन्दं भूताय भूतमणिः

verse8.english: mayy eva mana ādhatsva mayi buddhiṁ niveśaya nivasiṣyasi mayy eva ata ūrdhvaṁ na sanśhayaḥ
verse8.explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to focus his mind and intellect solely on Him. By doing so, Arjuna will certainly reside in Krishna, indicating a deep union with the Divine. This verse emphasizes the importance of total mental and intellectual dedication to God as the means to achieve spiritual unity and eternal peace.
verse8.sanskrit: मय्येव मन आधत्स्व मयि बुद्धिं निवेशय निवसिष्यसि मय्येव अत ऊर्ध्वं न संशयः

verse9.english: atha chittaṁ samādhātuṁ na śhaknoṣhi mayi sthiram abhyāsa-yogena tato mām ichāptuṁ dhanañjaya
verse9.explanation: Krishna acknowledges that it may be difficult for some to maintain a steady focus on Him. He suggests the practice of abhyasa-yoga, or the repeated practice of concentration, as a means to gradually train the mind and attain a connection with the Divine. This verse emphasizes the value of consistent effort and practice in the spiritual journey, offering an alternative path for those who struggle with direct and continuous focus on God.
verse9.sanskrit: अथ चित्तं समाधातुं न शक्नोषि मयि स्थिरम् अभ्यासयोगेन ततो मामिच्छाप्तुं धनञ्जय

verse10.english: abhyāse ’py asamartho ’si mat-karma-paramo bhava mad-artham api karmāṇi kurvan siddhim avāpsyasi
verse10.explanation: Krishna provides a practical approach for those who may find it difficult to maintain direct worship or meditation. He suggests that if direct worship or meditation is challenging, one can engage in selfless service or develop devotion and self-discipline as alternatives. This verse encourages a gradual and adaptable approach to spiritual practice, acknowledging that different paths can lead to liberation based on one's abilities and circumstances.
verse10.sanskrit: अभ्यासेऽप्यसमर्थोऽसि मत्कर्मपरमो भव मदर्थमपि कर्माणि कुर्वन्सिद्धिमवाप्स्यसि

verse11.english: athaitad apy aśhakto ’si kartum mad-yogam āśhritaḥ sarva-karma-phala-tyāgaṁ tataḥ kuru yatātmavān
verse11.explanation: Krishna offers guidance for those who find even self-discipline challenging. He suggests that one should at least practice self-control and maintain a calm mind. By focusing on detachment from the fruits of actions and finding contentment in one’s efforts, one can still make spiritual progress. This verse emphasizes the importance of self-regulation and inner peace in spiritual practice.
verse11.sanskrit: अथैतदप्यशक्तोऽसि कर्तुं मद्योगमाश्रितः सर्वकर्मफलत्यागं ततः कुरु यतात्मवान्

verse12.english: śhreyo hi jñānam abhyāsāj jñānād dhyānaṁ viśhiṣhyate dhyānāt karma-phala-tyāgas tyāgāc chhāntir anantaram
verse12.explanation: Krishna indicates that practicing devotion (bhakti-yoga) is superior to the pursuit of knowledge (jnana-yoga). He emphasizes that steadfast practice in devotion leads to inner equanimity and the ultimate well-being of the soul. This verse highlights the importance of devotion and steadfastness on the spiritual path as essential for attaining spiritual growth and ultimate liberation.

verse13.english: adveṣṭā sarva-bhūtānāṁ maitraḥ karuṇa eva cha nirmamo nirahankāraḥ sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ kṣhamī
verse13.explanation: Krishna describes the qualities of a true devotee: one who harbors no ill-will towards any being, is kind and compassionate, detached from material possessions, always content, and maintains self-control. Such a person is steadfast in their practice and remains calm in various situations. This verse outlines the virtues that lead to spiritual growth and realization, emphasizing inner qualities over external achievements.
verse13.sanskrit: अद्वेष्टा सर्वभूतानां मैत्रः करुण एव च निर्ममो निरहंकारः समदुःखसुखः क्षमी

verse14.english: saṁtuṣhṭaḥ satataṁ yogī yatātmā dṛiḍha-niśhchayaḥ mayy arpita-mano-buddhir yo mad-bhaktaḥ sa me priyaḥ
verse14.explanation: Krishna explains that a person who is dedicated to Yoga, whose mind is purified and controlled, remains unaffected by both suffering and pleasure. This individual has achieved mastery over their own mind and emotions, displaying a balanced approach to life's experiences. The verse underscores the inner strength and equanimity required to remain stable in the face of life's challenges and joys.
verse14.sanskrit: संतुष्टः सततं योगी यतात्मा दृढ़निश्चयः मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्यो मद्भक्तः स मे प्रियः

verse15.english: yasmān nodvijate loko lokān nodvijate cha yaḥ harṣhāmarṣha-bhayo-dvegair mukto yaḥ sa cha me priyaḥ
verse15.explanation: Krishna describes the characteristics of a true yogi. Such a person is free from envy, always content, and steadfast in their practice. They are wise, bring peace and happiness to others, and maintain a calm demeanor. This verse highlights the importance of inner peace and the positive impact of one's spiritual practice on themselves and those around them.
verse15.sanskrit: यस्मान्नोद्विजते लोको लोकान्नोद्विजते च यः हर्षामर्षभयोद्वेगैर्मुक्तो यः स च मे प्रियः

verse16.english: anapekṣhaḥ śhuchir dakṣhaḥ udāsīno gata-vyathaḥ sarvārambha-parityāgī yo mad-bhaktaḥ sa me priyaḥ
verse16.explanation: Krishna explains the distinction between the eternal and the temporary. The unreal, or that which is impermanent, does not truly exist, while the real, or the eternal, does not cease to be. This verse emphasizes the nature of reality and the importance of understanding what is eternal versus what is transient, guiding one toward the realization of the eternal truth.
verse16.sanskrit: अनपेक्षः शुचिर्दक्षः उदासीनो गतव्यथः सर्वारम्भपरित्यागी यो मद्भक्तः स मे प्रियः

verse17.english: yo na hṛiṣhyati na dveṣhṭi na śhochati na kāṅkṣhati śhubhāśhubha-parityāgī bhaktimān yaḥ sa me priyaḥ
verse17.explanation: Krishna describes the qualities of a sage or a true yogi.
