Such a person remains undisturbed by both pleasure and pain, is free from desires, fears, and anger, and maintains a steady, calm mind. This steadiness and detachment from emotional disturbances reflect a high level of spiritual maturity and inner peace.
verse17.sanskrit: यो न हृष्यति न द्वेष्टि न शोचति न काङ्क्षति शुभाशुभपरित्यागी भक्तिमान्यः स मे प्रियः

verse18.english: sarva-bhūta-sthitaṁ yo māṁ bhajaty ekatvam āśhritaḥ sarva-bhūtān ātmānaṁ sarva-bhūtāni paśhyati
verse18.explanation: Krishna explains that a person who is free from attachment and views all beings with equal vision, treating them all the same regardless of circumstances, achieves spiritual perfection. Such a person remains unaffected by pleasure or pain, maintaining inner balance and equanimity. This verse emphasizes the importance of non-attachment and equality in the spiritual path.
verse18.sanskrit: सर्वभूतस्थितं यो मां भजत्येकत्वमाश्रितः सर्वभूतान्यात्मानं सर्वभूतानि पश्यति

verse19.english: yo na hṛiṣhyati na dveṣhṭi na śhochati na kāṅkṣhati udāsīno bhagavaty sarva-bhūtāny ātmānaṁ paśhyati
verse19.explanation: Krishna describes the qualities of a truly devoted person. Such an individual does not experience joy or hatred, does not grieve, and does not desire the results of actions. Instead, they have renounced the attachment to outcomes and maintain a state of constant devotion and inner happiness. This verse highlights the contentment and peace that arise from renunciation and devotion.
verse19.sanskrit: यो न हृष्यति न द्वेष्टि न शोचति न काङ्क्षति उदासीनो भगवत्य सर्वभूतान्यात्मनं पश्यति

verse20.english: yo māṁ paśhyati sarvatra sarvaṁ cha māṁ paśhyati tasyāhaṁ na praṇaśhyāmi sa cha me na praṇaśhyati
verse20.explanation: Krishna indicates that those who are devoted to Him and dedicated to the Supreme Reality achieve the ultimate happiness and fulfillment. This verse emphasizes that through sincere devotion and worship of the Divine, one can attain the highest state of spiritual contentment and inner peace.
verse20.sanskrit: यो मां पश्यति सर्वत्र सर्वं च मां पश्यति तस्याहं न प्रणश्यामि स च मे न प्रणश्यति

verse1.english: arjuna uvācha prakṛitīṃ kṣhetra-kṣhetragña-yoh vyākhyaṃ pūrvaṃ bhagavān
verse1.explanation: Arjuna begins to question Krishna about the nature of the body and the soul, the distinction between the physical field and the knower of the field, and what constitutes true understanding. This sets the stage for Krishna's explanation of the field (the body) and the knower of the field (the soul), as well as the broader concepts of material and spiritual realities.
verse1.sanskrit: अरञ्जश्च हृदये च क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोः प्रकृत्यैव वाक्यं विप्रति स्त्रीति भागदः

verse2.english: vedāntakṛid vedavivekī sarvaḥ svadharmaḥ kṣhetra-kṣhetragña-yoh pratiṣṭhitamūlaṁ
verse2.explanation: Krishna explains that the body is referred to as the "field" and the soul as the "knower of the field." True knowledge involves understanding both the field and the knower of the field in their essence. However, Krishna also notes that the supreme knower, or the ultimate reality, is beyond ordinary comprehension. This verse introduces the concepts of the body and soul while acknowledging the difficulty in fully grasping the ultimate divine principle.

verse3.english: jñānena tu taj-jñeyam sarvam etad avasthitam veda-pranidhānaṁ hi jñānaṁ sākṣhāt-kṛitaṁ yathā
verse3.explanation: Krishna asserts that the concepts of the "field" (the body) and the "knower of the field" (the soul) are understood through wisdom and knowledge. He emphasizes that true knowledge is that which leads to direct realization and is aligned with the teachings of the Vedas. This verse underscores the importance of acquiring spiritual wisdom to grasp the ultimate truth of the self and the nature of reality.
verse3.sanskrit: ज्ञानेन तु तज्ज्ञेयम् सर्वमेतदवस्थितम् वेदप्रणिधानं हि ज्ञानं साक्षात्कृतं यथा

verse4.english: kṣhetra-kṣhetragñayoḥ evaṁ prakṛitiṁ prakṛitiṁ veda-veda-pātram vijñāya vayaṁ prapadyate
verse4.explanation: Krishna reinforces the idea that understanding the difference between the physical body (the field) and the soul (the knower of the field) is crucial for gaining true spiritual insight. By recognizing this distinction, one can achieve a deeper understanding of the self and the ultimate reality. This knowledge is fundamental for spiritual growth and realization.
verse4.sanskrit: क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोरेवं प्रकृतिं प्रकृतिं वेदवेदपात्रम् विज्ञाय वयं प्रपद्यते

verse5.english: anāditvādd vitiya-sya śharīrasya cha sattvataḥ vidhiṁ prakāṭāṁ sarvathā dharmamūlaṁ tu yattathā
verse5.explanation: Krishna explains that the physical body, while subject to change, is governed by eternal principles. The understanding of the body’s nature, including its impermanence and connection to the eternal soul, forms the basis of righteous living (Dharma). This verse highlights the idea that true understanding of the body and soul is foundational for living a life aligned with spiritual principles and truth.
verse5.sanskrit: अनादित्वाद्वितीयस्य शरीरस्य च सत्त्वतः विधिं प्रकटां सर्वथा धर्ममूलं तु यत्तथा

verse6.english: saptāśvaraśmākṛitsāraṁ pañcha-bhūta-ātmikaṁ savikāraṁ prapañcārtham vijñānaṁ śuddham ātmany
verse6.explanation: Krishna describes the body as composed of the five fundamental elements and subject to various changes. Understanding this material nature, along with recognizing the eternal, unchanging soul within, constitutes true knowledge. This verse emphasizes the importance of distinguishing between the mutable, physical aspects of existence and the immutable, spiritual essence.
verse6.sanskrit: सप्ताश्वरश्माकृत्सारं पञ्चभूतात्मिकं सविकारं प्रपञ्चार्थम् विज्ञानं शुद्धमात्मनि

verse7.english: amānitvam adamānitvam ahiṁsā śhāntiḥ satva-śhuddhiḥ dharma-mūlaṁ tad yathā
verse7.explanation: Krishna emphasizes the importance of certain virtues as the foundation of true knowledge. These virtues include humility, absence of arrogance, non-violence, truthfulness, and purity of heart. Such qualities are essential for understanding the distinction between the physical body (the field) and the eternal soul (the knower of the field). This verse highlights that spiritual wisdom is reflected in one's character and behavior.
verse7.sanskrit: अमानित्वमदम्बित्वम हिंसाचार्यति अहिंसा सत्त्वशुद्धिः धर्ममूलं तु यत्तथा

verse8.english: amānitvam adamānitvam ahiṁsā śhāntiḥ satva-śhuddhiḥ dharma-mūlaṁ tad yathā
verse8.explanation: Krishna lists essential virtues for those who seek true knowledge and understanding. Humility, absence of arrogance, non-violence, truthfulness, and purity of heart are crucial for recognizing the true nature of the physical body and the soul within. These qualities reflect the inner purity and moral integrity necessary for spiritual growth and understanding.
verse8.sanskrit: अमनित्वमदम्बित्वम हिंसाचार्यति अहिंसा सत्त्वशुद्धिः धर्ममूलं तु यत्तथा

verse9.english: adhishṭhānam iti tu sarvam aśhāsāstram cha yaḥ yaḥ śuchiḥ pathātmanam tasyā tattva-svarūpam
verse9.explanation: Krishna clarifies that the body is the place where all actions occur, while the soul is the ultimate observer of these actions. Understanding this distinction and maintaining inner purity helps one grasp the true nature of reality. This verse emphasizes the importance of recognizing the role of the body in actions and the soul's role as the eternal observer.
verse9.sanskrit: अधिष्ठानमिति तु सर्वमशास्त्रं च यः यः शुचिः पथात्मानं तस्या तत्त्वस्वरूपम्

verse10.english: amānitvam adamānitvam ahiṁsā śhāntiḥ satva-śhuddhiḥ dharma-mūlaṁ tad yathā
verse10.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that recognizing the body as the field of action and the soul as the observer of these actions is fundamental to understanding the nature of reality. This distinction helps one realize the supreme truth and gain a deeper insight into the nature of existence and consciousness.
verse10.sanskrit: अमानित्वमदम्बित्वम हिंसाचार्यति अहिंसा सत्त्वशुद्धिः धर्ममूलं तु यत्तथा

verse11.english: jñānaṁ yat tatsarvaṁ yathārthaṁ tattva-niścayam nālam prapadyate yastu karma-phala-smṛitiḥ
verse11.explanation: Krishna highlights that true knowledge involves comprehending the essence and nature of reality, beyond mere intellectual understanding. It is not about being attached to the results or fruits of one's actions, which indicates a deeper, more profound grasp of spiritual wisdom. This verse emphasizes the importance of realizing the true nature of the self and the universe, rather than being attached to the outcomes of one's actions.
verse11.sanskrit: ज्ञानं यदत्सर्वं यथार्थं तत्त्वनिश्चयम् नालं प्रपण्यते यस्तु कर्मफलस्मृतिः

verse12.english: na hi jñānena sadṛiṣhaṁ pavitram iha vidyate tatsvayam yoga-samprāptaṁ udāsīnaṁ yaccha saḥ
verse12.explanation: Krishna asserts that true knowledge is the most purifying force and that it surpasses all other methods of purification. Attaining this knowledge through yoga leads to a state of impartiality and detachment, where one views all things equally. This emphasizes the transformative power of spiritual wisdom in achieving purity and spiritual realization.
verse12.sanskrit: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते तत्स्वयं योगसंप्राप्तं उदासीनं यत्च सः

verse13.english: jñānena tu taj-jñeyam sarvam etad avasthitam veda-pranidhānaṁ hi jñānaṁ sākṣhāt-kṛitaṁ yathā
verse13.explanation: Krishna explains that true knowledge involves understanding the nature of the physical body (the field) and the soul (the knower of the field). This knowledge aligns with the teachings of the Vedas and leads to direct realization of the ultimate truth. It highlights that recognizing the fundamental nature of existence is central to achieving spiritual insight and enlightenment.
verse13.sanskrit: ज्ञानेन तु तज्ज्ञेयम् सर्वमेतदवस्थितम् वेदप्रणिधानं हि ज्ञानं साक्षात्कृतं यथा

verse14.english: na hi deha-bhṛitā śhakyaṁ tyaktum karmāṇy aśheṣhataḥ yas tu karma-phala-tyāgī sa tyāgīty abidhīyate
verse14.explanation: Krishna acknowledges that it is not feasible for an embodied being to completely abandon all actions. However, true renunciation is characterized by giving up attachment to the results or fruits of one's actions. This verse emphasizes that genuine renunciation involves detachment from the outcomes of actions, rather than the mere cessation of action itself.
verse14.sanskrit: न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते

verse15.english: na hi deha-bhṛitā śhakyaṁ tyaktum karmāṇy aśheṣhataḥ yas tu karma-phala-tyāgī sa tyāgīty abidhīyate
verse15.explanation: Krishna describes the Supreme Self (or the soul) as the eternal witness and enjoyer of all actions. It is the ultimate ruler and source of creation, existing beyond the material world. This verse highlights the transcendental nature of the Supreme Self, which remains unaffected by the actions performed in the material realm
verse15.sanskrit: न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते

verse16.english: avibhaktaṁ cha bhūta-stham tattva-jñāsa paśhyati na areṣṭām na punāti asmin vivaṁ hasti bhāgadā
verse16.explanation: Krishna describes the Supreme Self as indivisible and present within all beings. Despite being the source of all actions, it remains unaffected and pure. Understanding the undivided nature of the Self is crucial for realizing the ultimate truth and attaining spiritual wisdom.
verse16.sanskrit: अविभक्तं च भूतस्थं तत्त्वज्ञासपश्चात् न अरेष्टाम् न पुनात्यस्मिन् विवहस्तो भागदा

verse17.english: avibhaktaṁ cha bhūta-stham na saṁsthyam aitihāsikam sarvātma-bhūtaṁ hi vivekānusṛitamāḥ
verse17.explanation: Krishna highlights that the Supreme Self is the fundamental essence of all existence, undivided and consistent. It remains unchanged despite the diversity of the material world. Understanding this eternal and pervasive Self requires discernment and wisdom, revealing its true nature.
verse17.sanskrit: अविभक्तं च भूतस्थं न संस्त्य तत्त्वमैतिहासिकम् सर्वात्मभूतं हि विवेकानुसृतमाः

verse18.english: brahmaṇo hi prāṇo ’yam prāṇasya prakṛitiṁ prakṛitiṁ chaitanam viveka-sahitām
verse18.explanation: Krishna describes the Supreme Self as the essence of the life force and consciousness, which pervades all living beings. This Self is the fundamental reality that remains undivided and is understood through discernment and wisdom. Recognizing the Self's role as the source of life and consciousness helps one achieve a deeper spiritual understanding.
verse18.sanskrit: ब्रह्मणो हि प्राणोऽयम् प्राणस्य प्रकृतिं प्रकृतिं चैतनं विवेकसहितम्

verse19.english: prakṛitiṁ yānti bhūtāni na hi yānti tattvataḥ ātmanam yathāvat tattvatas tvam itāmy aham
verse19.explanation: Krishna explains that while all beings naturally move towards their destined end, they often lack a full comprehension of the ultimate truth. The realization of the Self, which is the ultimate reality, requires proper understanding and discernment. This verse emphasizes the importance of spiritual wisdom in grasping the true nature of existence.
verse19.sanskrit: प्रकृतिं यान्ति भूतानि न हि यान्ति तत्त्वतः आत्मनं यथावत् तत्त्वतस्त्वमिताम्यहम्

verse20.english: na hi deha-bhṛitā śhakyaṁ tyaktuṁ karmāṇy aśheṣhataḥ yas tu karma-phala-tyāgī sa tyāgīty abidhīyate
verse20.explanation: Krishna acknowledges that it is impossible for any embodied being to entirely abandon all actions. True renunciation is characterized by giving up attachment to the results or fruits of one's actions, rather than abandoning the actions themselves. This verse emphasizes that genuine renunciation involves detachment from outcomes, aligning one's actions with higher spiritual principles.
verse20.sanskrit: न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते

verse21.english: veda-saṁpranidhānaṁ hi puṇya-karma upajīvitam narakaṣya phalaṁ śhrutaṁ vadanti tattva-vidām
verse21.explanation: Krishna points out that the Vedic scriptures state that living a righteous life leads to spiritual progress and liberation. The result of virtuous actions is not only a life of ethical living but also a release from the cycle of rebirth. This understanding is imparted by those who have a deep knowledge of the ultimate truth.
verse21.sanskrit: वेदसंप्रणिधानं हि पुण्यकर्मोपजीवतम् नरकस्य फलं श्रुतं वदन्ति तत्त्वभिदा

verse22.english: kṛiṣhṇo ’yaṁ prāṇam āyati sarva-bhūtānāṁ yastu sarvātmanam yathā tattvataḥ sat-chid-ānanda-daḥ
verse22.explanation: Krishna explains that the Supreme Self, which is the core essence of all living beings, sustains their life and is realized through genuine knowledge. This Self embodies eternal existence, consciousness, and bliss. Understanding the Supreme Self in its true form reveals its fundamental nature as the source of all life and consciousness.
verse22.sanskrit: कृष्णोऽयं प्राणमायति सर्वभूतानां यस्तु सर्वात्मनं यथा तत्त्वतः सच्चिदानंददः

verse23.english: veda-pranidhānaṁ hi puṇya-karma upāsitam mukti-sādhanam bandhe mukti-sādhanam uttamam
verse23.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that understanding the nature of the field (the body) and the knower of the field (the soul) is achieved through righteous actions and adherence to Vedic principles. This knowledge is the highest path to liberation and freedom from the cycle of rebirth. It highlights that combining righteous action with spiritual wisdom is crucial for achieving ultimate liberation.
verse23.sanskrit: वेदप्रणिधानं हि पुण्यकर्म उपासितम् मुक्तिसाधनं बन्धे मुक्तिसाधनमुत्तमम्

verse24.english: upadraṣṭā anuśhṭātā siddhim paśhyati upadraṣṭā sākṣhī cha bhavati tattva-jñānam
verse24.explanation: Krishna describes the Supreme Self as the eternal witness and observer of all actions and their results. The Self, being the ultimate knower of truth, perceives everything but remains unaffected. This verse underscores the role of the Supreme Self as the impartial witness to all actions and outcomes, emphasizing its transcendental nature.
verse24.sanskrit: उपद्रष्टा अनुश्नाता सिद्धिम् पश्यति उपद्रष्टा साक्षी च भवति तत्त्वज्ञानम

verse25.english: yoga-vijñāna-saṅgamaṁ siddhiṁ yāti dhīra-dhīḥ bhāvaḥ sattva-bhāva-stu prakṛitiṁ vidvaj-jātam
verse25.explanation: Krishna explains that a person who diligently practices yoga and attains spiritual knowledge achieves the highest state of perfection. This state goes beyond the material qualities and represents true spiritual realization. It emphasizes that steadfastness in yoga and knowledge leads to ultimate spiritual attainment and freedom from material limitations.
verse25.sanskrit: योगविज्ञानसङ्गनम् सिद्धिं याति धीरधीः भावः सत्त्वभावस्तु प्रकृतिं विद्विजातम्

verse26.english: sarvataḥ pāṇi-pādam sarvataḥ patī kēśavam sarvataḥ pāṇi-pādam sarvataḥ pāṇi-pādam
verse26.explanation: Krishna explains that the Supreme Self is omnipresent and pervades all directions and aspects of existence. This verse highlights the all-encompassing nature of the Self, which transcends physical limitations and is present throughout the universe. Understanding this omnipresence is crucial for recognizing the true nature of reality.
verse26.sanskrit: सर्वतः पाणिपादं सर्वतः पति केशवम् सर्वतः पाणिपादं सर्वतः पाणिपादम्

verse27.english: vivekasya nidhi-prāptiḥ sarva-jñatvaṁ guṇa-ātmakam na hi sattvamanāśritya sattattvā viveka-dhāraṇam
verse27.explanation: Krishna highlights that true spiritual realization and wisdom come from a deep understanding of the Self’s nature and presence. Discerning the true essence of reality, including recognizing the omnipresence of the Self, is key to achieving spiritual enlightenment and liberation. This verse underscores the importance of discernment in spiritual practice.
verse27.sanskrit: विवेकस्य निधिप्राप्ति सर्वज्ञत्वं गुणात्मकम् नहिं सत्वमनाश्रित्य सतत्त्वा विवेकधारणम्

verse28.english: brahma-vidyā vrajet sarva-jñānaṁ guṇāt kṛitam na hi tattvam abhāvitvā satyatvaṁ samāhitam
verse28.explanation: Krishna explains that the knowledge of the Supreme Self, or Brahman, leads to comprehensive understanding and wisdom. This knowledge transcends material qualities and reveals the ultimate truth of existence. Realizing this truth brings one to a state of spiritual enlightenment and unity with the absolute.
verse28.sanskrit: ब्रह्मविद्या व्रजेत् सर्वज्ञाणं गुणात्कृतम् नहिं तत्त्वमभावित्वा सत्यत्वं समाहितम्

verse29.english: na hi deha-bhṛitā śhakyaṁ tyaktuṁ karmāṇy aśheṣhataḥ yas tu karma-phala-tyāgī sa tyāgīty abidhīyate
verse29.explanation: Krishna acknowledges that it is impossible for any embodied being to completely abandon all actions. True renunciation involves detachment from the outcomes or results of actions rather than from actions themselves. A person who relinquishes attachment to the results of their actions, rather than the actions themselves, is considered a true renunciant.
verse29.sanskrit: न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते

verse30.english: upadraṣṭā sākṣhī ca sarvasya-ātma vivikta-bhūṣhaṇā prakṛitya-ātmanah
verse30.explanation: Krishna describes the Supreme Self as the ultimate observer and witness of all actions. It is the fundamental essence of all existence and transcends the material realm. This verse emphasizes the Self's role as the impartial witness to all phenomena, highlighting its transcendental nature beyond the physical world.
verse30.sanskrit: उपद्रष्टा साक्षी च सर्वस्यात्मा विविक्तभूषणा प्रकृत्यात्मनः

verse31.english: na hi deha-bhṛitā śhakyaṁ tyaktuṁ karmāṇy aśheṣhataḥ yas tu karma-phala-tyāgī sa tyāgīty abidhīyate
verse31.explanation: Krishna reaffirms that complete renunciation of all actions is not feasible for any living being. Instead, the true essence of renunciation is to relinquish attachment to the outcomes or fruits of one's actions. A person who does so, while still engaging in necessary actions, is regarded as a true renunciant. This verse underscores the importance of detachment from the results rather than from the actions themselves.
verse31.sanskrit: न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते

verse32.english: sarva-bhūtāni tattva-jñāḥ sarva-jño ’sti pāṇḍava sarv-ātma prapannāni tattvataḥ sadā śṛṇoti
verse32.explanation: Krishna explains that the Supreme Self is the ultimate knower of all things and the essence of every being. It is ever-aware and remains unaffected by the material world. This verse emphasizes the Self's omniscient and transcendental nature, highlighting its role as the constant observer and the core of all existence.
verse32.sanskrit: सर्वभूतानि तत्त्वज्ञाः सर्वज्ञोऽस्ति पाण्डव सर्वात्मा प्रपन्नानि तत्त्वतः सदा शृणोति

verse33.english: sarva-bhūtāstham ātmānaṁ sarva-bhūtāni adhiṣṭhitam sarva-bhūtān ātmānaṁ sarva-bhūtāsthitaṁ
verse33.explanation: Krishna highlights that the Supreme Self is present within all beings and permeates all forms of life. It is the underlying essence that supports and sustains the entire universe, existing both within and beyond all manifestations. This verse underscores the omnipresence and fundamental role of the Self in the cosmos.

verse34.english: na hi deha-bhṛitā śhakyaṁ tyaktuṁ karmāṇy aśheṣhataḥ yas tu karma-phala-tyāgī sa tyāgīty abidhīyate
verse34.explanation: Krishna explains that the Supreme Self observes all actions and remains unaffected by them. It is the eternal essence that transcends the physical body and mind. This verse emphasizes the distinction between the Supreme Self and the transient activities of the material world, highlighting the Self's immutable and transcendent nature.
verse34.sanskrit: न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते

verse35.english: na hi deha-bhṛitā śhakyaṁ tyaktuṁ karmāṇy aśheṣhataḥ yas tu karma-phala-tyāgī sa tyāgīty abidhīyate
verse35.explanation: Krishna explains that the Supreme Self is the eternal observer of all actions but remains unaffected by them. While the Self witnesses all actions, it transcends the material activities and their consequences, maintaining its pure, unchanging nature. This verse underscores the distinction between the Supreme Self and the transient activities of the physical realm.
verse35.sanskrit: न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते

verse1.english: śrībhagavān uvāca paraṁ bhūyaḥ pravakṣyāmi jñānānāṁ jñānam uttamam yaj jñātvā munayaḥ sarve parāṁ siddhim ito gatāḥ
verse1.explanation: Lord Krishna introduces the supreme knowledge that surpasses all others. This knowledge is the key to liberation and perfection, as it has led many sages to transcendence and spiritual fulfillment.
verse1.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच: परं भूयः प्रवक्ष्यामि ज्ञानानां ज्ञानमुत्तमम्। यज्ज्ञात्वा मुनयः सर्वे परां सिद्धिमितो गताः।।

verse2.english: idaṁ jñānam upāśritya mama sādharmyam āgatāḥ sarge 'pi nopajāyante pralaye na vyathanti ca
verse2.explanation: By embracing this knowledge, one attains a divine nature and is not reborn at the time of creation, nor disturbed during the cosmic dissolution.
verse2.sanskrit: इदं ज्ञानमुपाश्रित्य मम साधर्म्यमागता: सर्गेऽपि नोपजायन्ते प्रलये न व्यथन्ति च।।

verse3.english: mama yonir mahad brahma tasmin garbhaṁ dadhāmy aham sambhavaḥ sarvabhūtānāṁ tato bhavati bhārata
verse3.explanation: Krishna explains the cosmic process of creation. He, as the divine, impregnates the material nature, Brahman, leading to the manifestation of all life forms. This verse highlights Krishna's role as the ultimate creator.
verse3.sanskrit: महद्ब्रह्म तस्मिन्गर्भं दधाम्यहम् सम्भव: सर्वभूतानां ततो भवति भारत।।

verse4.english: sarva-yoniṣu kaunteya mūrtayaḥ sambhavanti yāḥ tāsāṁ brahma mahadyonir ahaṁ bīja-pradaḥ pitā
verse4.explanation: Krishna states that He is the seed-giving father of all life forms, uniting all creatures in a single cosmic family. While material nature provides the body, the soul’s origin and sustenance come from Krishna.
verse4.sanskrit: सर्वयोनिषु कौन्तेय मूर्तयः सम्भवन्ति या: तासां ब्रह्म महद्योनिरहं बीजप्रदः पिता।।

verse5.english: sattvaṁ rajas tama iti guṇāḥ prakṛti-sambhavāḥ nibadhnanti mahābāho dehe dehinam avyayam
verse5.explanation: The verse introduces the three gunas or modes of material nature. These qualities bind the soul to the material body, influencing behavior and consciousness, and shaping a person’s actions and outlook on life.
verse5.sanskrit: सत्त्वं रजस्तम इति गुणा: प्रकृतिसम्भवा: निबध्नन्ति महाबाहो देहे देहिनमव्ययम्।।

verse6.english: tatra sattvaṁ nirmalatvāt prakāśakam anāmayam sukhasaṅgena badhnāti jñānasaṅgena cānagha
verse6.explanation: Sattva is pure and leads to knowledge and happiness, but it still binds the soul through attachment to these qualities.
verse6.sanskrit: तत्र सत्त्वं निर्मलत्वात्प्रकाशकमनामयम्। सुखसङ्गेन बध्नाति ज्ञानसङ्गेन चानघ।।

verse7.english: rajo rāgātmakaṁ viddhi tṛṣṇāsaṅgasamudbhavam tannibadhnāti kaunteya karmasaṅgena dehinam
verse7.explanation: Rajas is associated with passion and action, leading to attachment and the desire for outcomes.
verse7.sanskrit: रजो रागात्मकं विद्धि तृष्णासङ्गसमुद्भवम्। तन्निबध्नाति कौन्तेय कर्मसङ्गेन देहिनम्।।

verse8.english: tamas tv ajñānajaṁ viddhi mohanaṁ sarvadehinām pramādālasya-nidrābhis tan nibadhnāti bhārata
verse8.explanation: Tamas, born from ignorance, leads to delusion and binds the soul through laziness, negligence, and sleep.
verse8.sanskrit: तमस्त्वज्ञानजं विद्धि मोहनं सर्वदेहिनाम्। प्रमादालस्यनिद्राभिस्तन्निबध्नाति भारत।।

verse9.english: sattvaṁ sukhe saṁjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata jñānam āvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde saṁjayaty uta
verse9.explanation: Each Guna binds the soul in different ways: Sattva through happiness, Rajas through action, and Tamas through ignorance.
verse9.sanskrit: सत्त्वं सुखे सञ्जयति रजः कर्मणि भारत। ज्ञानमावृत्य तु तमः प्रमादे सञ्जयत्युत।।

verse10.english: rajas tamaś ca abhibhūya sattvaṁ bhavati bhārata rajaḥ sattvaṁ tamaś ca eva tamaḥ sattvaṁ rajas tathā
verse10.explanation: The three Gunas are constantly in conflict, with each taking dominance at different times.
verse10.sanskrit: रजस्तमश्चाभिभूय सत्त्वं भवति भारत। रजः सत्त्वं तमश्चैव तमः सत्त्वं रजस्तथा।।

verse11.english: sarvadvāreṣu dehe 'smin prakāśa upajāyate jñānaṁ yadā tadā vidyād vivṛddhaṁ sattvam ity uta
verse11.explanation: When knowledge illuminates all aspects of life, it indicates the dominance of Sattva.
verse11.sanskrit: सर्वद्वारेषु देहेऽस्मिन्प्रकाश उपजायते। ज्ञानं यदा तदा विद्याद्विवृद्धं सत्त्वमित्युत।।

verse12.english: lobhaḥ pravṛttir ārambhaḥ karmaṇām aśamaḥ spṛhā rajasy etāni jāyante vivṛddhe bharatarṣabha
verse12.explanation: When Rajas is dominant, it manifests as greed, restlessness, and an intense desire to act.
verse12.sanskrit: लोभः प्रवृत्तिरारम्भः कर्मणामशमः स्पृहा। रजस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे भरतर्षभ।।

verse13.english: aprakāśo 'pravṛttiś ca pramādo moha eva ca tamasy etāni jāyante vivṛddhe kurunandana
verse13.explanation: Tamas leads to darkness, inactivity, and delusion when it prevails over the other Gunas.
verse13.sanskrit: अप्रकाशोऽप्रवृत्तिश्च प्रमादो मोह एव च। तमस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे कुरुनन्दन।।

verse14.english: yadā sattve pravṛddhe tu pralayaṁ yāti deha-bhṛt tadottama-vidāṁ lokān amālān pratipadyate
verse14.explanation: Those who die in a state of Sattva go to higher, pure realms, aligning with the wise and enlightened.
verse14.sanskrit: यदा सत्त्वे प्रवृद्धे तु प्रलयं याति देहभृत्। तदोत्तमविदां लोकानमलान्प्रतिपद्यते।।

verse15.english: rajasi pralayaṁ gatvā karma-saṅgiṣu jāyate tathā pralīnas tamasi mūḍha-yoniṣu jāyate
verse15.explanation: A person who dies in Rajas is reborn among those attached to action, while dying in Tamas leads to birth in ignorance.
verse15.sanskrit: रजसि प्रलयं गत्वा कर्मसङ्गिषु जायते। तथा प्रलीनस्तमसि मूढयोनिषु जायते।।

verse16.english: karmaṇaḥ su-kṛtasya āhuḥ sāttvikaṁ nirmalaṁ phalam rajasas tu phalaṁ duḥkham ajñānaṁ tamasaḥ phalam
verse16.explanation: Good actions yield pure and positive results (Sattvic), actions driven by Rajas bring pain, and actions driven by Tamas result in ignorance.
verse16.sanskrit: कर्मणः सुकृतस्याहुः सात्त्विकं निर्मलं फलम्। रजसस्तु फलं दुःखमज्ञानं तमसः फलम्।।

verse17.english: sattvāt saṁjāyate jñānaṁ rajaso lobha eva ca pramāda-mohau tamaso bhavato 'jñānam eva ca
verse17.explanation: Sattva gives rise to knowledge, Rajas to greed, and Tamas to ignorance and delusion.
verse17.sanskrit: सत्त्वात्सञ्जायते ज्ञानं रजसो लोभ एव च। प्रमादमोहौ तमसो भवतोऽज्ञानमेव च।।

verse18.english: ūrdhvaṁ gacchanti sattva-sthā madhye tiṣṭhanti rājasāḥ jaghanya-guṇa-vṛtti-sthā adho gacchanti tāmasāḥ
verse18.explanation: Individuals dominated by Sattva ascend spiritually, those in Rajas remain in the middle, and those in Tamas decline.
verse18.sanskrit: ऊर्ध्वं गच्छन्ति सत्त्वस्था मध्ये तिष्ठन्ति राजसाः। जघन्यगुणवृत्तिस्था अधो गच्छन्ति तामसाः।।

verse19.english: nānyaṁ guṇebhyaḥ kartāraṁ yadā draṣṭā 'nupaśyati guṇebhyaś ca paraṁ vetti mad-bhāvaṁ so 'dhigacchati
verse19.explanation: Understanding that the Gunas are responsible for all actions, and realizing the Supreme beyond them, leads to liberation.
verse19.sanskrit: नान्यं गुणेभ्यः कर्तारं यदा द्रष्टानुपश्यति। गुणेभ्यश्च परं वेत्ति मद्भावं सोऽधिगच्छति।।

verse20.english: guṇān etān atītya trīn dehī deha-samudbhavān janma-mṛtyu-jarā-duḥkhair vimukto 'mṛtam aśnute
verse20.explanation: By transcending the Gunas, one becomes free from the cycle of birth and death and attains immortality.

verse21.english: arjuna uvāca: kair liṅgais trīn guṇān etān atīto bhavati prabho kim ācāraḥ kathaṁ caitāṁs trīn guṇān ativartate
verse21.explanation: Arjuna inquires about the characteristics and behavior of a person who has transcended the Gunas.
verse21.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। कैर्लिङ्गैस्त्रीन्गुणानेतानतीतो भवति प्रभो। किमाचारः कथं चैतांस्त्रीन्गुणानतिवर्तते।।

verse22.english: śrībhagavān uvāca prakāśaṁ ca pravṛttiṁ ca moham eva ca pāṇḍava na dveṣṭi sampravṛttāni na nivṛttāni kāṅkṣati
verse22.explanation: Krishna describes the one who is indifferent to the presence or absence of the Gunas.
verse22.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। प्रकाशं च प्रवृत्तिं च मोहमेव च पाण्डव। न द्वेष्टि सम्प्रवृत्तानि न निवृत्तानि काङ्क्षति।।

verse23.english: udāsīna-vad āsīno guṇair yo na vicālyate guṇā vartanta ity eva yo 'vatiṣṭhati neṅgate
verse23.explanation: The person who transcends the Gunas remains unaffected by them, staying steady and unconcerned.
verse23.sanskrit: उदासीनवदासीनो गुणैर्यो न विचाल्यते। गुणा वर्तन्त इत्येव योऽवतिष्ठति नेङ्गते।।

verse24.english: sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ svasthaḥ sama-loṣṭāśma-kāñcanaḥ tulya-priyāpriyo dhīras tulya-nindātma-saṁstutiḥ
verse24.explanation: Such a person is balanced in all situations, seeing everything with equanimity and detachment

verse25.english: mānāpamānayos tulyo tulyo mitrāri-pakṣayoḥ sarvārambha-parityāgī guṇātītaḥ sa ucyate
verse25.explanation: They are unaffected by honor, dishonor, friendship, or enmity and are free from the desire to act.
verse25.sanskrit: मानापमानयोस्तुल्यस्तुल्यो मित्रारिपक्षयोः। सर्वारम्भपरित्यागी गुणातीतः स उच्यते।।

verse26.english: māṁ ca yo 'vyabhicāreṇa bhakti-yogena sevate sa guṇān samatītyaitān brahma-bhūyāya kalpate
verse26.explanation: Devotion to Krishna leads to transcending the Gunas and attaining the state of Brahman
verse26.sanskrit: मां च योऽव्यभिचारेण भक्तियोगेन सेवते। स गुणान्समतीत्यैतान्ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते।।

verse27.english: brahmaṇo hi pratiṣṭhāham amṛtasya avyayasya ca śāśvatasya ca dharmasya sukhasya aikāntikasya ca
verse27.explanation: Krishna declares Himself as the foundation of Brahman, eternal truth, and supreme bliss.
verse27.sanskrit: ब्रह्मणो हि प्रतिष्ठाहममृतस्याव्ययस्य च। शाश्वतस्य च धर्मस्य सुखस्यैकान्तिकस्य च।।

verse1.english: Ūrdhva-mūlam adhaḥ-śākham aśvatthaṁ prāhur avyayam। Chhandāṁsi yasya parṇāni yas taṁ veda sa vedavit॥
verse1.explanation: The Blessed Lord said: "They speak of an eternal Ashvattha tree, with its roots above and branches below, whose leaves are the Vedic hymns. One who knows this tree is a knower of the Vedas."
verse1.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच: ऊर्ध्वमूलमधःशाखमश्वत्थं प्राहुरव्ययम्। छन्दांसि यस्य पर्णानि यस्तं वेद स वेदवित्।।

verse2.english: Na rūpam asyeha tathopalabhyate nānto na cādir na ca saṁpratiṣṭhā। Aśvattham enaṁ su-virūḍha-mūlaṁ asaṅga-śastreṇa dṛḍhena chittvā॥
verse2.explanation: The tree's branches, representing the various forms of life, grow in all directions, fueled by the Gunas (qualities of nature), while the roots symbolize the attachment that binds beings to the cycle of karma.
verse2.sanskrit: अधश्चोर्ध्वं प्रसृतास्तस्य शाखा गुणप्रवृद्धा विषयप्रवाला:। अधश्च मूलान्यनुसन्ततानि कर्मानुबन्धीनि मनुष्यलोके।।

verse3.english: Tataḥ padaṁ tat-parimārgitavyaṁ yasmin gatā na nivartanti bhūyaḥ। Tam eva cādyaṁ puruṣaṁ prapadye yataḥ pravṛttiḥ prasṛtā purāṇī॥
verse3.explanation: The tree of life, rooted deeply in material existence, is difficult to perceive and even harder to escape from. However, it can be severed by the sword of detachment.
verse3.sanskrit: न रूपमस्येह तथोपलभ्यते नान्तो न चादिर्न च संप्रतिष्ठा। अश्वत्थमेनं सुविरूढमूलमसङ्गशस्त्रेण दृढेन छित्त्वा।।

verse4.english: Nirmāna-mohā jita-saṅga-doṣā adhyātma-nityā vinivṛtta-kāmāḥ। Dvandvair vimuktāḥ sukha-duḥkha-saṁjñair gacchanty amūḍhāḥ padam avyayaṁ tat॥
verse4.explanation: After detaching oneself from the material world, one should seek the ultimate reality, the eternal abode, where one does not return to the cycle of birth and death.
verse4.sanskrit: ततः पदं तत्परिमार्गितव्यं यस्मिन्गता न निवर्तन्ति भूयः। तमेव चाद्यं पुरुषं प्रपद्ये यतः प्रवृत्तिः प्रसृता पुराणी।।

verse5.english: Na tat-bhāsayate sūryo na śaśāṅko na pāvakaḥ। Yad gatvā na nivartante tad dhāma paramaṁ mama॥
verse5.explanation: Those who transcend ego, ignorance, attachment, and dualities, who dwell in the Self, and who are free from worldly desires attain the eternal, unchanging state of liberation.
verse5.sanskrit: निर्मानमोहा जितसङ्गदोषा अध्यात्मनित्या विनिवृत्तकामाः। द्वन्द्वैर्विमुक्ताः सुखदुःखसंज्ञैर्गच्छन्त्यमूढाः पदमव्ययं तत्।।

verse6.english: Mamaivāṁśo jīva-loke jīva-bhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ। Manaḥ-ṣaṣṭhānīndriyāṇi prakṛti-sthāni karṣati॥
verse6.explanation: The supreme abode of Krishna, unlike the material world, does not require external illumination. Once one attains it, they are freed from the cycle of rebirth.
verse6.sanskrit: न तद्भासयते सूर्यो न शशाङ्को न पावकः। यद्गत्वा न निवर्तन्ते तद्धाम परमं मम।।

verse7.english: Śarīraṁ yad avāpnoti yac cāpy utkrāmatīśvaraḥ। Gṛhītvaitāni saṁyāti vāyur gandhān ivāśayāt॥
verse7.explanation: Each soul is a part of Krishna, carrying with it the mind and senses, which are tied to the material world through nature.
verse7.sanskrit: ममैवांशो जीवलोके जीवभूतः सनातनः। मनःषष्ठानीन्द्रियाणि प्रकृतिस्थानि कर्षति।।

verse8.english: Yad āditya-gataṁ tejo jagad bhāsayate'khilam। Yac-candramasi yac-cāgnau tat-tejo viddhi māmakam॥
verse8.explanation: Just as the wind carries scents from one place to another, the soul carries the mind and senses from one body to the next during rebirth.
verse8.sanskrit: शरीरं यदवाप्नोति यच्चाप्युत्क्रामतीश्वरः। गृहीत्वैतानि संयाति वायुर्गन्धानिवाशयात्।।

verse9.english: Śrotraṁ cakṣuḥ sparśanaṁ ca rasanaṁ ghrāṇam eva ca। Adhiṣṭhāya manaś cāyaṁ viṣayān upasevate॥
verse9.explanation: The soul, through the mind and senses, experiences the pleasures and pains of the material world.
verse9.sanskrit: श्रोत्रं चक्षुः स्पर्शनं च रसनं घ्राणमेव च। अधिष्ठाय मनश्चायं विषयानुपसेवते।।

verse10.english: Utkrāmantaṁ sthitaṁ vā'pi bhuñjānaṁ vā guṇānvitam। Vimūḍhā nānupaśyanti paśyanti jñāna-cakṣuṣaḥ॥
verse10.explanation: Only the wise, who have the vision of knowledge, can perceive the soul's journey through life and its eventual liberation
verse10.sanskrit: उत्क्रामन्तं स्थितं वाऽपि भुञ्जानं वा गुणान्वितम्। विमूढा नानुपश्यन्ति पश्यन्ति ज्ञानचक्षुषः।।

verse11.english: Yatanto yoginaś cainaṁ paśyanty ātman-yavasthitam। Yatanto'py akṛtātmāno nainaṁ paśyanty acetasaḥ॥
verse11.explanation: Yogis, who purify themselves through discipline, can perceive the soul within, whereas those lacking refinement and awareness cannot.
verse11.sanskrit: यतन्तो योगिनश्चैनं पश्यन्त्यात्मन्यवस्थितम्। यतन्तोऽप्यकृतात्मानो नैनं पश्यन्त्यचेतसः।।

verse12.english: Yad āditya-gataṁ tejo jagad bhāsayate'khilam। Yac-candramasi yac-cāgnau tat-tejo viddhi māmakam॥
verse12.explanation: Krishna declares that the light in the sun, moon, and fire, which illuminates the universe, is a manifestation of His divine energy.
verse12.sanskrit: यदादित्यगतं तेजो जगद्भासयतेऽखिलम्। यच्चन्द्रमसि यच्चाग्नौ तत्तेजो विद्धि मामकम्।।

verse13.english: Gām āviśya ca bhūtāni dhārayāmy aham ojasā। Puṣṇāmi cauṣadhīḥ sarvāḥ somo bhūtvā rasātmakaḥ॥
verse13.explanation: Krishna sustains all life on earth, nourishing plants and beings through His divine presence and energy.
verse13.sanskrit: गामाविश्य च भूतानि धारयाम्यहमोजसा। पुष्णामि चौषधीः सर्वाः सोमो भूत्वा रसात्मकः।।

verse14.english: Ahaṁ vaiśvānaro bhūtvā prāṇināṁ deham āśritaḥ। Prāṇāpāna-samāyuktaḥ pacāmy annaṁ catur-vidham॥
verse14.explanation: Krishna explains how He manifests as the vital fire in all living beings, aiding in the digestion and assimilation of food.
verse14.sanskrit: अहं वैश्वानरो भूत्वा प्राणिनां देहमाश्रितः। प्राणापानसमायुक्तः पचाम्यन्नं चतुर्विधम्।।

verse15.english: Sarvasya cāhaṁ hṛdi sanniviṣṭo mattaḥ smṛtir jñānam apohanaṁ ca। Vedaiś ca sarvair aham eva vedyo vedānta-kṛd veda-vid eva cāham॥
verse15.explanation: Krishna resides in the hearts of all beings, controlling memory, knowledge, and forgetfulness. He is the ultimate goal of the Vedas and the creator and knower of all wisdom.
verse15.sanskrit: सर्वस्य चाहं हृदि सन्निविष्टो मत्तः स्मृतिर्ज्ञानमपोहनं च। वेदैश्च सर्वैरहमेव वेद्यो वेदान्तकृद्वेदविदेव चाहम्।।

verse16.english: Dvāv imau puruṣau loke kṣaraś cākṣara eva ca। Kṣaraḥ sarvāṇi bhūtāni kūṭa-stho'kṣara ucyate॥
verse16.explanation: The world consists of two types of beings: the perishable (all living entities) and the imperishable (the unchanging soul or Kutastha).
verse16.sanskrit: द्वाविमौ पुरुषौ लोके क्षरश्चाक्षर एव च। क्षरः सर्वाणि भूतानि कूटस्थोऽक्षर उच्यते।।

verse17.english: Uttamaḥ puruṣas tv anyaḥ paramātmety udāhṛtaḥ। Yo loka-trayam āviśya bibharty avyaya īśvaraḥ॥
verse17.explanation: Beyond the perishable and imperishable is the Supreme Purusha (Paramatman), the eternal Lord who pervades and sustains all creation.
verse17.sanskrit: उत्तमः पुरुषस्त्वन्यः परमात्मेत्युधाहृतः। यो लोकत्रयमाविश्य बिभर्त्यव्यय ईश्वरः।।

verse18.english: Yasmāt kṣaram atīto'ham akṣarād api cottamaḥ। Ato'smi loke vede ca prathitaḥ puruṣottamaḥ॥
verse18.explanation: Krishna is beyond both the perishable and imperishable, making Him the Supreme Being, known as Purushottama in the world and scriptures.
verse18.sanskrit: यस्मात्क्षरमतीतोऽहमक्षरादपि चोत्तमः। अतोऽस्मि लोके वेदे च प्रथितः पुरुषोत्तमः।।

verse19.english: Yo mām evam asammūḍho jānāti puruṣottamam। Sa sarva-vid bhajati māṁ sarva-bhāvena bhārata॥
verse19.explanation: One who recognizes Krishna as the Supreme Being and worships Him with full devotion attains true knowledge and liberation.
verse19.sanskrit: यो मामेवमसम्मूढो जानाति पुरुषोत्तमम्। स सर्वविद्भजति मां सर्वभावेन भारत।।

verse20.english: Iti guhya-tamaṁ śāstram idam uktaṁ mayānagha। Etad buddhvā buddhimān syāt kṛta-kṛtyaś ca bhārata॥
verse20.explanation: Krishna concludes the chapter by emphasizing that understanding this supreme teaching leads to wisdom and fulfillment of all life's purposes.
verse20.sanskrit: इति गुह्यतमं शास्त्रमिदमुक्तं मयानघ। एतद्बुद्ध्वा बुद्धिमान्स्यात्कृतकृत्यश्च भारत।।

verse1.english: Abhayaṁ sattva-saṁśuddhir jñāna-yoga-vyavasthitiḥ। Dānaṁ damaś ca yajñaś ca svādhyāyas tapa ārjavam॥
verse1.explanation: Krishna begins by listing the divine qualities that lead to liberation, emphasizing the importance of fearlessness, purity, and self-discipline.
verse1.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। अभयं सत्त्वसंशुद्धिर्ज्ञानयोगव्यवस्थितिः। दानं दमश्च यज्ञश्च स्वाध्यायस्तप आर्जवम्।।

verse2.english: Ahiṁsā satyam akrodhas tyāgaḥ śāntir apaiśunam। Dayā bhūteṣv aloluptvaṁ mārdavaṁ hrīr acāpalam॥
verse2.explanation: These additional divine qualities highlight non-violence, truth, and compassion, which are essential for a righteous life.
verse2.sanskrit: अहिंसा सत्यमक्रोधस्त्यागः शान्तिरपैशुनम्। दया भूतेष्वलोलुप्त्वं मार्दवं ह्रीरचापलम्।।

verse3.english: Tejaḥ kṣamā dhṛtiḥ śaucam adroho nātimānitā। Bhavanti sampadaṁ daivīm abhijātasya bhārata॥
verse3.explanation: The final qualities include strength, patience, purity, and humility, which together make up the divine nature.
verse3.sanskrit: तेजः क्षमा धृतिः शौचमद्रोहो नातिमानिता। भवन्ति सम्पदं दैवीमभिजातस्य भारत।।

verse4.english: Dambho darpo'bhimānaś ca krodhaḥ pāruṣyam eva ca। Ajñānaṁ cābhijātasya pārtha sampadām āsurīm॥
verse4.explanation: Krishna contrasts the divine qualities with those of the demoniac nature, which includes arrogance, anger, and ignorance.
verse4.sanskrit: दम्भो दर्पोऽभिमानश्च क्रोधः पारुष्यमेव च। अज्ञानं चाभिजातस्य पार्थ सम्पदामासुरीम्।।

verse5.english: Daivī sampad vimokṣāya nibandhāyāsurī matā। Mā śucaḥ sampadaṁ daivīm abhijāto'si pāṇḍava॥
verse5.explanation: The divine qualities lead to freedom, while the demoniac traits bind one to the material world. Krishna reassures Arjuna that he is born with divine qualities.
verse5.sanskrit: दैवी सम्पद्विमोक्षाय निबन्धायासुरी मता। मा शुचः सम्पदं दैवीमभिजातोऽसि पाण्डव।।

verse6.english: Dvau bhūta-sargau loke'smin daiva āsura eva ca। Daivo vistaraśaḥ prokta āsuraṁ pārtha me śṛṇu॥
verse6.explanation: Krishna explains that humanity is divided into those with divine qualities and those with demoniac traits. He has already described the divine and now will elaborate on the demoniac.
verse6.sanskrit: द्वौ भूतसर्गौ लोकेऽस्मिन्दैव आसुर एव च। दैवो विस्तरशः प्रोक्त आसुरं पार्थ मे शृणु।।

verse7.english: Pravṛttiṁ ca nivṛttiṁ ca janā na vidur āsurāḥ। Na śaucaṁ nāpi cācāro na satyaṁ teṣu vidyate॥
verse7.explanation: The demoniac individuals are ignorant of righteous conduct and are devoid of purity, discipline, and truth.
verse7.sanskrit: प्रवृत्तिं च निवृत्तिं च जना न विदुरासुराः। न शौचं नापि चाचारो न सत्यं तेषु विद्यते।।

verse8.english: Asatyam apratiṣṭhaṁ te jagad āhur anīśvaram। Aparaspara-sambhūtaṁ kim anyat kāma-haitukam॥
verse8.explanation: Those with demoniac nature deny the reality of the world, rejecting any divine authority and viewing life as merely a product of physical desires.

verse9.english: Etām dṛṣṭim avaṣṭabhya naṣṭātmāno'lpa-buddhayaḥ। Prabhavanty ugra-karmāṇaḥ kṣayāya jagato' hitāḥ॥
verse9.explanation: Such distorted views lead these individuals to destructive actions, harming themselves and the world around them.
verse9.sanskrit: एतां दृष्टिमवष्टभ्य नष्टात्मानोऽल्पबुद्धयः। प्रभवन्त्युग्रकर्माणः क्षयाय जगतोऽहिताः।।

verse10.english: Kāmam āśritya duṣpūraṁ dambha-māna-madānvitāḥ। Mohād gṛhītvāsad-grāhān pravartante'śuci-vratāḥ॥
verse10.explanation: Driven by endless desires and false pride, the demoniac are deluded, clinging to erroneous beliefs and impure actions.

verse11.english: Chintām aparimeyāṁ ca pralaya-antām upāśritāḥ। Kāma-upabhoga-paramā etāvad iti niścitāḥ॥
verse11.explanation: Their lives are consumed by worries, with the fulfillment of desires as their sole goal, leading them to believe that there is nothing beyond.
verse11.sanskrit: चिंतामपरिमेयां च प्रलयान्तामुपाश्रिताः। कामोपभोगपरमा एतावदिति निश्चिताः।।

verse12.english: Āśā-pāśa-śatair baddhāḥ kāma-krodha-parāyaṇāḥ। Īhante kāma-bhogārtham anyāyenārtha-sañcayān॥
verse12.explanation: Tied to hopes and desires, they pursue wealth through unrighteous means, driven by greed and anger.

verse13.english: Idam adya mayā labdham imaṁ prāpsye manoratham। Idam astīdam api me bhaviṣyati punar dhanam॥
verse13.explanation: Their thoughts are dominated by greed, always thinking about what they have acquired and what they will obtain in the future.
verse13.sanskrit: इदमद्य मया लब्धमिमं प्राप्स्ये मनोरथम्। इदमस्तीदमपि मे भविष्यति पुनर्धनम्।।

verse14.english: Asau mayā hataḥ śatrur haniṣye cāparān api। Īśvaro'ham ahaṁ bhogī siddho'haṁ balavān sukhī॥
verse14.explanation: They are filled with ego, believing themselves to be the controllers and enjoyers of all, delighting in their own imagined superiority.
verse14.sanskrit: असौ मया हतः शत्रुर्हनिष्ये चापरानपि। ईश्वरोऽहमहं भोगी सिद्धोऽहं बलवान्सुखी।।

verse15.english: Āḍhyo'bhijanavān asmi ko'nyaḥ asti sadṛśo mayā। Yakṣye dāsyāmi modiṣya ity ajñāna-vimohitāḥ॥
verse15.explanation: Their arrogance blinds them to reality, leading them to believe they are superior and righteous, even in their ignorance.
verse15.sanskrit: आद्योऽभिजनवानस्मि कोऽन्योऽस्ति सदृशो मया। यक्ष्ये दास्यामि मोदिष्य इत्यज्ञानविमोहिताः।।

verse16.english: Aneka-citta-vibhrāntā moha-jāla-samāvṛtāḥ। Prasaktāḥ kāma-bhogeṣu patanti narake'śucau॥
verse16.explanation: Lost in delusions and overwhelmed by desires, such people ultimately fall into suffering and degradation.
verse16.sanskrit: अनेकचित्तविभ्रान्ता मोहजालसमावृताः। प्रसक्ताः कामभोगेषु पतन्ति नरकेऽशुचौ।।

verse17.english: Ātma-sambhāvitāḥ stabdhā dhana-māna-madānvitāḥ। Yajante nāma-yajñais te dambhenāvidhi-pūrvakam॥
verse17.explanation: Their sacrifices and religious acts are hollow, performed for show rather than out of true devotion, driven by ego and pride.
verse17.sanskrit: आत्मसम्भाविताः स्तब्धा धनमानमदान्विताः। यजन्ते नामयज्ञैस्ते दम्भेनाविधिपूर्वकम्।।

verse18.english: Ahaṅkāraṁ balaṁ darpaṁ kāmaṁ krodhaṁ ca saṁśritāḥ। Mām ātma-para-deheṣu pradviṣanto'bhyasūyakāḥ॥
verse18.explanation: Consumed by ego and negative emotions, they despise the divine presence both within themselves and in others.
verse18.sanskrit: अहङ्कारं बलं दर्पं कामं क्रोधं च संश्रिताः। मामात्मपरदेहेषु प्रद्विषन्तोऽभ्यसूयकाः।।

verse19.english: Tān ahaṁ dviṣataḥ krūrān saṁsāreṣu narādhamān। Kṣipāmy ajasram aśubhān āsurīṣv eva yoniṣu॥
verse19.explanation: Krishna declares that those who are evil and malicious are condemned to be born repeatedly in demoniac circumstances, leading to further suffering.
verse19.sanskrit: तानहं द्विषतः क्रूरान्संसारेषु नराधमान्। क्षिपाम्यजस्रमशुभानासुरीष्वेव योनिषु।।

verse20.english: Āsurīṁ yonim āpannā mūḍhā janmani janmani। Mām aprāpyaiva kaunteya tato yānty adhamāṁ gatim॥
verse20.explanation: Such souls, trapped in demoniac births, fail to attain Krishna and fall deeper into darkness and ignorance.
verse20.sanskrit: आसुरीं योनिमापन्ना मूढा जन्मनि जन्मनि। मामप्राप्यैव कौन्तेय ततो यान्त्यधमां गतिम्।।

verse21.english: Tri-vidhaṁ narakasye'daṁ dvāraṁ nāśanam ātmanaḥ। Kāmaḥ krodhas tathā lobhas tasmād etat trayaṁ tyajet॥
verse21.explanation: Krishna warns against the destructive nature of lust, anger, and greed, which lead to self-destruction and should be avoided at all costs.
verse21.sanskrit: त्रिविधं नरकस्येदं द्वारं नाशनमात्मनः। कामः क्रोधस्तथा लोभस्तस्मादेतत्त्रयं त्यजेत्।।

verse22.english: Etair vimuktaḥ kaunteya tamo-dvārais tribhir naraḥ। Ācaraty ātmanaḥ śreyas tato yāti parāṁ gatim॥
verse22.explanation: By freeing oneself from these three vices, one can pursue righteousness and eventually attain the ultimate spiritual goal.
verse22.sanskrit: एतैर्विमुक्तः कौन्तेय तमोद्वारैस्त्रिभिर्नरः। आचरत्यात्मनः श्रेयस्ततो याति परां गतिम्।।

verse23.english: Yaḥ śāstra-vidhim utsṛjya vartate kāma-kārataḥ। Na sa siddhim avāpnoti na sukhaṁ na parāṁ gatim॥
verse23.explanation: Ignoring the guidance of the scriptures and acting out of selfish desire leads to neither spiritual progress nor true happiness.
verse23.sanskrit: यः शास्त्रविधिमुत्सृज्य वर्तते कामकारतः। न स सिद्धिमवाप्नोति न सुखं न परां गतिम्।।

verse24.english: Tasmāc chāstraṁ pramāṇaṁ te kāryākārya-vyavasthitau। Jñātvā śāstra-vidhānoktaṁ karma kartum ihārhasi॥
verse24.explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to follow the scriptures as the guide for righteous action, understanding what should and should not be done according to their teachings.
verse24.sanskrit: तस्माच्छास्त्रं प्रमाणं ते कार्याकार्यव्यवस्थितौ। ज्ञात्वा शास्त्रविधानोक्तं कर्म कर्तुमिहार्हसि।।

verse1.english: Arjuna uvāca। Ye śāstra-vidhim utsṛjya yajante śraddhayānvitāḥ। Teṣāṁ niṣṭhā tu kā kṛṣṇa sattvam āho rajas tamaḥ॥
verse1.explanation: Arjuna asks Krishna about the nature of faith in people who worship without following scriptural guidelines. He inquires whether such faith is in the mode of goodness, passion, or ignorance.
verse1.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच। ये शास्त्रविधिमुत्सृज्य यजन्ते श्रद्धयान्विताः। तेषां निष्ठा तु का कृष्ण सत्त्वमाहो रजस्तमः।।

verse2.english: Śrībhagavān uvāca। Tri-vidhā bhavati śraddhā dehināṁ sā svabhāva-jā। Sāttvikī rājasī caiva tāmasī ceti tāṁ śṛṇu॥
verse2.explanation: Krishna explains that faith arises from one's inherent nature and can be classified into three types—goodness, passion, and ignorance. Each type reflects the individual's character and tendencies.
verse2.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच। त्रिविधा भवति श्रद्धा देहिनां सा स्वभावजा। सात्त्विकी राजसी चैव तामसी चेति तां शृणु।।

verse3.english: Sattvānurūpā sarvasya śraddhā bhavati bhārata। Śraddhāmayo'yaṁ puruṣo yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ॥
verse3.explanation: Krishna highlights that a person's faith aligns with their inner nature and essentially defines who they are. One's faith shapes their identity and actions.
verse3.sanskrit: सत्त्वानुरूपा सर्वस्य श्रद्धा भवति भारत। श्रद्धामयोऽयं पुरुषो यो यच्छ्रद्धः स एव सः।।

verse4.english: Yajante sāttvikā devān yakṣa-rakṣāṁsi rājasāḥ। Pretān bhūta-gaṇāṁś cānye yajante tāmasā janāḥ॥
verse4.explanation: Different forms of worship correspond to the three modes of nature. People in goodness worship higher beings (gods), those in passion worship powerful beings (yakshas and rakshasas), and those in ignorance worship lower spirits.
verse4.sanskrit: यजन्ते सात्त्विका देवान्यक्षरक्षांसि राजसाः। प्रेतान्भूतगणांश्चान्ये यजन्ते तामसा जनाः।।

verse5.english: Aśāstra-vihitaṁ ghoraṁ tapyante ye tapo janāḥ। Dambhāhaṁkāra-saṁyuktāḥ kāma-rāga-balānvitāḥ॥
verse5.explanation: Krishna warns against severe and harmful austerities performed without scriptural backing. Such acts are driven by ego, desire, and attachment rather than true spiritual intent.
verse5.sanskrit: अशास्त्रविहितं घोरं तप्यन्ते ये तपो जनाः। दम्भाहङ्कारसंयुक्ताः कामरागबलान्विताः।।

verse6.english: Karṣayantaḥ śarīra-sthaṁ bhūta-grāmam acetasaḥ। Māṁ caivāntaḥ-śarīra-sthaṁ tān viddhy āsura-niścayān॥
verse6.explanation: Krishna condemns those who harm their own bodies and the divine presence within by performing extreme practices. Such actions are considered demoniacal.
verse6.sanskrit: कर्शयन्तः शरीरस्थं भूतग्राममचेतसः। मां चैवान्तःशरीरस्थं तान्विद्ध्यासुरनिश्चयान्।।

verse7.english: Āhāras tv api sarvasya tri-vidho bhavati priyaḥ। Yajñas tapas tathā dānaṁ teṣāṁ bhedam imaṁ śṛṇu॥
verse7.explanation: Krishna states that even food, sacrifice, austerity, and charity are influenced by the three modes of nature. He prepares to explain how these activities differ according to one's nature.
verse7.sanskrit: आहारस्त्वपि सर्वस्य त्रिविधो भवति प्रियः। यज्ञस्तपस्तथा दानं तेषां भेदमिमं शृणु।।

verse8.english: Āyuḥ-sattva-bala-ārogya-sukha-prīti-vivardhanāḥ। Rasyāḥ snigdhāḥ sthirā hṛdyā āhārā sāttvika-priyāḥ॥
verse8.explanation: Sattvic foods are those that promote longevity, vitality, and well-being. They are tasty, wholesome, and satisfying, preferred by those in the mode of goodness.
verse8.sanskrit: आयुःसत्त्वबलारोग्यसुखप्रीतिविवर्धनाः। रस्याः स्निग्धाः स्थिरा हृद्या आहाराः सात्त्विकप्रियाः।।

verse9.explanation: Rajasic foods, characterized by intense flavors, lead to discomfort and health issues. They are favored by those influenced by the mode of passion, resulting in suffering.

verse10.english: Yāta-yāmaṁ gata-rasaṁ pūti paryuṣitaṁ ca yat। Ucchiṣṭam api cāmedhyaṁ bhojanaṁ tāmasa-priyam॥
verse10.explanation: Tamasic foods are unhealthy and unclean, lacking freshness and taste. These foods are favored by those in the mode of ignorance, leading to degradation.
verse10.sanskrit: यातयामं गतरसं पूति पर्युषितं च यत्। उच्छिष्टमपि चामेध्यं भोजनं तामसप्रियम्।।

verse11.english: Aphala-ākāṅkṣibhir yajño vidhi-dṛṣṭo ya ijyate। Yaṣṭavyam eveti manaḥ samādhāya sa sāttvikaḥ॥
verse11.explanation: Sattvic sacrifices are performed as a duty, without attachment to the results, following scriptural guidelines. They are done with sincerity and dedication.
verse11.sanskrit: अफलाङ्क्षिभिर्यज्ञो विधिदृष्टो य इज्यते। यष्टव्यमेवेति मनः समाधाय स सात्त्विकः।।

verse12.english: Abhisandhāya tu phalaṁ dambhārtham api caiva yat। Ijyate bharata-śreṣṭha taṁ yajñaṁ viddhi rājasam॥
verse12.explanation: Rajasic sacrifices are driven by desires for rewards or to display one's devotion. Such sacrifices are performed with selfish motives rather than spiritual intent.
verse12.sanskrit: अभिसंधाय तु फलं दम्भार्थमपि चैव यत्। इज्यते भरतश्रेष्ठ तं यज्ञं विद्धि राजसम्।।

verse13.english: Vidhi-hīnam asṛṣṭānnaṁ mantra-hīnam adakṣiṇam। Śraddhā-virahitaṁ yajñaṁ tāmasaṁ paricakṣate॥
verse13.explanation: Tamasic sacrifices disregard scriptural rules, lack proper rituals, and are performed without faith or sincerity. These sacrifices are ineffective and spiritually harmful.
verse13.sanskrit: विधिहीनमसृष्टान्नं मन्त्रहीनमदक्षिणम्। श्रद्धाविरहितं यज्ञं तामसं परिचक्षते।।

verse14.english: Deva-dvija-guru-prājña-pūjanaṁ śaucam ārjavam। Brahmacaryam ahiṁsā ca śārīraṁ tapa ucyate॥
verse14.explanation: Krishna describes physical austerity as involving respect for the divine and elders, maintaining cleanliness, truthfulness, celibacy, and non-violence.
verse14.sanskrit: देवद्विजगुरुप्राज्ञपूजनं शौचमार्जवम्। ब्रह्मचर्यमहिंसा च शारीरं तप उच्यते।।

verse15.english: Anudvega-karaṁ vākyaṁ satyaṁ priyaṁ hitaṁ ca yat। Svādhyāya-abhyasanaṁ caiva vāṅmayaṁ tapa ucyate॥
verse15.explanation: Austerity of speech involves speaking truthfully, kindly, and beneficially, avoiding words that cause harm, and engaging in the study and recitation of sacred texts.
verse15.sanskrit: अनुद्वेगकरं वाक्यं सत्यं प्रियं हितं च यत्। स्वाध्यायाभ्यसनं चैव वाङ्मयं तप उच्यते।।

verse16.english: Manaḥ-prasādaḥ saumyatvaṁ maunam ātma-vinigrahaḥ। Bhāva-saṁśuddhir ity etat tapo mānasam ucyate॥
verse16.explanation: Mental austerity includes cultivating inner peace, gentleness, silence, self-restraint, and purity of thought. These practices lead to a disciplined and serene mind.
verse16.sanskrit: मनः प्रसादः सौम्यत्वं मौनमात्मविनिग्रहः। भावसंशुद्धिरित्येतत्तपो मानसमुच्यते।।

verse17.english: Śraddhayā parayā taptaṁ tapas tat tri-vidhaṁ naraiḥ। Aphala-ākāṅkṣibhir yuktaiḥ sāttvikaṁ paricakṣate॥
verse17.explanation: Sattvic austerity is characterized by self-discipline practiced with deep faith and without attachment to the fruits of the actions. It is done with pure intent and devotion.
verse17.sanskrit: श्रद्धया परया तप्तं तपस्तत्त्रिविधं नरैः। अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिर्युक्तैः सात्त्विकं परिचक्षते।।

verse18.english: Satkāra-māna-pūjārthaṁ tapo dambhena caiva yat। Kriyate tad iha proktaṁ rājasaṁ calam adhruvam॥
verse18.explanation: Rajasic austerities are motivated by the desire for recognition and are often accompanied by insincerity, making them fleeting and unreliable.
verse18.sanskrit: सत्कारमानपूजार्थं तपो दम्भेन चैव यत्। क्रियते तदिह प्रोक्तं राजसं चलमध्रुवम्॥

verse19.english: Mūḍha-grāheṇātmano yat pīḍayā kriyate tapaḥ। Parasya utsādana-arthaṁ vā tat tāmasam udāhṛtam॥
verse19.explanation: Tamasic austerities are characterized by ignorance, self-harm, and the intent to harm others, leading to negative consequences.
verse19.sanskrit: मूढग्राहेणात्मनो यत्पीडया क्रियते तपः। परस्योत्सादनार्थं वा तत्तामसमुदाहृतम्॥

verse20.english: Dātavyam iti yad dānaṁ dīyate'nupakāriṇe। Deśe kāle ca pātre ca tad dānaṁ sāttvikaṁ smṛtam॥
verse20.explanation: Sattvic charity is performed selflessly, with proper discernment, and without any expectation of reciprocation.
verse20.sanskrit: दातव्यमिति यद्दानं दीयतेऽनुपकारिणे। देशे काले च पात्रे च तद्दानं सात्त्विकं स्मृतम्॥

verse21.english: Yat tu pratyupakārārthaṁ phalam uddiśya vā punaḥ। Dīyate ca parikliṣṭaṁ tad dānaṁ rājasaṁ smṛtam॥
verse21.explanation: Rajasic charity is motivated by the desire for rewards or recognition, and is often done reluctantly, reflecting the self-centered nature of passion.
verse21.sanskrit: यत्तु प्रत्युपकारार्थं फलमुद्दिश्य वा पुनः। दीयते च परिक्लिष्टं तद्दानं राजसं स्मृतम्॥

verse22.english: Adeśa-kāle yad dānam apātrebhyaś ca dīyate। Asat-kṛtam avajñātaṁ tat tāmasam udāhṛtam॥
verse22.explanation: Tamasic charity is performed without proper consideration or respect, often leading to negative consequences and is considered impure.
verse22.sanskrit: अधर्मेण परिक्लिष्टं दानं यत्पात्युपासते। असत्कृतं तदविज्ञातं तत्तामसमुदाहृतम्॥

verse23.english: Om tat sad iti nirdeśo brahmaṇas tri-vidhaḥ smṛtaḥ। Brāhmaṇās tena vedāś ca yajñāś ca vihitāḥ purā॥
verse23.explanation: Krishna introduces the sacred syllables "Om Tat Sat," representing the Supreme Reality and the essence of creation, which are used in Vedic rituals and sacrifices.
verse23.sanskrit: ॐ तत्सदिति निर्देशो ब्रह्मणस्त्रिविधः स्मृतः। ब्राह्मणास्तेन वेदाश्च यज्ञाश्च विहिताः पुरा॥

verse24.english: Tasmād om ity udāhṛtya yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-kriyāḥ। Pravartante vidhānoktāḥ satataṁ brahma-vādinām॥
verse24.explanation: The sacred syllable "Om" is used to initiate all Vedic rituals, reflecting the connection with the divine and the importance of following scriptural injunctions.
verse24.sanskrit: तस्मादोमित्युदाहृत्य यज्ञदानतपःक्रियाः। प्रवर्तन्ते विधानोक्ताः सततं ब्रह्मवादिनाम्॥

verse25.english: Tathā iti anabhisandhāya phalaṁ yajña-tapaḥ-kriyāḥ। Dāna-kriyāś ca vividhāḥ kriyante mokṣa-kāṅkṣibhiḥ॥
verse25.explanation: The utterance of "Tat" signifies the selfless nature of acts performed without attachment to results, aimed at spiritual liberation.
verse25.sanskrit: तदित्यनभिसंधाय फलं यज्ञतपःक्रियाः। दानक्रियाश्च विविधाः क्रियन्ते मोक्षकाङ्क्षिभिः॥

verse26.english: Sad-bhāve sādhubhāve ca sad ity etat prayujyate। Praśaste karmaṇi tathā sa-cchabdaḥ pārtha yujyate॥
verse26.explanation: "Sat" signifies the true and the good, and is associated with acts that are considered auspicious and virtuous.
verse26.sanskrit: सत्भावे साधुभावे च सदित्येतत्प्रयुज्यते। प्रशस्ते कर्मणि तथा सच्छब्दः पार्थ युज्यते॥

verse27.english: Yajñe tapasi dāne ca sthitiḥ sad iti cocyate। Karma caiva tad-arthīyaṁ sad ity evābhidhīyate॥
verse27.explanation: "Sat" is also associated with perseverance in performing sacrifices, austerities, and charity, and with actions directed towards the Supreme.
verse27.sanskrit: यज्ञे तपसि दाने च स्थितिः सदिति चोच्यते। कर्म चैव तदर्थीयं सदित्येवाभिधीयते॥

verse28.english: Aśraddhayā hutaṁ dattaṁ tapas taptaṁ kṛtaṁ ca yat। Asad ity ucyate pārtha na ca tat pretya no iha॥
verse28.explanation: Acts performed without faith are considered "Asat" (unreal) and bear no lasting fruit, neither in this life nor in the next.
verse28.sanskrit: अश्रद्धया हुतं दत्तं तपस्तप्तं कृतं च यत्। असदित्युच्यते पार्थ न च तत्प्रेत्य नो इह॥

verse1.english: Arjuna uvāca। Sannyāsasya mahā-bāho tattvam icchāmi veditum। Tyāgasya ca hṛṣīkeśa pṛthak keśi-niṣūdana॥
verse1.explanation: Arjuna begins the final chapter by seeking clarification on the concepts of Sannyasa (renunciation) and Tyaga (renunciation of the fruits of actions), and how they differ.
verse1.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच: संन्यासस्य महाबाहो तत्त्वमिच्छामि वेदितुम्। त्यागस्य च हृषीकेश पृथक्केशिनिषूदन॥

verse2.english: Śrībhagavān uvāca। Kāmyānāṁ karmaṇāṁ nyāsaṁ sannyāsaṁ kavayo viduḥ। Sarva-karma-phala-tyāgaṁ prāhus tyāgaṁ vicakṣaṇāḥ॥
verse2.explanation: Krishna defines Sannyasa as the renunciation of actions driven by desires, while Tyaga is the renunciation of the fruits or outcomes of all actions.
verse2.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच: काम्यानां कर्मणां न्यासं संन्यासं कवयो विदुः। सर्वकर्मफलत्यागं प्राहुस्त्यागं विचक्षणाः॥

verse3.english: Tyājyaṁ doṣavad ity eke karma prāhur manīṣiṇaḥ। Yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-karma na tyājyam iti cāpare॥
verse3.explanation: There are differing views on renunciation: some argue that all actions should be abandoned due to their potential for attachment, while others believe that certain righteous actions should not be forsaken.
verse3.sanskrit: त्याज्यं दोषवदित्येके कर्म प्राहुर्मनीषिणः। यज्ञदानतपःकर्म न त्याज्यमिति चापरे॥

verse4.english: Niḥśreyasam anusam-labhya karma-tyāgād vijānatām। Na ca sannyāsam iccheyus tatra kāścit sahā-jvarāḥ॥
verse4.explanation: Krishna promises to clarify the concept of renunciation, explaining that it can be categorized into three types, corresponding to the three modes of nature (Sattva, Rajas, Tamas).
verse4.sanskrit: निश्‍चयं श्रृणु मे तत्र त्यागे भरतसत्तम। त्यागो हि पुरुषव्याघ्र त्रिविधः संप्रकीर्तितः॥

verse5.english: Yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-karma na tyājyaṁ kāryam eva tat। Yajño dānaṁ tapaś caiva pāvanāni manīṣiṇām॥
verse5.explanation: Krishna emphasizes that acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity should be maintained as they purify the performer and are essential for spiritual progress.
verse5.sanskrit: यज्ञदानतपःकर्म न त्याज्यं कार्यमेव तत्। यज्ञो दानं तपश्चैव पावनानि मनीषिणाम्॥

verse6.english: Etāny api tu karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā phalāni ca। Kartavyāni iti me pārtha niścitaṁ matam uttamam॥
verse6.explanation: Krishna advises that these actions should be done selflessly, without attachment to the results, which is the highest form of renunciation
verse6.sanskrit: एतान्यपि तु कर्माणि संगं त्यक्त्वा फलानि च। कर्तव्यानि इति मे पार्थ निश्चितं मतमुत्तमम्॥

verse7.english: Niyatasya tu sannyāsaḥ karmaṇo nopapadyate। Mohāt tasya parityāgas tāmasaḥ parikīrtitaḥ॥
verse7.explanation: Abandoning one’s prescribed duties due to confusion or misunderstanding is considered Tamasic, or an act of ignorance.
verse7.sanskrit: नियतस्य तु संन्यासः कर्मणो नोपपद्यते। मोहात्तस्य परित्यागस्तामसः परिकीर्तितः॥

verse8.english: Duḥkham ity eva yat karma kāya-kleśa-bhayāt tyajet। Sa kṛtvā rājasaṁ tyāgaṁ naiva tyāga-phalaṁ labhet॥
verse8.explanation: Renunciation driven by fear of hardship or discomfort is classified as Rajasic, and it does not lead to true spiritual benefits.
verse8.sanskrit: दुःखमित्येव यत्कर्म कायक्लेशभयात्त्यजेत्। स कृत्वा राजसं त्यागं नैव त्यागफलं लभेत॥

verse9.english: Kāryam ity eva yat karma niyataṁ kriyate'rjuna। Saṅgaṁ tyaktvā phalaṁ caiva sa tyāgaḥ sāttviko mataḥ॥
verse9.explanation: Sattvic renunciation involves performing one’s duties without attachment and without desire for the results, purely out of a sense of obligation.
verse9.sanskrit: कार्यमित्येव यत्कर्म नियतं क्रियतेऽर्जुन। संगं त्यक्त्वा फलं चैव स त्यागः सात्त्विको मतः॥

verse10.english: Na dveṣṭy akusalaṁ karma kuśale nānuṣajjate। Tyāgī sattva-samāviṣṭo medhāvī chinna-saṁśayaḥ॥
verse10.explanation: A person who is established in Sattva is indifferent to the nature of the work, whether pleasant or unpleasant, and remains free from doubts, embodying true renunciation.
verse10.sanskrit: न द्वेष्ट्यकुशलं कर्म कुशले नानुषज्जते। त्यागी सत्त्वसमाविष्टो मेधावी छिन्नसंशयः॥

verse11.english: Na hi deha-bhṛtā śakyaṁ tyaktuṁ karmāṇy aśeṣataḥ। Yas tu karma-phala-tyāgī sa tyāgīty abhidhīyate॥
verse11.explanation: Complete renunciation of all action is impractical, but renouncing the desire for the fruits of action is considered true renunciation.
verse11.sanskrit: न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः। यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते॥

verse12.english: Aniṣṭam iṣṭaṁ miśraṁ ca tri-vidhaṁ karmaṇaḥ phalam। Bhaviṣyati tyāgināṁ pretya na tu sannyāsināṁ kvacit॥
verse12.explanation: Those who renounce attachment to the outcomes of their actions are not bound by the threefold results (pleasant, unpleasant, and mixed), unlike those who act with attachment.
verse12.sanskrit: अनिष्टमिष्टं मिश्रं च त्रिविधं कर्मणः फलम्। भवत्यत्यागिनां प्रेत्य न तु संन्यासिनां क्वचित्॥

verse13.english: Pañcaitāni mahā-bāho kāraṇāni nibodha me। Sāṅkhye kṛtānte proktāni siddhaye sarva-karmaṇām॥
verse13.explanation: Krishna introduces the five factors involved in the performance of any action, as explained in the Sankhya philosophy.
verse13.sanskrit: पञ्चैतानि महाबाहो कारणानि निबोध मे। साङ्ख्ये कृतान्ते प्रोक्तानि सिद्धये सर्वकर्मणाम्॥

verse14.english: Adhiṣṭhānaṁ tathā kartā karaṇaṁ ca pṛthag-vidham। Vividhāś ca pṛthak-ceṣṭā daivaṁ caivātra pañcamam॥
verse14.explanation: The five causes of action are the body (the place of action), the doer (the individual soul), the senses (instruments of action), the efforts (various activities), and divine providence (the Supreme Lord’s influence).
verse14.sanskrit: अधिष्ठानं तथा कर्ता करणं च पृथग्विधम्। विविधाश्च पृथक्चेष्टा दैवं चैवात्र पञ्चमम्॥

verse15.english: Śarīra-vāṅ-manobhir yat karma prārabhate naraḥ। Nyāyyaṁ vā viparītaṁ vā pañcaitē tasya hetavaḥ॥
verse15.explanation: Every action, whether moral or immoral, involves these five causes. Therefore, the doer alone is not responsible for the results of actions.
verse15.sanskrit: शरीरवाङ्मनोभिर्यत्कर्म प्रारभते नरः। न्याय्यं वा विपरीतं वा पञ्चैते तस्य हेतवः॥

verse16.english: Tatraivaṁ sati kartāram ātmānaṁ kevalaṁ tu yaḥ। Paśyaty akṛta-buddhitvān na sa paśyati durmatiḥ॥
verse16.explanation: Those who see themselves as the sole doer, without recognizing the other factors, are misguided and lack true understanding.
verse16.sanskrit: तत्रैवं सति कर्तारमात्मानं केवलं तु यः। पश्यत्यकृतबुद्धित्वान्न स पश्यति दुर्मतिः॥

verse17.english: Yasya nāhaṅkṛto bhāvo buddhir yasya na lipyate। Hatvā'pi sa imāṁl lokān na hanti na nibadhyate॥
verse17.explanation: A person free from ego and selfish motives is not bound by their actions, even if they involve seemingly harmful activities, as they act without attachment.
verse17.sanskrit: यस्य नाहंकृतो भावो बुद्धिर्यस्य न लिप्यते। हत्वापि स इमाँल्लोकान्न हन्ति न निबध्यते॥

verse18.english: Jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ parijñātā tri-vidhā karma-codanā। Karaṇaṁ karma karte'ti tri-vidhaḥ karma-saṅgrahaḥ॥
verse18.explanation: Action is driven by three factors: knowledge, the object of knowledge, and the knower. It is composed of the instrument (body and senses), the act itself, and the doer.
verse18.sanskrit: ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं परिज्ञाता त्रिविधा कर्मचोदना। करणं कर्म कर्तेति त्रिविधः कर्मसङ्ग्रहः॥

verse19.english: Jñānaṁ karma ca kartā ca tri-dhaiva guṇa-bhedataḥ। Procyate guṇa-saṅkhyāne yathāvac chṛṇu tāny api॥
verse19.explanation: Krishna explains that knowledge, action, and the doer can each be classified according to the three gunas (Sattva, Rajas, Tamas), influencing their nature.
verse19.sanskrit: ज्ञानं कर्म च कर्ता च त्रिधैव गुणभेदतः। प्रोच्यते गुणसंख्याने यथावच्छृणु तान्यपि॥

verse20.english: Sarva-bhūteṣu yenaikaṁ bhāvam avyayam īkṣate। Avibhaktaṁ vibhakteṣu taj-jñānaṁ viddhi sāttvikam॥
verse20.explanation: Sattvic knowledge recognizes the unity of all beings, seeing the same divine essence in everyone, beyond external differences.
verse20.sanskrit: सर्वभूतेषु येनैकं भावमव्ययमीक्षते। अविभक्तं विभक्तेषु तज्ज्ञानं विद्धि सात्त्विकम्॥

verse21.english: Pṛthaktvena tu yat jñānaṁ nānā-bhāvān pṛthag-vidhān। Vetti sarveṣu bhūteṣu taj-jñānaṁ viddhi rājasam॥
verse21.explanation: Rajasic knowledge perceives the world in terms of diversity and separation, focusing on the differences between beings.
verse21.sanskrit: पृथक्त्वेन तु यज्ज्ञानं नानाभावान्पृथग्विधान्। वेत्ति सर्वेषु भूतेषु तज्ज्ञानं विद्धि राजसम्॥

verse22.english: Yat tu kṛtsna-vad ekasmin kārye sakta-mahāhetukam। Atattvārtha-vad alpaṁ ca tat tāmasam udāhṛtam॥
verse22.explanation: Tamasic knowledge is limited, seeing only a partial reality, ignoring the bigger picture, and is often baseless and insignificant.
verse22.sanskrit: यत्तु कृत्स्नवदेकस्मिन्कार्ये सक्तमहैतुकम्। अति तुच्चं तदज्ञानं तत्तामसमुदाहृतम्॥

verse23.english: Niyataṁ saṅga-rahitam arāga-dveṣataḥ kṛtam। Aphala-prepsunā karma yat tat sāttvikam ucyate॥
verse23.explanation: Sattvic action is performed in accordance with duty, without attachment, and without being influenced by likes or dislikes, and without desire for results.
verse23.sanskrit: नियतं सङ्गरहितमरागद्वेषतः कृतम्। अफलप्रेप्सुना कर्म यत्तत्सात्त्विकमुच्यते॥

verse24.english: Yat tu kāmepsunā karma sāhaṅkāreṇa vā punaḥ। Kriyate bahulā-yāsaṁ tad rājasam udāhṛtam॥
verse24.explanation: Rajasic action is motivated by desire and ego, often requiring significant effort and leading to attachment.
verse24.sanskrit: यत्तु कामेप्सुना कर्म साहङ्कारेण वा पुनः। क्रियते बहुलायासं तद्राजसमुदाहृतम्॥

verse25.english: Anubandhaṁ kṣayaṁ hiṁsām anapekṣya ca pauruṣam। Mohād ārabhyate karma yat tat tāmasam ucyate॥
verse25.explanation: Tamasic action is performed without foresight, consideration of consequences, or regard for the harm it may cause, driven by ignorance.
verse25.sanskrit: अनुबन्धं क्षयं हंस्यं अनवेक्ष्य च पौरुषम्। मोहादारभ्यते कर्म यत्तत्तामसमुच्यते॥

verse26.english: Mukta-saṅgo'nahaṁ-vādī dhṛty-utsāha-samanvitaḥ। Siddhy-asiddhyor nirvikāraḥ kartā sāttvika ucyate॥
verse26.explanation: A Sattvic doer performs actions without attachment, with determination and enthusiasm, remaining unaffected by the outcomes.
verse26.sanskrit: मुक्तसङ्गोऽनहंवादी धृत्युत्साहसमन्वितः। सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योर्निर्विकारः कर्ता सात्त्विक उच्यते॥

verse27.english: Rāgī karma-phala-prepsur lubdho hiṁsātmako'śuciḥ। Harṣa-śokānvitaḥ kartā rājasaḥ parikīrtitaḥ॥
verse27.explanation: A Rajasic doer is driven by personal desires, greed, and emotional fluctuations, often engaging in harmful or impure actions.
verse27.sanskrit: रागी कर्मफलप्रेप्सुर्लुब्धो हिंसात्मकोऽशुचिः। हर्षशोकान्वितः कर्ता राजसः परिकीर्तितः॥

verse28.english: Ayuktaḥ prākṛtaḥ stabdhaḥ śaṭho naiṣkṛtiko'lasaḥ। Viṣādī dīrgha-sūtrī ca kartā tāmasa ucyate॥
verse28.explanation: A Tamasic doer is characterized by instability, stubbornness, deceit, laziness, and a tendency to delay actions, leading to negative outcomes.
verse28.sanskrit: अयुक्तः प्राकृतः स्तब्धः शठो नैष्कृतिकोऽलसः। विषादी दीर्घसूत्री च कर्ता तामस उच्यते॥

verse29.english: Buddher bhedaṁ dhṛteś caiva guṇatas tri-vidhaṁ śṛṇu। Procyamānam aśeṣeṇa pṛthaktvena dhanañjaya॥
verse29.explanation: Krishna explains that intellect (Buddhi) and determination (Dhriti) are also influenced by the three gunas, and He elaborates on their differences.
verse29.sanskrit: बुद्धेर्भेदं धृतेश्चैव गुणतस्त्रिविधं श्रृणु। प्रोच्यमानमशेषेण पृथक्त्वेन धनञ्जय॥

verse30.english: Pravṛttiṁ ca nivṛttiṁ ca kāryākārye bhaya-abhaye। Bandhaṁ mokṣaṁ ca yā vetti buddhiḥ sā pārtha sāttvikī॥
verse30.explanation: Sattvic intellect is discerning, knowing the difference between right and wrong, action and renunciation, and the path to liberation.
verse30.sanskrit: प्रवृत्तिं च निवृत्तिं च कार्याकार्ये भयाभये। बन्धं मोक्षं च या वेत्ति बुद्धिः सा पार्थ सात्त्विकी॥

verse31.english: Yayā dharmam adharmam ca kāryaṁ ca akāryam eva ca। Ayathāvat prajānāti buddhiḥ sā pārtha rājasī॥
verse31.explanation: Rajasic intellect is clouded by confusion, leading to a distorted understanding of right and wrong, and the appropriate course of action.
verse31.sanskrit: यया धर्ममधर्मं च कार्यं चाकार्यमेव च। अयथावत्प्रजानाति बुद्धिः सा पार्थ राजसी॥

verse32.english: Adharmaṁ dharmam iti yā manyate tamasā-vṛtā। Sarvārthān viparītāṁś ca buddhiḥ sā pārtha tāmasī॥
verse32.explanation: Tamasic intellect is deluded, mistaking unrighteousness for righteousness, and is unable to see things as they truly are.
verse32.sanskrit: अधर्मं धर्ममिति या मन्यते तमसावृता। सर्वार्थान्विपरीतांश्च बुद्धिः सा पार्थ तामसी॥

verse33.english: Dhṛtyā yayā dhārayate manaḥ-prāṇendriya-kriyāḥ। Yogena avyabhicāriṇyā dhṛtiḥ sā pārtha sāttvikī॥
verse33.explanation: Sattvic determination is characterized by the disciplined control of mind, body, and senses, maintained through unwavering commitment to the practice of yoga.
verse33.sanskrit: धृत्या यया धारयते मनःप्राणेन्द्रियक्रियाः। योगेनाव्यभिचारिण्या धृतिः सा पार्थ सात्त्विकी॥

verse34.english: Yayā tu dharma-kāma-arthān dhṛtyā dhārayate'rjuna। Prasaṅgena phalākāṅkṣī dhṛtiḥ sā pārtha rājasī॥
verse34.explanation: Rajasic determination is motivated by desire for material gain, pleasure, and wealth, and is marked by attachment to the outcomes of actions.
verse34.sanskrit: यया तु धर्मकामार्थान्धृत्या धारयतेऽर्जुन। प्रसङ्गेन फलाकाङ्क्षी धृतिः सा पार्थ राजसी॥

verse35.english: Yayā svapnaṁ bhayaṁ śokaṁ viṣādaṁ madam eva ca। Na vimūncati durmedhā dhṛtiḥ sā pārtha tāmasī॥
verse35.explanation: Tamasic determination is characterized by inertia, fear, grief, despair, and arrogance, and is unable to break free from these negative states.
verse35.sanskrit: यया स्वप्नं भयं शोकं विषादं मदमेव च। न विमुञ्चति दुर्मेधा धृतिः सा पार्थ तामसी॥

verse36.english: Sukhaṁ tv idānīṁ tri-vidhaṁ śṛṇu me bharatarṣabha। Abhyāsād ramate yatra duḥkhāntaṁ ca nigacchati॥
verse36.explanation: Krishna introduces the concept of threefold happiness, explaining how different types of happiness are experienced based on the gunas.
verse36.sanskrit: सुखं त्विदानीं त्रिविधं श्रृणु मे भरतर्षभ। अभ्यासाद्रमते यत्र दुःखान्तं च निगच्छति॥

verse37.english: Yat tad agre viṣam iva pariṇāme'mṛto-pamam। Tat sukhaṁ sāttvikaṁ proktam ātma-buddhi-prasādajam॥
verse37.explanation: Sattvic happiness may initially appear difficult or unpleasant, but ultimately leads to inner peace and spiritual fulfillment.
verse37.sanskrit: यत्तदग्रे विषमिव परिणामेऽमृतोपमम्। तत्सुखं सात्त्विकं प्रोक्तमात्मबुद्धिप्रसादजम्॥

verse38.english: Viṣayendriya-saṁyogād yat tad agre'mṛto-pamam। Pariṇāme viṣam iva tat sukhaṁ rājasaṁ smṛtam॥
verse38.explanation: Rajasic happiness comes from sensory pleasures, which may seem delightful initially but eventually lead to dissatisfaction and suffering.
verse38.sanskrit: विषयेन्द्रियसंयोगाद्यत्तदग्रेऽमृतोपमम्। परिणामे विषमिव तत्सुखं राजसं स्मृतम्॥

verse39.english: Yad agre cānubandhe ca sukhaṁ mohanam ātmanaḥ। Nidrā-lasya-pramādotthaṁ tat tāmasam udāhṛtam॥
verse39.explanation: Tamasic happiness is derived from ignorance, laziness, and delusion, offering no real or lasting fulfillment, only perpetuating ignorance.
verse39.sanskrit: यदग्रे चानुबन्धे च सुखं मोहनमात्मनः। निद्रालस्यप्रमादोत्थं तत् तामसमुदाहृतम्॥

verse40.english: Na tad asti pṛthivyāṁ vā divi deveṣu vā punaḥ। Sattvaṁ prakṛti-jair muktaṁ yad ebhiḥ syāt tribhir guṇaiḥ॥
verse40.explanation: All beings, whether on earth or in higher realms, are influenced by the three gunas, and none can transcend them without spiritual practice.
verse40.sanskrit: न तदस्ति पृथिव्यां वा दिवि देवेषु वा पुनः। सत्त्वं प्रकृतिजैर्मुक्तं यदेभिः स्यात्त्रिभिर्गुणैः॥

verse41.english: Brāhmaṇa-kṣatriya-viśāṁ śūdrāṇāṁ ca paraṁtapa। Karmāṇi pravi-bhaktāni svabhāva-prabhavair guṇaiḥ॥
verse41.explanation: Krishna explains that the duties of the four varnas (Brahmanas, Kshatriyas, Vaishyas, Shudras) are determined by their inherent qualities and nature, not by birth alone.
verse41.sanskrit: ब्राह्मणक्षत्रियविशां शूद्राणां च परन्तप। कर्माणि प्रविभक्तानि स्वभावप्रभवैर्गुणैः॥

verse42.english: Śamo damaḥ tapaḥ śaucaṁ kṣāntir ārjavam eva ca। Jñānaṁ vijñānam āstikyaṁ brahma-karma svabhāva-jam॥
verse42.explanation: The qualities of a Brahmana include inner peace, self-control, spiritual discipline, purity, patience, honesty, knowledge, wisdom, and faith.
verse42.sanskrit: शमो दमस्तपः शौचं क्षान्तिरार्जवमेव च। ज्ञानं विज्ञानमास्तिक्यं ब्रह्मकर्म स्वभावजम्॥

verse43.english: Śauryaṁ tejo dhṛtiḥ dākṣyaṁ yuddhe cāpy apalāyanam। Dānam īśvara-bhāvaś ca kṣātraṁ karma svabhāva-jam॥
verse43.explanation: The qualities of a Kshatriya include bravery, strength, determination, strategic thinking, fearlessness in battle, generosity, and leadership.
verse43.sanskrit: शौर्यं तेजो धृतिर्दाक्ष्यं युद्धे चाप्यपलायनम्। दानमीश्वरभावश्च क्षात्रं कर्म स्वभावजम्॥

verse44.english: Kṛṣi-go-rakṣya-vāṇijyaṁ vaiśya-karma svabhāva-jam। Paricaryātmakaṁ karma śūdrasyāpi svabhāva-jam॥
verse44.explanation: The natural duties of a Vaishya involve agriculture, commerce, and cattle-rearing, while the duties of a Shudra involve service and labor for others.
verse44.sanskrit: कृषिगौरक्ष्यवाणिज्यं वैश्यकर्म स्वभावजम्। परिचर्यात्मकं कर्म शूद्रस्यापि स्वभावजम्॥

verse45.english: Sve sve karmaṇy abhirataḥ saṁsiddhiṁ labhate naraḥ। Svakarma-nirataḥ siddhiṁ yathā vindati tac chṛṇu॥
verse45.explanation: Perfection is attained by fulfilling one's own duties according to their nature. Krishna emphasizes the importance of performing one’s prescribed duties.
verse45.sanskrit: स्वे स्वे कर्मण्यभिरतः संसिद्धिं लभते नरः। स्वकर्मनिरतः सिद्धिं यथा विन्दति तच्छृणु॥

verse46.english: Yataḥ pravṛttir bhūtānāṁ yena sarvam idaṁ tatam। Sva-karmaṇā tam abhyarcya siddhiṁ vindati mānavaḥ॥
verse46.explanation: Worshipping the Supreme by performing one’s duties with devotion leads to spiritual perfection.
verse46.sanskrit: यतः प्रवृत्तिर्भूतानां येन सर्वमिदं ततम्। स्वकर्मणा तमभ्यर्च्य सिद्धिं विन्दति मानवः॥

verse47.english: Śreyān sva-dharmo viguṇaḥ para-dharmāt sv-anuṣṭhitāt। Sva-dharme nidhanaṁ śreyaḥ para-dharmo bhayāvahaḥ॥
verse47.explanation: Krishna advises that it is preferable to follow one’s own path, even with flaws, than to imitate someone else’s path perfectly, as following one’s nature leads to growth without sin.
verse47.sanskrit: श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्। स्वभावनियतं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम्॥

verse48.english: Sahajaṁ karma kaunteya sa-doṣam api na tyajet। Sarvārambhā hi doṣeṇa dhūmena-gnir ivāvṛtāḥ॥
verse48.explanation: Every action has some imperfections, but one should still pursue their inherent duties, as this leads to progress.
verse48.sanskrit: सहजं कर्म कौन्तेय सदोषमपि न त्यजेत्। सर्वारम्भा हि दोषेण धूमेनाग्निरिवावृताः॥

verse49.english: Asakta-buddhiḥ sarvatra jitātmā vigata-spṛhaḥ। Naiṣkarmya-siddhiṁ paramāṁ saṁnyāsenādhigacchati॥
verse49.explanation: A person who is detached, self-controlled, and free from desires attains liberation through renunciation.
verse49.sanskrit: असक्तबुद्धिः सर्वत्र जितात्मा विगतस्पृहः। नैष्कर्म्यसिद्धिं परमां संन्यासेनाधिगच्छति॥

verse50.english: Siddhiṁ prāpto yathā brahma tathāpnoti nibodha me। Samāsenaiva kaunteya niṣṭhā jñānasya yā parā॥
verse50.explanation: Krishna explains how one who has attained perfection in their duties reaches the ultimate state of Brahman, the supreme spiritual knowledge.
verse50.sanskrit: सिद्धिं प्राप्तो यथा ब्रह्म तथाप्नोति निबोध मे। समासेनैव कौन्तेय निष्ठा ज्ञानस्य या परा॥

verse51.english: Buddhyā viśuddhayā yukto dhṛtyā''tmānaṁ niyamya ca। Śabdādīn viṣayāṁs tyaktvā rāga-dveṣau vyudasya ca॥
verse51.explanation: A person with a pure intellect, self-control, and detachment from sensory objects and emotions like attachment and aversion, prepares for the path to liberation.
verse51.sanskrit: बुद्ध्या विशुद्धया युक्तो धृत्याऽऽत्मानं नियम्य च। शब्दादीन्विषयांस्त्यक्त्वा रागद्वेषौ व्युदस्य च॥

verse52.english: Vivikta-sevī laghv-āśī yata-vāk-kāya-mānasaḥ। Dhyāna-yoga-paro nityaṁ vairāgyaṁ samupāśritaḥ॥
verse52.explanation: Such a person lives a life of simplicity, solitude, and meditation, constantly seeking detachment and spiritual enlightenment.
verse52.sanskrit: विविक्तसेवी लघ्वाशी यतवाक्कायमानसः। ध्यानयोगपरो नित्यं वैराग्यं समुपाश्रितः॥

verse53.english: Ahaṅkāraṁ balaṁ darpaṁ kāmaṁ krodhaṁ parigraham। Vimucya nirmamaḥ śānto brahma-bhūyāya kalpate॥
verse53.explanation: By relinquishing ego, pride, desire, anger, and attachment, and becoming calm and detached, one becomes eligible to attain Brahman, or supreme realization.
verse53.sanskrit: अहङ्कारं बलं दर्पं कामं क्रोधं परिग्रहम्। विमुच्य निर्ममः शान्तो ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते॥

verse54.english: Brahma-bhūtaḥ prasannātmā na śocati na kāṅkṣati। Samaḥ sarveṣu bhūteṣu mad-bhaktiṁ labhate parām॥
verse54.explanation: A person who has realized Brahman is peaceful, free from sorrow and desire, and sees all beings equally, and thus attains the highest form of devotion to Krishna.
verse54.sanskrit: ब्रह्मभूतः प्रसन्नात्मा न शोचति न काङ्क्षति। समः सर्वेषु भूतेषु मद्भक्तिं लभते पराम्॥

verse55.english: Bhaktyā mām abhijānāti yāvān yaś cāsmi tattvataḥ। Tato māṁ tattvato jñātvā viśate tad-anantaram॥
verse55.explanation: True knowledge of Krishna, attained through devotion, leads to unity with the Divine.
verse55.sanskrit: भक्त्या मामभिजानाति यावान्यश्चास्मि तत्त्वतः। ततो मां तत्त्वतो ज्ञात्वा विशते तदनन्तरम्॥

verse56.english: Sarva-karmāṇy api sadā kurvāṇo mad-vyapāśrayaḥ। Mat-prasādād avāpnoti śāśvataṁ padam avyayam॥
